post_content:
The causes of anxiety disorders are not fully known, however, scientists believe that they are most likely the result of a combination of factors including changes in the brain, environmental stress, genetics, and psychological and developmental factors. Anxiety can also manifest due to medical conditions such as hyperthyroidism, heart failure or COPD, and the use of certain medications or drugs such as corticosteroids, cocaine, amphetamines, and excessive amounts of caffeine. Since the causes are varied in nature, but the end result (that of anxiousness) is still the same, the only way to treat anxiety disorders—without medication—appears to be to discover a pattern for symptoms and to try and then isolate triggers. This allows an individual to at the very least avoid a possible anxious situation. But avoidance is only half of the answer. While an anxiety disorder may not have a cure to the extent that the person afflicted will never have to go through extreme anxiety, it doesn’t mean that there isn’t a way to satisfactorily overcome the disorder. Once an individual knows what causes the anxiety to flare up they can preempt the negative experience by modifying their attitude and behavior going in to the situation as opposed to just reacting to it. For example, if a cramped space like a subway car or an elevator causes you anxiety, embrace the time spent in this triggering space by normalizing the area. This can be achieved by being mindful of your breathing, speaking to a stranger with a prepared, friendly greeting, or opening up your posture and putting a smile on your face to invite positivity. In the end mindfulness is key to overcoming social anxiety.

The Bottom Line – For Your Health!

Social anxiety in an age of virtual worlds, ever distancing relationships, and instant gratification is becoming a big problem. Because anxiety disorders cause extreme discomfort in the individual, escapism is one of the easiest solutions to employ—particularly because one can escape by simply taking out their phone. But the only way to overcome anxiety is to face it with the knowledge of one’s self. The mind is malleable and, if you suffer from an anxiety disorder, this fact along with the idea that the avoidance of anxiety inducing situations can only take you so far should help motivate you to kick anxiety to the curb.
MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_content: The benefits of regular physical activity are enormous. In addition to weight management, stress relief and an improved sense of well–being, the performance of regular physical exercise reduces the risk of many diseases and conditions, improves the overall quality of one’s life and helps maintain the functional independence of older adults. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
post_title: people who are physically active for approximately 7 hours per week have a 40 percent lower risk of dying at an early age than those who are active for less than 30 minutes per week.

ID: The following items are benefits of physical activity:
The Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP) conducted a major study of 3
post_author: 234 people at high risk for diabetes. The study’s findings showed that people can delay and possibly prevent type 2 diabetes by losing 5 to 7 percent of their total body weight
post_date: performing at least 30 minutes of moderate–intensity physical activity 5 days a week and eating a variety of healthy foods that are high in fiber and low in fat. Participants in the DPP who made lifestyle changes in diet and exercise reduced their risk of developing type 2 diabetes by 58 percent. This was almost twice the reduction seen in the group that received medication (31 percent).

ID: Regular activity strengthens the heart muscle
post_author: lowers blood pressure
post_date: raises high–density lipoprotein levels (good cholesterol)
post_content: improves blood flow and helps the heart to function more efficiently. All of these benefits reduce the risk of peripheral vascular disease
post_excerpt: heart disease and high blood pressure.

post_author: bones become stronger — and stay stronger — with regular exercise
post_date: preventing or even reversing any increased rates of bone loss.

ID: A study published in PLoS Medicine found that physical activity decreases an active individual’s obesity risk by 40 percent. Another significant finding in the study showed that an individual with a greater genetic predisposition to obesity
post_author: when compared to an individual with a lesser predisposition to obesity
post_date: can markedly decrease his or her likelihood of becoming obese by becoming physically active.

ID: In addition to items listed above
post_author: physical activity also produces the following benefits:

ID: <li>Decreases the risk of certain forms of cancer (e.g.
post_author: colon and breast cancers)
C–reactive protein and other CHD indicators

ID: • Plays an important role in weight management
<li>Preserves bone mass and reduces the risk of falling
post_author: thereby helping to maintain the functional independence of older adults

ID: • May prevent and improve mild to moderate depressive disorders and anxiety

post_author: well–being
post_date: quality of life and cognitive function

ID: • Is associated with a lower risk of cognitive decline and dementia
• Is associated with fewer problems with erectile dysfunction in men

post_author: length
post_date: type and intensity of exercise an individual performs should be determined by an individual’s goals
post_content: age
post_excerpt: skills
comment_status: most experts agree that most adults should engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate–intensity exercise each week.

ID: To avoid the dangers of physical inactivity and to reap the many benefits exercise has to offer
post_author: it is important that physical activity becomes a regular and permanent habit that is incorporated into your daily life. It is one of the easiest and one of the most effective ways in which you can improve your overall health.

The results showed that \"costs of absenteeism rise with clinical weight classification for both women and men
post_title: and vary across occupation. Absenteeism costs associated with obesity total $4.3 billion annually in the United States.\"

ID: The authors' conclusion has a rather understated
post_author: if not surprising
post_date: solution for curbing the substantial costs to American business associated with obesity: \"Employers should explore workplace interventions and health care expansions to reduce these costs.\" Indeed

ID: Corporate leaders have come to the realization that
post_author: in order to be healthy
post_date: employees need to embrace healthy lifestyle habits. Yet
post_date_gmt: many of us do not have the knowledge
post_content: time
post_title: or motivation to make the right choices. Thus
post_excerpt: forward-thinking companies are adding preventive health programs to their suite of employee benefits. As part of such a program

post_password: and other health professionals. This is especially important for anyone struggling with obesity or other chronic conditions that affect their work productivity.

post_author: like any successful investment we’ve made

comment_status: more committed workforce and significantly lower overall healthcare costs. For every dollar we invest in our workers’ health

ID: Diet. Consuming adequate amounts of fruits and vegetables as part of an overall healthy diet has proven to decrease the risk of developing obesity and other debilitating conditions. Individuals who already have a dangerously high body mass index can take immediate steps in their diet and dramatically improve their health. A company’s policies and corporate culture can foster healthy eating by providing healthy snacks and drinks in the break room
post_author: installing adequate kitchen supplies for employees to refrigerate and reheat home cooked lunches
post_date: and allowing sufficient time for lunch breaks so that staff are not forced to grab unhealthy fast food on the run.

ID: Exercise. Many Americans are physically inactive
post_author: which is a major contributor to the obesity epidemic. Exercise is a vital part of health living; the more you move
post_date: the better your health outcomes. According to the CDC
post_date_gmt: people who are physically active for approximately 7 hours per week have a 40% lower risk of dying at an early age than those who are active for less than 30 minutes per week. The American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) concurs
post_content: reporting that most causes of death are delayed by regular performance of physical activity.

post_author: I am a big proponent of exercise as a preventive health measure and strongly believe that every leader is accountable for promoting the health and wellness of their employees
post_date: \" says Ana Dutra CEO of the Executives’ Club of Chicago at a event sponsored by the National Coalition for Promoting Physical Activity. \"With healthcare costs spiraling out of control
post_date_gmt: wellness and prevention have become strategic business imperatives - in addition to creating a healthier
post_content: happier and more productive workforce
post_title: these initiatives directly impact the bottom line.\"

ID: The JOEM study is not new information. Other studies in recent years have documented the costs of employee absenteeism and reduced on-the-job productivity due to poor health. Preventing disease increases productivity
post_author: period. The CDC estimates that asthma
post_date: high blood pressure

ID: EHE physician Dr. Frederica Linick says it is understandable that \"multiple medical problems associated with obesity would affect all aspects of life

September is considered “National Prostate Cancer Awareness Month,” where numerous organizations and experts seek to raise awareness for prostate health, inform about the risk factors for prostate cancer, and encourage prostate screenings. This month is right before “National Breast Cancer Awareness Month” (October) where there is a similar push for awareness and prevention, but this time for the breasts. Both men and women can get both types of cancers, but prostate cancer is much more prevalent in men and breast cancer is much more prevalent in women, inevitably causing gendered associations. While October enjoys a flood of pink ribbons (the symbol used in support of breast cancer), you’d be hard-pressed to find a blue ribbon (the symbol used in support of prostate cancer) in September—which underpins a major issue: Men’s health, in general, needs a major push so that men of all ages can be made aware of their increased risk for disease and death.

A Proclivity for Lifestyle Diseases

According to Healthfinder.org
post_excerpt: men are more likely to:

ID: • Put off regular checkups and medical care”
These behaviors are all common risk factors for lifestyle diseases—those that are associated and brought upon by how an individual lives. These diseases
post_author: according to Medicinenet.com
post_date: include “atherosclerosis
post_content: and stroke; obesity and type 2 diabetes; and diseases associated with smoking and alcohol and drug abuse.”

post_author: lifestyle disease is becoming more of a problem in the U.S. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention:

ID: <em>“The five leading causes of death in the United States are heart disease
post_author: cancer
post_date: chronic lower respiratory diseases
post_content: and unintentional injuries. Together they accounted for 63 percent of all U.S. deaths in 2010
post_title: with rates for each cause varying greatly from state to state.”

post_author: the Kaiser Family Foundation finds that life expectancy of a man is several years fewer than that of a woman
post_date: which speaks nothing of the quality of life that a man who smokes
post_content: and makes unhealthy choices leads.

ID: From this we can gather that men are a prime audience for preventive healthcare and education. Unfortunately
post_author: the reason for this is because they are more susceptible to unhealthy behavior. As this month is Prostate Cancer Awareness Month—essentially a month designated for men’s health considering the gendered association—and seeing the extreme push that occurs for Breast Cancer Awareness (which is typically aimed at female health)
post_date: now is the time for men to consider their current and future states of health.

Wearing contact lenses is typically a convenient and safe form of vision correction, but sometimes convenience breeds complacency. Keeping your contacts clean and maintained is of the utmost importance because these medical devices are placed directly on the eye, and unhygienic use will eventually cause certain eye infections and vision problems. And while this may appear obvious, it isn’t unheard of for contact lens wearers to forget to wear, wash or store their lenses properly, or even discard them after prolonged use. Actually that last point—about it not being unheard of for contact lens wearers to exhibit unhygienic behavior—is an understatement. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention:  “An estimated one in six adults in the United States wears contact lenses, and one third of them report at least one health care visit for a red or painful eye while wearing lenses. Approximately 99% of contact lens wearers reported at least one risk behavior ever for eye infections or inflammation. Of particular concern, contact lens wearers of all types frequently reported exposure of their contact lenses to water, including storing or rinsing their lenses in tap water and showering or swimming while wearing lenses.” This is very revealing. It means that contact lens wearers are among the most at-risk for eye infections. And it's not only because they neglect to care for their contacts. A recent study by NYU Langone reports that the bacteria present in the eyes of contact wearers is different from that of non-wearers:

post_author: the NYU Langone team found that the eye surface
post_date: or conjunctiva
post_date_gmt: has surprisingly higher bacterial diversity than the skin directly beneath the eye and three times the usual proportion of Methylobacterium
post_content: Lactobacillus
post_excerpt: and Pseudomonas bacteria in the eyes of the study’s nine contact lens wearers than is typically found on the surface of the eyeballs of 11 other men and women in the study who did not wear contact lenses. When measured and plotted on a graph
post_status: statistical germ diversity scores showed that the eye microbiome of contact lens wearers had a composition more similar to that of the wearer’s skin than the eye microbiome of non-lens wearers.”

ID: It is almost ironic that the devices used to improve one’s vision so that he/she may have a greater quality of life may
post_author: in the end
post_date: cause that person to have diminished or lost vision. In the end
post_date_gmt: contact lens wearers should be more prudent with their vision.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

Over the past decade, the word “core” has become a very popular buzzword within the fitness community. There are many fitness product commercials and websites that equate the strengthening of one’s core to improved athletic performance. However, like many health-related topics, the true importance of the core is hidden underneath a commonly held misconception: that strengthening the core leads to improved performance. In actuality, the main benefit of a strong core is injury prevention.

What are the Core Muscles?

The muscles and tendons that make up an individual’s core include the rectus abdominis, transversus abdominis, internal and external obliques, erector spinae, multifidus, the pelvic floor, and the diaphragm; essentially, the core includes everything except for the limbs and appendages. The muscles of the core work to support, stiffen, and stabilize the spine, abdomen, and pelvis; distributing and generating force without placing undo stress on the joints.

Core Stability, Athletic Performance, and Injury Prevention

A core-strengthening program increases core stability, which is the capacity of the body to return to equilibrium (or balance) after being in a state of non-equilibrium. Activities that attempt to throw off the body’s equilibrium can generally be called “functional movements.” Participating in sports, riding the subway, and even getting up from a chair are functional movements as the body is constantly re-aligning its center of gravity to effectively handle force distribution. Functional training
post_excerpt: has become popular among athletes and fitness enthusiasts alike. The thinking is that if you train your body to effectively transfer force with movements that mimic those that would occur in a real-life scenario (like throwing a medicine ball to mimic passing a basketball)
post_status: your body will adapt to these movements and be able to execute them better. This is the basis for the argument that core strength equals improved performance
comment_status: and it is easy to make this argument when individuals are incorporating a total body workout in addition to core strengthening.

post_author: _Functional.36.aspx\">Study after study has concluded
post_date: however
post_date_gmt: that functional training and core strengthening alone do not increase performance. You might be wondering then
post_content: “if this stuff doesn’t make me jump higher or run faster then what’s the point?” The point is preventive healthcare. While most studies attempting to link core strength and athletic performance have been met with underwhelming results
post_title: there is a wealth of literature espousing the link between core strength and injury prevention.

post_author: ” remarks that individuals with lower back pain (LBP) have “delayed contraction of the transversus abdominis and multifidi prior to limb movement.” Additionally
post_date: the document notes that “people with sacroiliac pain have impaired recruitment of the diaphragm and pelvic floor.” This shows that individuals with weak cores are susceptible to these and other musculoskeletal injuries.

ID: Another study showed that in the dangerous world of firefighting
post_author: an occupation that requires extensive functional movements in less than ideal situations
post_date: injuries were reduced significantly when the firefighters were placed under a core strengthening program:

ID: <em>“Comparing the number of injuries pre- and post- intervention of these 433 firefighters
post_author: loss time injuries were reduced by 62%
post_date: whereas total injuries were reduced by 44% compared to a historical group.”

post_author: according to article
post_date: “injuries are the leading cause of mortality and loss of potential years of life for working individuals.”

post_author: you won’t become a better athlete because the core efficiently distributes force rather than generating it. What you will accomplish
post_date: however
post_date_gmt: is even more important. You will improve your body’s ability to maintain equilibrium
post_content: protect against injury and various health conditions related to the muscles and joints
post_title: and increase your functional independence.  So
post_excerpt: while it may not improve your performance on the basketball court
post_status: functional training can increase the strength of the muscles that provide stability and mobility for the spine

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider. Individuals with specific complaints should seek immediate consultation from their personal physicians.

post_content: open

In an era of obesity, heart disease, stroke, diabetes, cancer, arthritis, and other chronic diseases, creating a culture of health may seem impossible. However, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), these common chronic diseases are some of the most costly and preventable of all health issues in the United States today. Creating a culture of health that encourages and rewards healthy behaviors at work can help to lower or eliminate risk factors for these diseases. Organizations that institute policies and programs that encourage healthy behaviors can lower their indirect costs (e.g., absenteeism and poor productivity) and direct costs (e.g., health premiums, disability, and workers compensation claims). According to the CDC, indirect costs of poor health may be more damaging to a business than the direct costs. The CDC estimates that “productivity losses related to personal and family health issues cost employers $1,685 per employee per year, or $225.8 billion annually.” It is important for organizations to keep in mind that employees come in all shapes, sizes, and fitness levels. Although each situation is unique and will call for specially tailored programs, some examples of workplace health initiatives that can foster a culture of health include:
  • Offering health education classes, including classes on nutrition, fitness and stress reduction
  • Offering tobacco cessation programs
  • Instituting policies that promote healthy behaviors such as a tobacco-free workplace policy
  • Negotiating a discount to a local fitness facility
  • Offering employee incentives for receiving appropriate preventive screenings
  • Offering employee outcome-based incentives for blood pressure, weight management and BMI
  • Making healthy food choices available and accessible through vending machines and/ or cafeterias
  • Posting nutritional information in workplace cafeterias
  • Offering opportunities for physical activity, such as an accessible walking trail or onsite fitness center
  • Encouraging employees who sit behind a desk for most of the day to take stretch breaks to improve their circulation and work efficiency
Of course, it is important to realize that one size does not fit all, and organizations will need to determine which strategies to incorporate based on their employees needs and interests, and what is affordable and feasible for the organization. Additionally organizations must recognize that creating a culture of health cannot and will not happen overnight. A well-designed program will address the physical, mental, emotional, social and spiritual health of employees. It will be a challenging, long-term process that will require persistent and persuasive leadership at all levels of an organization and constant communication. However, based on numerous studies, employers can expect that instituting high-quality, comprehensive, employee-focused workplace health programs may lead to positive changes for both the employer and the employee.
MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.
post_excerpt: Creating a culture of health that encourages and rewards healthy behaviors at work can help to lower or eliminate risk factors for these diseases.

A single health topic may often be positioned very differently across various news outlets, even to the extent that the outlets directly contradict each other though each seems to cite credible sources. For example, there are numerous conflicting claims regarding the cause of obesity.

Some reports indicate that obesity is largely a product of diet and environment (and is therefore modifiable), while others indicate that obesity is largely a product of genetics and cannot be changed.

According to an article titled, <a href=\http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/obesity-prevention-source/obesity-causes/genes-and-obesity/\">“Genes Are Not Destiny
post_title: ” that appears on the Harvard School of Public Health’s Obesity Prevention Source website
post_excerpt: current research into the causes of obesity indicate that an individual’s genes do not determine if he or she is destined to become obese. Evidence from this study also shows that individuals who have a healthy lifestyle and are immersed in a healthy environment can significantly decrease their chances of becoming obese.

post_author: a study by UCLA researchers that was published in Cell Metabolism found that the amount of food consumed by subjects (mice) in the study had a minor effect on their likelihood of becoming obese. Researchers claim that the amount of weight gained by an individual is influenced by his or her genetic makeup much more than diet
post_date: even among individuals who consume a high-calorie diet with large amounts of added sugar.

post_author: both studies are published by seemingly credible sources and likely contain sound
post_date: evidence-based information. So
post_date_gmt: neither article may necessarily be ‘wrong.’ However
post_content: one may contain information that is more applicable to an individual’s life than the other. A cursory look at the articles reveals an important difference: the study(s) referenced in the “Genes Are Not Destiny” article involved humans
post_title: while the study referenced in the Cell Metabolism article involved mice. By identifying this key difference between the articles
post_excerpt: an individual is able to put the information in a clearer perspective.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_author: Deciphering Seeming Contradictions in Health Media
post_date: A single health topic may often be positioned very differently across various news outlets.
post_content: open

American travelers abroad frequently get sick from eating foods or drinking water because we often have no immunity to local pathogens. If you don’t take certain health precautions, you may eventually pay the consequences. Stomach and digestive problems should not be the price of your visit nor a test of your mettle as a traveler. A night or two spent in a hotel bathroom is no fun, and stomach infections can lead to aggravated health issues, especially for children or individuals with compromised immune systems. “While you can be adventurous in your travels, try not to be so adventurous in your food choices while in third world countries,” says EHE International travel medicine nurse practitioner Marianne Dyke. “Nobody wants digestive distress while away from home.” Diarrhea affects 30% to 70% of travelers and is the most predictable travel-related illness. Your personal health status and travel destination greatly impacts the types of precautions you should take. The exposure potential is relative to the season and destination:

post_author: Canada
post_date: Australia
post_content: Japan

post_author: South Africa
post_date: Caribbean islands

post_author: Middle East
post_date: Africa
post_content: Central and South America

ID: Diarrhea is more than inconvenient. Bacteria and viruses may cause severe dehydration and lead to gastrointestinal problems. In extreme cases
post_author: infections become acute medical conditions requiring a hospital stay. A doctor may recommend a prophylactic vaccine (such as against Typhoid) if exposure is unavoidable.
but many of us don’t know what preventive health measures to take and rely on word-of-mouth or unscientific remedies. Follow a few simple steps in your daily routine:

ID: • Do not eat from street vendors in third world countries
• Eat well cooked foods or steamed vegetables in restaurants regardless of your location

The best advice for avoiding diarrhea is to talk with a travel medicine doctor. A doctor trained in preventive health for travelers will help plan your itinerary and provide care specific to your needs. With proper information and smart choices
post_author: you will not have to worry about diarrhea—and enjoy your travels.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider. Individuals with specific complaints should seek immediate consultation from their personal physicians.

According to the Institute of Medicine’s (IOMs) <a href=\https://fnic.nal.usda.gov/dietary-guidance/dri-nutrient-reports/energy-carbohydrate-fiber-fat-fatty-acids-cholesterol-protein\"><i>Dietary Reference Intakes for Energy
post_excerpt: Fiber
to_ping: dietary fat is a macronutrient that provides a major source of energy for the body--approximately 9 units of energy (or calories) per gram.

ID: <span id=\"hs_cos_wrapper_post_body\" class=\"hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text\" data-hs-cos-general-type=\"meta_field\" data-hs-cos-type=\"rich_text\">While there are three main types of fats--saturated fats
post_author: unsaturated fats
post_date: and trans fats--according to Harvard Medical School all fats have a similar chemical structure. Fats are comprised of “a chain of carbon atoms bonded by hydrogen atoms.”

ID: <span id=\"hs_cos_wrapper_post_body\" class=\"hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text\" data-hs-cos-general-type=\"meta_field\" data-hs-cos-type=\"rich_text\">What differentiates one type of fat from another is “the length and shape of the carbon chain and the number of hydrogen atoms connected to the carbon atoms. Seemingly slight differences in structure translate into crucial differences in form and function.”
There are three main types of dietary fat: unsaturated
post_author: saturated
post_date: and trans.

ID: Unsaturated Fats: Often referred to as the “good” fats
post_author: unsaturated fats are either monounsaturated or polyunsaturated. According to the Harvard Medical School
post_date: unsaturated fats are usually liquid at room temperature and are found mainly in plant–based sources. Polyunsaturated fats are referred to as essential fats because the body requires them for good health but cannot synthesize them on its own
post_date_gmt: so they must be obtained from food.

ID: Unsaturated fats can be found in olive
post_author: peanut
post_date: sunflower
post_content: soybean
post_title: and flaxseed oils; avocados; nuts; seeds; and fish. Unsaturated fats are considered to be beneficial because they may help improve and maintain blood cholesterol levels
post_excerpt: reduce blood pressure

ID: Saturated Fats: According to the American Heart Association (AHA)
post_author: “From a chemical standpoint
post_date: saturated fats are simply fat molecules that have no double bonds between carbon molecules because they are saturated with hydrogen molecules.”

ID: These fats can be found in red meat
post_author: butter
post_date: whole milk
post_date_gmt: dairy products made with whole or 2 percent milk
post_content: cheeses
post_excerpt: and many commercially prepared baked goods and fried foods.

post_author: recent research has called the association between saturated fats and cardiovascular disease into question. A systematic review and meta-analysis examining the association between dietary fatty acids and coronary heart disease (CHD) published in the March 18
post_date: 2014 Annals of Internal Medicine
post_content: “Current evidence does not clearly support cardiovascular guidelines that encourage high consumption of polyunsaturated fatty acids and low consumption of total saturated fats.” A meta-analysis of 21 studies that appeared in the March 2010 issue of The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition found that there was not enough evidence to conclude that saturated fat increases the risk of CHD or cardiovascular disease (CVD).

post_author: the AHA recommends limiting saturated fats to less than 7 percent of one’s total daily calories because “Decades of sound science has proven it can raise your “bad” cholesterol and put you at higher risk for heart disease.”

ID: Trans Fats: There are two types of trans fats in the diet: those formed naturally and those created during food processing.
Those formed naturally are produced in the gut of some grazing animals. According to the AHA
post_author: trans fats that are created during processing (also called “partially hydrogenated oils”) “are created in an industrial process that adds hydrogen to liquid vegetable oils to make them more solid.”

ID: The primary source of trans fats in the American diet are foods containing industrially–modified and partially–hydrogenated vegetable oils such as fried foods
post_author: pizza dough
post_date: pie crust
post_content: chips
post_title: and commercially baked goods such as pastries
post_excerpt: cookies

ID: Artificial trans fats are harmful because they raise bad (LDL) cholesterol levels and lower good (HDL) cholesterol levels
post_author: which are risk factors for heart disease. The AHA recommends limiting artificial trans fats to less than one percent of total daily calories.

ID: Although the excessive consumption of some fats can cause serious health issues
post_author: individuals should not cut out fats altogether because fats are essential to health. In addition to providing the body with energy
post_date: fats serve many other important functions; according to Harvard Medical School

ID: <li>The absorption of the fat-soluble vitamins A
post_author: D
post_date: E and K as well as carotenoids

ID: It is important to keep in mind that all fats are very high in calories and therefore must be eaten in moderation as part of an overall well–balanced diet. Unfortunately
post_author: according to the <a href=\"https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/\"><i>Dietary Guidelines for Americans
post_date_gmt: the diets of most Americans contain far more fat than the body needs. The consistent consumption of excessive fat
post_content: particularly excessive amounts of the wrong types of fat
post_title: can lead to serious health complications. It is important for you to be aware of the fat content of the foods you consume and try to replace most saturated and trans fats with healthier unsaturated fats because these types of fats will help promote your health and well-being."
post_excerpt: What is Dietary Fat?

post_content:
In the “Maintaining Health” series it was established that what you put inside your body determines, more than any other component, the trajectory of your health. This series, titled “Digestive Health,” will help you discover how food and drink is broken down; why the kinds of food that you ingest affect your digestion and consequently your health; and what you can do to keep your digestive system in optimal working condition.

Digestive Health: An Introduction to Digestion

Digestion is like breathing: it’s an important, automatic bodily process that isn’t given a second thought unless something goes wrong; but unlike breathing, digestion is complex and requires consistent maintenance. This article will inform readers what the digestive system is and how it works so they can begin to have a deeper understanding of its significance.

What is the Digestive System?

According to the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDKD)
post_title: “The digestive system is made up of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract—also called the digestive tract—and the liver
post_excerpt: pancreas
post_status: and gallbladder.” It is made up of hollow organs and solid organs. The hollow organs are the mouth
post_password: and the small and large intestines. The solid organs include the liver
to_ping: and gallbladder. Together the components of the digestive system utilize muscle movements
post_parent: and distribute the nutrition present in foods and drink.

ID: Digestion first begins in the mouth
post_author: a hollow organ that leads to the esophagus. The mouth uses mastication (chewing) in order to break down foods into smaller bits. While chewing is taking place
post_date: saliva is secreted by the salivary glands in the mouth to break down complex carbohydrates as well as to moisten the food bits so that they may be swallowed.

ID: Swallowing is performed by the esophagus
post_author: a hollow organ which leads to the stomach. Food that is swallowed is involuntarily pushed by the muscles in the esophagus towards the lower esophageal sphincter (the muscle that controls what goes into the stomach) in a process called esophageal peristalsis.

ID: Food passes through the esophageal sphincter and enters the stomach
post_author: a hollow organ that leads to the duodenum of the small intestine. Here
post_date: food is mixed with hydrochloric acid (to further break down food bits) and proteases (an enzyme secreted by the pancreas that turns proteins into amino acids). The stomach is lined with muscles that churn this mixture (via peristalsis) into chime--a mass of partly digested food.

ID: Chyme enters the duodenum of the small intestine to be further broken down. Digestive juices from the small intestine and pancreas combined with bile from the liver allow the food to be absorbed into the blood where it can be distributed throughout the body. Chyme that wasn’t fully digested for whatever reason is sent to the large intestine.
The large intestine receives waste products and anything else that wasn’t fully digested in the small intestine. It absorbs any remaining water and nutrients before turning the waste into stool
post_author: where it is stored in the rectum (as part of the large intestine) to be discharged via defecation.

ID: The digestive process utilizes many components of the body in order to turn food and drink into nourishment. Though as with any process with moving parts
post_author: it is subject to malfunction if routine maintenance isn’t upheld. In the next entry in the “Digestive Health” series
post_date: we will take a closer look at the components of digestion in order to keep your digestive system running at peak performance.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_author: Digestive Health

In the “Digestive Health” series, we will take a closer look at the components of digestion in order to keep your digestive system running at peak performance.
post_content: open
When it comes to peace of mind, your gut is largely influential. In fact, a 2008 paper titled, “Brain foods: the effects of nutrients on brain function
post_title: ” goes into detail on how the nutrients of food impact the enzymes of the gut
post_excerpt: which consequently interact with neurons in the brain. But even though food has a real affect on mood (and brain function for that matter)
post_status: many Americans suffer from digestive disorders. The National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) remarks that “60 to 70 million people are affected by all digestive diseases’—almost a quarter of the population.

ID: Digestive disorders impact the processing of nutrients and bring on discomfort. Some of the most common are chronic constipation
post_author: acid reflux
post_date: gallstones and irritable bowel syndrome. This article will examine these disorders and setup one’s diet as the main determinant to good (or bad) digestive health.

ID: One of the worst feelings is being backed up
post_author: and unfortunately many Americans face this scenario on a daily basis. According to the NIDDK constipation “is the most common gastrointestinal complaint in the United States” accounting for 2 million annual doctor visits and $725 million spent annually on laxatives.

ID: Constipation is described as infrequent (less than three times a week) bowel movements which are hard and dry in appearance and texture. For comparison
post_author: many individuals move their bowels one to three times a day.

ID: Constipation occurs when the large intestines
post_author: responsible for absorbing fluid and nutrients of food before it moves to the rectum
post_date: absorbs too much fluid leaving a hardened stool. These stools are difficult to pass and result in infrequent bowel movements.

ID: While typically seen as more of an annoyance than anything
post_author: constipation (when chronic) can lead to problems that can become severe. Hemorrhoids (swollen or inflamed veins in the anal canal)
post_date: anal fissures (a skin break or tear in the anal canal)
post_date_gmt: and fecal impaction (hard stool packed in the intestine and rectum over time) are complications that can result from constipation.

ID: The causes of constipation are varied
post_author: but the most common are: not enough fiber in the diet
post_date: not enough liquids in the diet
post_content: lack of exercise
post_excerpt: and ironically the overuse of laxatives.

ID: For those who’ve ever had heartburn
post_author: the thought of getting it again is enough to throw off one’s appetite. Heartburn is caused by acid reflux
post_date: a situation where the lower esophageal sphincter (the circular group of muscles that control what goes into the stomach from the esophagus) either doesn’t close all the way after allowing food to pass or opens to frequently. This allows stomach acid to enter the esophagus and creates a burning sensation.

post_author: typically twice or more a week should see a doctor as they may have gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). According to NIDDK
post_date: some common symptoms of GERD is: “bad breath
post_content: pain in your chest or the upper part of your abdomen
post_excerpt: respiratory problems
comment_status: the wearing away of your teeth”.

post_author: GERD can cause complications such as esophagitis (damaged tissue lining the esophagus leading to bleeding and ulcers)
post_date: difficulty swallowing
post_content: and Barret’s esophagus (a condition where esophagus tissue is replaced by tissue resembling that found in the intestine). Unchecked cases of esophagitis and Barret’s esophagus can lead to cancer.

post_author: medications
post_date: or surgery if necessary. Lifestyle changes involve abstaining from smoking
post_content: and eating greasy
post_title: spicy foods. Medications typically involve ingesting an antacid. Surgery is usually an extreme case and typically involves the individual suffering from some physical abnormality that allows GERD to persist.

ID: Like kidney stones
post_author: gallstones are hardened material that can become trapped in troublesome places. The gall bladder contains the secreted bile from the liver before it is used in the small intestines. The bile gets to the small intestine via the biliary tract. If a gallstone (or stones) gets trapped in the biliary tract it can sudden and shooting pain in the abdomen
post_date: known as a gallbladder attack.

ID: Gallstones can be really small or quite large (about the size of a golf ball). Also
post_author: there can be many gallstones present in the gallbladder at one time
post_date: each of which can vary in size. According to womenshealth.gov these stones are formed when there is an excess of cholesterol in the liquid bile or if the gallbladder doesn’t empty entirely or not enough.

ID: Risk factors for gallstones include: having a family history of gallstones
post_author: being overweight or obese
post_date: consuming a energy-rich
post_content: losing a lot of weight very quickly
post_excerpt: have diabetes
post_status: or are American Indian or Mexican American.

ID: If a gallstone gets trapped in one of the bile ducts it can eventually cause severe damage to the biliary tract
post_author: the gallbladder
post_date: and the liver. Gallstones can even become fatal in this manner. Fortunately
post_date_gmt: individuals can reduce their risk for gallstones by eating a low-cholesterol diet
post_content: maintaining a healthy weight

ID: IBS is a common yet mysterious disease: it affects approximately 10 to 15 percent of the US population yet doesn’t have a known cause
post_author: and diagnosis is based on a pattern of common digestion issues such as abdominal pain
post_date: bloating
post_date_gmt: and constipation—meaning it can easily be mistaken for something else.

post_author: this disease is classified into four types: 1) IBS with constipation (IBS-C)
post_date: IBS with diarrhea (IBS-D)
post_content: and Unsubtyped IBS (IBS-U). These distinctions are determined by stool sample and will affect the type of treatment advice from doctors.

ID: Symptoms of IBS are typically abdominal pain and a change in bowel movement frequency. While these symptoms are minor
post_author: their triggers are many
post_date: such as: motility problems in the colon
post_content: and feelings of stress stemming from depression
post_excerpt: and panic disorder can all trigger IBS symptoms.

ID: Treatment of IBS typically involves changes to one’s diet and going after the physical symptoms the person experiences—such as taking fiber supplements for constipation
post_author: antidepressants for stress
post_date: and antispasmodics to control motility.

ID: Digestive disorders are common and share similarities in both symptoms and treatment. If you are having trouble going or are experiencing inexplicable abdominal pain then you should schedule a visit with your doctor if these conditions persist. Usually they will recommend a change in diet.

post_author: prevention is always better than treatment
post_date: so in the next entry in the “Digestive Health” series we will look at how diet affects the digestion system

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

If you are having trouble going or are experiencing inexplicable abdominal pain then you should schedule a visit with your doctor if these conditions persist. Usually they will recommend a change in diet.

According to the Health Services department at Cornell University (Gannet), “The most immediate benefit of dietary fiber is its improvement of digestive function.” This article will examine fiber’s role in digestion with particular emphasis on how it affects the colon.

What is Dietary Fiber?

According to Gannet
post_title: “Dietary fiber is the edible component of plant foods that can’t be digested by humans.” While it doesn’t provide any nutritional value
post_excerpt: dietary fiber aids digestion by improving the absorption of nutrients
comment_status: and the colon’s motility (moving indigestible material to the rectum).

ID: There are two types of dietary fiber: soluble (able to be dissolved in water) and insoluble fiber.

post_author: soluble fiber dissolves into a gel substance when it reaches the colon. This process occurs through colonic fermentation—whereby bacteria in the colon interact with ingested material in order to produce gases and short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs)
post_date: which have numerous health benefits including controlling blood glucose (sugar) levels and improving intestinal immune function.

ID: Insoluble fiber doesn’t dissolve in water
post_author: but rather attracts and absorbs it. This serves to add bulk to your diet as it makes you feel full
post_date: improve the consistency of stool through hydration
post_date_gmt: and increases bowel movements by engaging colonic motility.

ID: Soluble fiber is found in “oat bran
post_author: barley
post_date: nuts
post_content: beans
post_excerpt: peas
comment_status: ” whereas insoluble is found in “wheat bran

ID: Adding fiber to your diet is one of the best ways to improve your digestive health
post_author: especially if you suffer from constipation or irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

ID: Constipation is a result of infrequent bowel movements (typically less than 3 times a week) which tend to produce hard and dry stool. Insoluble fiber addresses these issues as it absorbs water in the colon during digestion and both softens and moistens stool. In addition
post_author: the consistency of this stool is able to be easily moved to the rectum by the colon
post_date: increasing bowel movement.

ID: IBS typically includes abdominal pain and irregular bowel movements. While treatment outside of diet (e.g.
post_author: being prescribed probiotics and going to stress management) aid in treating this complex disease
post_date: adding fiber is still one of the quickest and most effective solutions to controlling symptoms. As mentioned previously
post_date_gmt: fiber increases regularity constipation and improves consistency which relieves constipation and diarrhea respectively. As there is no single treatment for IBS—and particularly the pain associated with it—prevention is the best form of medicine. Sticking to a healthy diet with plenty of fiber
post_content: along with performing exercise and other healthy behaviors
post_title: is the best way to combat this disease.

ID: While fiber is important for digestive health
post_author: too much of it can cause symptoms that typically result from poor digestive health; e.g.
post_date: gas
post_content: and abdominal pain. According to Medline Plus
post_title: “The average American now eats 10 to 15 grams of fiber per day. The recommendation for older children
post_excerpt: adolescents
post_status: and adults is to eat 20 to 35 grams of fiber each day.”

ID: As the average American doesn’t get enough fiber in their diet it is likely beneficial that the inclusion of additional fiber will aid in digestive health. Both types of fiber (soluble and insoluble) are necessary for the proper maintenance of the colon and to prevent issues that stem from poor colonic health (e.g.
post_author: constipation
post_date: diarrhea
post_content: nuts and seeds
post_title: and fruits and vegetables are excellent sources of fiber and should always be added to your diet.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_author: Digestive Health: Fiber
post_date: Whole grains, nuts and seeds, and fruits and vegetables are excellent sources of fiber and should always be added to your diet.
post_content: open

As the saying goes, “knowledge is power.” When it comes to personal health, however, many prefer another adage: “ignorance is bliss.” Visiting the doctor for a medical exam and learning one’s overall health status may stir up thoughts of mortality and guilt for not taking better care of our bodies, especially as we age. This avoidance mindset will not help us make pro-active decisions about our health. “Avoiding medical tests because of anxiety can cause more health problems, such as fatigue, muscle tension, restlessness, and difficulty sleeping, according to the Anxiety and Depression Association of America
post_title: ” writes John Fortunbury in The Atlantic. “Even if the worry is only an occasional one
post_excerpt: [anxiety] weakens the immune system.”

ID: You can turn around fear of seeking and understanding health information by embracing medical screenings and preventive exams as tools to build a plan to get and/or stay healthy. When a doctor conducts a thorough exam and provides the results
post_author: you are in command. If you take control over medical information
post_date: instead of the other way around
post_date_gmt: you will not only alleviate anxiety but change your health outcomes.

ID: EHE Physician Dr. Gabriella Trotta-Barni says
post_author: “knowledge of certain information
post_date: such as cholesterol levels or blood pressure can be empowering; with a change in lifestyle habits
post_content: one can decrease cardiovascular risk

post_author: approach medical screenings like taking a test. We all take tests in school to measure where we are and what we’ve learned thus far. A medical screening is no different. There’s no failing grade
post_date: and it’s not a prescription for your destiny. Preventive medical screenings are conducted to establish a physical health baseline in order to know what to address and where to make improvements.

ID: \"When we avoid preventive tests we take away our greatest weapon in fighting chronic disease
post_author: ” says psychologist Mike Friedman of EHE’s Medical Advisory Board. “We must remember that most diseases are chronic but controllable if we detect them and implement strong health behaviors.\"

ID: Even if medical screenings find a problem
post_author: catching it in the early stages may prevent an ailment from becoming a chronic disease and/or make it more manageable. Don’t leave your medical condition unresolved. Far from being scary
post_date: a proper medical screening is your greatest protection from harm and the best resource for improving your overall health.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider. Individuals with specific complaints should seek immediate consultation from their personal physicians.

post_author: Don’t Fear Medical Screenings
post_date: Visiting the doctor for medical screenings is the best way to improve your health
post_content: open

The holidays are a time to enjoy ourselves and to take a mental health break. If we completely lose sight of our health goals, however, holiday rejoicing can quickly turn into regret after the New Year. Now, this doesn’t mean we have to resign ourselves to eating only Kale chips at the holiday parties – we just need to be mindful of eating and exercise. EHE International fitness experts recommend balancing the extra intake of calories during the season with increased physical activity. Exercising is a simple, effective way to offset the added sweets, fats, and alcohol. Luckily, many of us have more free time during the holidays to run outside, visit the gym, and pound the pavement while shopping and prepping for parties. “Realistically, this is not the ideal time to make lofty weight loss goals,” says EHE’s Shereé Chambers. “You cannot pack in exercise to lose the weight you promised last year. But you can burn away what you consume now.”

Holiday Fitness 101

Our bodies need calories from food for energy, but extra calories are stored as fat. The typical holiday dinner plate can triple the body’s daily calorie intake. Since most of us have several high-calorie
post_title: low-nutrient meals over the two-week holiday period
post_excerpt: we generally far exceed the body’s ability to meet energy needs. This acute uptick in empty calories does more than increase waistlines. As fat accumulates
post_status: it interferes with the proper functioning of the heart
ping_status: liver and digestive tract. Research shows holiday season weight gain adds to net fat accumulation and increases long-term health consequences.

ID: Nature has designed our bodies to gain weight easier than lose it. Adipocytes (fat cells) prefer being fat. Increasing the number and size of these cells makes gaining even more weight easier and requires greater effort to “shrink” fat cells. Adipocytes don’t disappear once created
post_author: unfortunately. We can only shrink fat cells
post_date: but they are eagerly waiting for another opportunity to be overfed and balloon again.

ID: • Minimized stress and maximized sleep strengthen willpower and improve overall healthy.
• Make healthful balanced meals and snacks at home to avoid overindulging at parties.
• Skipping meals to over-consume later can disrupt metabolism and increased fat storage.
• Make food-related decisions based on hunger rather than emotional anxiety or exhaustion.
<li>Make a list what is truly important to you about holiday parties (e.g.
post_author: reconnecting with friends
post_date: visiting family
post_date_gmt: etc.). Post the list at home and work for reminders of good times outside of food and drink.

ID: <li>Create detailed steps for each holiday meal. For example
post_author: fill up on veggies first
post_date: choose one small serving of a favorite food instead of grazing everything
post_date_gmt: and take dessert to-go to avoid the temptation of wanting a second of third helping.

ID: • Keep track of cocktail food and appetizers. Sampling finger foods from every tray can add up to a couple hundred calories.
• Control temptation. Bring in your own healthful treats to substitute sugary desserts.
<li>Limit high-calorie foods such as fried and creamy foods (including sauces
post_author: dressings
post_date: and cheese)
post_content: and alcohol.

ID: • Don’t over-consume just because the food is free
• Survey the entire food selection before plating your food.
• Always start “lean and green” by filling ½ your plate with fruit and vegetables.
• Don’t waste calories on “average” food. Eat what looks delicious.
• Take sample sizes to avoid eating a full portion of food simply because it’s on your plate.

post_author: don’t refill your plate. Choose a small portion of 1 or 2 of the foods you liked best.

ID: <li>Keep a visual of the portion plate in mind –

post_author: ¼ protein and ¼ carbohydrate.

ID: <li>Eat slowly. Setting down the fork and knife after each bite. Take time to chew
post_author: taste and enjoy your food. Take a drink between bites.

ID: • Prepare traditional holiday foods with a healthful twist.
• Give healthful snacks extra appeal with creative recipes and presentation.
• Prepare individual servings in ramekin dishes and portion out desserts in bite sizes.
<li>Caution: Tasting while cooking can add up in significant calories. Keep healthy snacking vegetables and fruit nearby to nibble (sliced celery
post_author: baby carrots
post_date: red pepper
post_content: cherries or good options
post_excerpt: citrus-fruit-infused seltzer water).

post_author: plastic bags and foil to share all tempting leftovers with departing guests.

ID: <li>Plan continuous activities. Party games take the emphasis off food
post_author: creating an environment focused on celebration and conversation.

ID: • Bring a healthy dish to share. In addition
post_author: bring at least 2 individual personal snacks as a backup.

ID: • Avoid temptations to overeat by engaging in conversation and fun activities.
<li>To avoid mindless consumption as a relief from boredom or anxiousness
post_author: invite a friend along.

ID: • Plan a timely departure before you become tired.
• Implement the one-a-day plan. Allow yourself one small holiday treat each day. You won’t feel deprived. And it will help keep you mindful and on track.
• Survey the offerings before choosing. Decide what you really want. And pair it with fresh fruit as a backup plan to distract from second helpings.
<li>If your sweet tooth generally gets the best of you
post_author: postpone dessert.

ID: • Use the 3-bite-rule on a rich dessert or split it with a friend.
• Decide in advance your drink limit and keep count.
• Start drinking later after the event begins.

post_author: bypass rounds
post_date: and alternate with non-alcoholic beverages.

ID: • Split your exercise routine when time does not allow for a full workout to maintain consistency. Planning 5
post_date: or 15 minutes of exercise in the morning helps keep your muscles engaged and your routine intact.

ID: <li>Opt for home workouts over the gym to save travel time. Play a DVD
post_author: dance to music
post_date: or use resistance bands.

post_author: squeeze in a quick workout at the gym or go for a walk.
schedule exercise as priority first thing in the morning before the day gets hectic. Any kind of movement will do
post_date: including shoveling snow.

ID: <li>Instead of meeting for drinks or a meal
post_author: go ice skating
post_date: snow-shoeing
post_content: or walk around and check out holiday window decorations.

ID: • Find more ways to be active from Fitness.gov.
• Don’t stretch yourself too thin. Prioritize the most important tasks and events.
<li>A gracious decline is better received that we imagine. Save yourself time
post_author: stress and calories with three easy words: \"No thank you
post_date: ” “I have plans
post_content: but I’m full!\"

ID: The holidays provide the temptation to over-consume and under-exercise. Physical activity helps reduces stress and compensate for eating too much. Balancing calories is the key. Attacking holiday foods with reckless abandon will have long-term consequences. Conversely
post_author: trying to be “good” is a set up for failure. Feeling guilty for breaking a diet may dissuade us from returning to a healthy living plan after the holiday parties are over.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider. Individuals with specific complaints should seek immediate consultation from their personal physicians.

post_author: Don't Take a Holiday from Your Health
post_date: The holidays are a time to enjoy ourselves and to take a break. But don't forget about fitness and healthy eating.
post_content: open

<span id=\hs_cos_wrapper_post_body\" class=\"hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text\" data-hs-cos-general-type=\"meta_field\" data-hs-cos-type=\"rich_text\">While e–cigarettes do not contain most of the thousands of chemicals—many of them cancer-causing—found in traditional cigarettes
post_excerpt: the substance responsible for causing addiction to tobacco products
post_status: as well as other chemicals including flavorings.

ID: Those championing their benefits tend to focus on the effects e–cigarettes have on current smokers as compared to the effects of smoking traditional tobacco products. Public Health England seems to be leading the way for proponents of e–cigarettes and has stated that: “An expert review of the latest evidence concludes that e–cigarettes are around 95% safer than smoked tobacco and they can help smokers to quit.” Public Health England commissioned an independent review of the latest evidence and published its findings in
post_author: “E–cigarettes: an evidence update.” This report appears to provide a fairly comprehensive summary of the arguments most proponents put forth advocating the benefits of e–cigarettes.

ID: <li>That while e–cigarettes may not be completely safe
post_author: they contain far fewer harmful chemicals that cause smoking–related diseases in individuals who smoke traditional cigarettes
post_date: and the chemicals that are present pose only limited danger.

ID: • That e–cigarettes can be used to help individuals who smoke traditional cigarettes quit smoking and reduce their cigarette consumption and may even encourage individuals with no interest in quitting or reducing their cigarette consumption to do so.

• That the accuracy of nicotine content labeling currently raises no major concerns. Packaging that was found to be poorly labeled—for the most part—contained less nicotine than stated on the packaging.
<li>That despite recent studies that indicate the contrary
post_author: there is no indication that individuals who use e–cigarettes are exposed to dangerous levels of aldehydes.

ID: <li>That there is no evidence that e–cigarettes are undermining the long–term decline in cigarette smoking among adults and youth
post_author: and may in fact be contributing to it. Additionally despite e–cigarette experimentation by individuals who have never smoked
post_date: e–cigarettes rarely turn individuals who have never smoked into regular e–cigarette users.

Medics on the frontlines of the outbreak are those at highest risk. A lead physician has died
post_author: and the disease has spread to healthcare workers. One American doctor and a Peace Corps volunteer afflicted with the disease were recently airlifted to the United States for treatment.

ID: The Ebola virus is one of several viruses causing a hemorrhagic fever. Ebola is transmitted to humans by infected primates; bats are suspected as the reservoir host. The disease spreads amongst humans through contact with bodily fluids
post_author: such as blood
post_date: vomit
post_content: feces

post_author: muscle aches
post_date: sore throat
post_content: vomiting and diarrhea. Bleeding manifestations of the disease include conjunctival hemorrhage
post_excerpt: and bleeding from blood-draw sites. The fatality rate is approximately 60%. No effective medicines or vaccines to prevent the illness exist
post_status: and therefore treatment is only supportive. The incubation period varies from a few days to a few weeks
comment_status: during which time an individual is not infectious.

prior to international travel

There is no one ideal body size, shape or weight that every individual should strive to attain. The human body exists in all shapes and sizes. By learning to accept and appreciate the body that you have, you can develop and maintain a healthy and positive body image. Here are some tips for encouraging one to have a positive self-image of their body:
  • Focus on the many positive qualities, skills, and talents that you possess instead of focusing primarily on physical appearance. Appreciate and respect the entire you.
  • Recognize that there are certain aspects of your appearance that you can change and some that you cannot. Things such as height, shoe size, and bone structure cannot be changed and spending valuable time trying to change these features will prove fruitless and frustrating.
  • Prioritize good health rather than the attainment of a certain body weight, size, or shape. Decide to become physically active by performing activities that you enjoy, and decide to eat more nutritiously (but do so gradually as fad diets and sudden and severe diet restrictions are almost certain to backfire). Choose to live a healthier life and make changes gradually so that they can become life-long habits. As you begin to feel healthier and more energetic, your body image will also become more positive.
  • Avoid using food as a reward or punishment. Do not make certain foods forbidden, instead encourage and promote moderation.
  • Choose to be around positive, supportive people. Friends and family that support, value and accept you as you currently are can help to boost body image.
  • Replace negative self-talk with positive self-talk. Do not focus on perceived flaws. Instead, focus on thoughts that celebrate the amazing things that you do now and can/will do in the future.
  • Avoid alcohol, cigarettes and drugs. Self–medicating with these items may provide an easy escape from negative thoughts and feelings, but the relief will only be temporary. Issues and problems should not be avoided; they should be dealt with a clear mind.
  • For some individuals, the focus and constant worry about their weight or some other aspect of their body that they are dissatisfied with is more than they can deal with on their own. If you ever feel this way, it is important to seek professional help.

The Bottom Line—For Your Health!

Many people spend an inordinate amount of time trying to change the way they look. Instead of experiencing the here and now and enjoying their life today, they put their lives on hold until they achieve some impossible “ideal.” Rather than trying to meet the impossible standards that are perceived to be expected in today’s culture, try to accept yourself as you are today. There is certainly no harm in trying to improve yourself, but learning to accept and appreciate yourself as you are today is the first step to a healthy, positive body image.
MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.
post_excerpt: By learning to accept and appreciate the body that you have, you can develop and maintain a healthy and positive body image.

post_content:
Companies that elevate employee wellness programs from a simple perk to a broader corporate mission—for every employee—will have greater success.

Faced with the dual challenge of health care costs, companies interested in improving their bottom line are focusing on disease prevention, improved fitness, weight-loss programs, and smoking cessation. “The earlier people address these issues, the less likely they are to actually get sick,” says Dee Edington, founder of the University of Michigan’s Health Management Research Center and chairman of consulting firm Edington Associates LLC. “It’s the best way to cut health care costs.” A well-designed organizational and employee health program can also boost productivity, improve morale, and energize the workplace—putting companies, says Edington, at the next frontier in corporate strategy. Employee wellness programs actually predate health care reform, but their impact has been limited because of low participation. In a recent RAND Corporation study, 92% of companies with 200 or more employees offered employees a workplace wellness program, but less than 20% of employees chose to participate. Why not? Companies offer wellness as a perk, but then fail to make it part of a shared vision of corporate values, says Deborah McKeever, president and COO of EHE International, a 101-year-old company that has pioneered corporate physical exams and employee health and lifestyle management programs. “What’s important to the company becomes important to employees. It’s an expression of loyalty,” says McKeever. “Companies need to develop a unifying and credible vision that elevates health from simple perks to one of inclusion in the corporate mission statement”. While some perks such as physical exams and personal trainers have traditionally been reserved for top management, companies would be wise to design inclusive benefits that extend to all employees. It starts with a physical exam for early detection and identification of risk factors for diabetes, hypertension, and other preventive conditions, stress reduction workshops, and work-life balance initiatives. Companies need to make these initiatives a corporate priority, with executives embracing wellness both for themselves and all employees. The role of the organizational climate must also be examined for a healthy and high-performing workforce to grow. Current labor trends appear to be driving the push toward organizational health programs, as an improving economy makes it harder for companies to retain employees. The U.S. Department of Labor estimates that 2.5 million Americans voluntarily left their jobs in May, up from 2.2 million a year earlier. Of the 18% of workers who recently told employment website CareerBuilder that they’re dissatisfied with their work, 65% said they didn’t feel valued by their company. “Health is personal and no other employee benefit offering says ‘I care about you’ more than a robust wellness program,” says McKeever. A shared-values approach sends a clear message that a company values its employees and is committed to their success. It is a message, Edington says, that resonates deeply with today’s workers, who were raised in a culture that values meaning and purpose as much, if not more, than financial success. “We are really on the edge of a sea change,” he says, noting that the conversation is shifting away from health care and focusing on health instead. “Health is a win-win organizational value.” A version of this article was originally published in Fortune Magazine, December 2014.
MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider. Individuals with specific complaints should seek immediate consultation from their personal physicians.

Energy drinks are produced by companies and brands such as Monster, Red Bull, Rock Star, Wired, Venom, Amp, NOS and 5–Hour Energy. These products typically claim to decrease fatigue while improving mental alertness, concentration, metabolism and overall performance. Energy shots are simply smaller, concentrated versions of energy drinks. Both are easy to find in supermarkets, convenience stores, drug stores, sporting goods stores, gas stations and vending machines. The two most common ingredients in energy drink products are caffeine and sugar.
  • Caffeine: Caffeine is a central nervous system stimulant and diuretic (a substance that helps to rid the body of fluids) that is naturally found in the leaves, seeds or fruits of over 60 plant species worldwide. Caffeine is commonly found in foods and beverages derived from coffee beans, cocoa beans, kola nuts and tea leaves. It can also be produced synthetically and added to foods, beverages, supplements and medications. After ingestion, caffeine is absorbed and passes quickly to the brain. It usually reaches its peak level in the blood within one hour and stays there for four to six hours. Caffeine does not collect in the bloodstream, nor is it stored in the body. It leaves the body through urine many hours after it has been consumed.
  • Sugar: Sugar is a simple carbohydrate that supplies energy to the body. It is found in the food supply as either \naturally–occurring sugar\" or \"added sugar.\" Naturally–occurring sugar is found in fruits
post_excerpt: while added sugar is added to food products during processing. Added sugar contributes a large amount of calories to an individual’s diet while providing little to no nutritional benefit. Energy drink products contain added sugar.

ID: Other ingredients are commonly included in energy drinks:

• Guarana: Guarana is a South American plant. One seed of the guarana plant contains approximately twice as much caffeine as a coffee bean. Energy drink marketing language claims that guarana increases weight loss and improves energy and mental function though these claims are unsubstantiated.
• Taurine: Taurine is an amino acid produced naturally by the body
post_author: though the taurine that is added to energy drinks is synthetic. In its natural form
post_date: taurine is thought to help regulate salt and water in the blood and support neurological development. Marketing language claims that taurine improves metabolism and reduces fatigue during exercise though these claims are also unsubstantiated.

ID: • B–vitamins: B–vitamins are added to many energy drinks with claims that they boost energy and mental and physical performance. However
post_author: all that individuals need to do to ensure adequate consumption of B–vitamins is consume a healthy
post_date: nutrient–rich

ID: While the caffeine and sugar in energy drinks and energy shots may make you feel more alert temporarily
post_author: they can also lead to unwanted health effects. These products are not substitutes for a healthy lifestyle and the natural energy that results from it. A healthy lifestyle that includes adequate sleep
post_date: rest and relaxation
post_date_gmt: proper nutrition and regular exercise provides the body with all the fuel that it needs to get through each day."

A thorough examination and comprehensive set of preventive health screenings by medical experts will produce valuable data for your doctor; however, health care isn’t all a numbers game. Talk with your doctor to fully understand what the data charts mean in real-life terms to you. This is particularly critical when making medical or lifestyle decisions based on risk factors—whether to change your diet, go on medications, or have major surgery. Prevention is founded upon a dialogue where patients are active partners with doctors in developing their care.

What to Expect from a Risk Assessment

As the CDC advises
post_title: only trained doctors should perform examinations and evaluate your health status and risks. Provide your physician with as much information as possible about your current health issues (including any medical conditions or prescriptions)

Motivation to be Motivated…why can’t I stick to my good intentions? My goals were intentionally not lofty.  I work with a trainer twice a week on strengthening and conditioning and I fit cardio in where I can on other days.  Seems achievable, right? I like the idea of having a workout routine, but with a hectic schedule, it is the first thing that drops off of my calendar when a meeting/home repair service/doctor appointment pops up, which is regularly in my world.  So, I’m trying to do the best I can, and that’s just it, DO THE BEST YOU CAN.  You’ll surprise yourself.  Here are a couple of things I do to stay focused on a physical activity routine. Get a trainer:  they hold a spot for you on their calendar which holds you to that commitment.  You cancel, you pay.  Don’t feel guilty about taking this time for yourself, keep it as a firm meeting time. Reach out to your friends and get a couple of workout buddies. A group workout is cheaper, and one buddy is not enough. They're going to have the same scheduling challenges that you have. So if you know that one or both of your buddies are depending on you to be at the session, you’ll go. Celebrate small victories:  give up sugar, pasta, bread and alcohol for one week.  Celebrate!  Lose one pound.  Celebrate! Reward yourself:  when I hit my weight goal, I am buying a new workout outfit.  Because I earned it! What do you do to stay motivated?
post_title: Finding the Motivation to Stay Motivated
post_excerpt: Finding the Motivation to Stay Motivated

post_content: Employee wellness programs are increasingly popular in corporate America. A National Business Group on Health survey shows that spending on employee wellness programming increased by 15 percent in 2013 from the previous year
post_title: and the number of companies offering incentives for participation in such programs \"has increased from 57 percent in 2009 to 74 percent in 2014.\" These trends include growth in subsidized gym memberships and exercise programs. A focus on fitness makes sense for all involved.

ID: Companies reap tax benefits from fitness programs
post_author: and employees enjoy improved health outcomes by participating. A healthy workforce may also result in further savings for companies through lower healthcare costs.

ID: A 2012 U.S. Department of Labor-commissioned study reports that \"30 percent of all employers and 63 percent of large firms provided either gym membership discounts or on-site exercise facilities\" for employees. However
post_author: corporate incentives alone may be enough to get some everyone to the gym. Many people struggle with motivation
post_date: scheduling
post_date_gmt: and knowing how to integrate exercise in their daily routine. The success of these fitness programs are defined by the employees who must take advantage of these benefits. One person’s motivation to go to the gym regularly is different from another.

ID: Starting a physical activity regimen is easier with a gym membership. A gym's operating hours allow for a consistent exercise schedule regardless of weather
post_author: and a variety of equipment and activities help prevent boredom. If you have a membership
post_date: begin by planning workout times around your daily schedule. Develop your exercise plan based upon the Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans. In order to obtain health benefits
post_date_gmt: the Guidelines recommend adults perform the following:

post_author: brisk walking) every week
post_date: plus muscle-strengthening activities on 2 or more days a week that target all major muscle groups (legs
post_content: back
post_excerpt: chest
