post_author: jogging or running) every week
post_date: plus muscle-strengthening activities on 2 or more days a week that target all major muscle groups (legs
post_content: back

While the path to physical fitness is straightforward (i.e., dieting and exercise), this path starts to meander wildly when people attempt to actually follow it--lengthening the time it takes to reach the finish line, if ever. The question, of course, becomes \why?\"

ID: Why are people hard-pressed to achieve fitness when every voice out there is saying that it's good? Not only that
post_author: but it is equally ubiquitous to hear that not being fit is bad. So why?

ID: An article in the NY Times poses an interesting answer: perhaps unfit people are simply not programmed to be fit.

post_author: the article summarizes the study by describing the findings. Essentially
post_date: rats that like to run on a wheel were bred with other rats that like to run on a wheel and they in turn produced rats that also like to run on a wheel. The opposite was true for rats that were not so inclined to run.

ID: This difference in the rats is attributed to genes encouraging certain neurons in the brains of running rats to mature and develop the drive to run. The rats that weren't inclined to run showed considerably less mature neurons in their brains. But before we put down the dumbbell in nihilistic fashion
post_author: the study also showed that even some non-running rats ran reluctantly.

ID: The professor that oversaw this study cautions that these findings shouldn't be attributed to people as the brains of rats and humans are different
post_author: and that \"people can decide to exercise\".

ID: My personal opinion of this article and its cited source is that while genetics dictate whether you'll be an Olympic-class athlete
post_author: it doesn't dictate whether you lead a healthy life. Thoughts?

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

When it comes to food and mood, you are what you eat. We tend to soothe ourselves with foods that contain high levels of added fat, sodium, and/or sugar—among other things—when we’re feeling strained. In fact, our current mood is an often overlooked component of our health. In order to maintain one’s health, individuals should understand the relationship food has on their mood.

How Food affects the Brain

It is common knowledge that foods have a basic, physical effect on the body; for example, if you eat too much junk food then you will get fat, or if you don’t eat for a few days you will feel weak. But foods also play a significant role in brain function and by extension one’s mood. A 2008 paper titled, “Brain foods: the effects of nutrients on brain function
post_title: ” published in Nature Reviews Neuroscience finds that hormones found in the stomach
post_excerpt: specifically leptin
post_password: and nutrients found in foods have been shown to influence cognition and emotion.

post_author: leptin is the hunger hormone that reduces one’s appetite (i.e. tells you when you are full) and “facilitates synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus
post_date: ” which is responsible in strengthening our ability to learn and memorize new information. Ghrelin is a peptide hormone released from the stomach that raises one’s appetite and produces similar benefits as leptin. GLP1 regulates one’s metabolism and improves memory. Insulin is an essential hormone that is produced before
post_content: and after a meal and affects cognition. In addition
post_title: omega-3 fatty acids and micro-nutrients such as iron
post_excerpt: zinc
comment_status: and vitamins A through E were shown to affect “neural pathways that are associated with synaptic plasticity.”

ID: These findings present a biological connection between food and the brain
post_author: and the necessity of providing the brain with the right kinds of food. When it comes to eating
post_date: the hormones in the stomach work with the brain in order to regulate when we eat and stop eating when we feel full. But many foods eaten today (i.e. refined
post_content: and packaged foods) can actually make you feel hungry (i.e. not full) cause insulin levels to spike. In an article titled “

ID: 11 foods that make you hungrier
post_author: ” the author lists many commonly consumed foods that studies show cause hunger by reducing leptin and spiking insulin. As the hormones in the stomach affect learning and memory
post_date: foods that constantly make us feel hungry or give us a quick boost of energy (all while lacking essential nutrients) eventually influence our brains into seeing them in an overwhelmingly positive light.

ID: When a food tastes bad or makes us feel sick
post_author: we begin to form negative associations with that food. This is a basic biological function that has helped people stay away from consuming things that were harmful to them
post_date: such as poison which can also be found in certain kinds of berries and mushrooms. But when a food tastes good and makes us feel energetic
post_date_gmt: we form positive associations. These foods taste good and make us feel energetic. And in the case of foods that reduces leptin production and spikes insulin levels
post_content: hormones shown to affect learning and memory
post_title: the positive association gets promoted to borderline addiction. Refined
post_excerpt: packaged
post_password: and then lows—an emotional roller coaster.

ID: The “Brain foods” paper concludes that: “Brain networks that are associated with the control of feeding are intimately associated with those that are involved in processing emotions
post_author: reward and cognition.” What this means is that food affects your brain on a neurological level. Healthy foods form positive associations that lead to better health and peace of mind. Refined
post_date: packaged
post_date_gmt: and processed foods form positive associations that lead to cravings and emotional mood swings
post_content: typically compounded by the fact that these foods also lead to obesity and other issues. Don’t reward good behavior with junk
post_title: and don’t allow negative feedback to occur if you’ve cheated on your diet. The consequences of these actions are more significant than just feeling bad.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_author: Maintaining Health While Healthy Part 5: Food and Mood
post_date: When it comes to food and mood, you are what you eat. Healthy foods form positive associations that lead to better health and peace of mind. Refined, packaged, and processed foods form positive associations that lead to cravings and emotional mood swings, typically compounded by the fact that these foods also lead to obesity and other issues. When maintaining one's health, don’t reward good behavior with junk.

<span id=\hs_cos_wrapper_post_body\" class=\"hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text\" data-hs-cos-general-type=\"meta_field\" data-hs-cos-type=\"rich_text\">There is no uniform or universally–accepted system used for food dating in the United States. In fact
post_title: product dating is generally not required by federal regulations (except for infant formula)
post_excerpt: and the FDA does not require \"expired by
post_status: \" \"use by\" or \"best before\" dates on food products; such information is entirely at the discretion of the manufacturer.

ID: <span id=\"hs_cos_wrapper_post_body\" class=\"hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text\" data-hs-cos-general-type=\"meta_field\" data-hs-cos-type=\"rich_text\">According to the FDA
post_author: a principle of U.S. food law is that foods in U.S. commerce must be wholesome and fit for consumption. An expiration date does not relieve a firm from this obligation. A product that is dangerous to consumers is subject to potential action by the FDA to remove it from commerce regardless of any date printed on a label.

ID: According to the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
post_author: \"open dating\" is the process of displaying a calendar date (as opposed to a code) on a food product in order to help stores determine the length of time to display a product for sale and allow the consumer to make purchase decisions based on freshness and quality. It is not a safety date. When a calendar date is used
post_date: both the month and day of the month must be stated. In the case of shelf–stable foods (foods that can be safely stored at room temperature; i.e.
post_date_gmt: on the shelf) and frozen products
post_content: the year must also be expressed. Additionally
post_title: when a date is displayed on a product
post_excerpt: there must be a phrase explaining the meaning of that date such as \"sell–by\" or \"use before.\" immediately adjacent to the date. What do these different phrases mean?

ID: • A \"sell–by\" date informs a store of the length of time to display a product for sale. Consumers should purchase such products before this date.
• A \"best if used by (or before)\" date is a recommendation pertaining to the product’s optimal flavor or quality. It is not a purchase or safety recommendation.
• A \"use–by\" date is the suggested last date that the product will be at peak quality. The date has been determined by the manufacturer of the product.
• A \"closed or coded date\" is a packing number used by the manufacturer.
These dates are indications of optimum quality as deemed by the manufacturer rather than safety recommendations. Both the FDA and the USDA agree that
post_author: even if a use–by date expires during home storage
post_date: a product should still be safe
post_date_gmt: wholesome and of good quality for a period of time beyond the date if handled properly and kept at 40 degrees Fahrenheit or below.

post_author: proper storage is critical to the integrity and shelf life of food. The mishandling and/or improper storage of food can cause food–borne bacteria to grow and result in illness before or after the date displayed on a package.

ID: The USDA recommends that consumers follow these tips:

post_author: refrigerated or frozen items should be selected after non–perishable items.

ID: • Meat or poultry in packaging that is torn or leaking should never be purchased. Products should be purchased prior to their expiration date.
• Perishable food items should be brought home immediately after purchase and refrigerated within 2 hours (1 hour when the temperature is above 90° F).
• The temperature of the refrigerator and freezer should be checked with an appliance thermometer.
• The refrigerator should be at or below forty degrees Fahrenheit and the freezer at or below zero degrees Fahrenheit.
• Handling recommendations that are listed on the product should be followed.
• Perishable food such as meat and poultry should be wrapped securely to maintain quality and to prevent meat juices from contaminating other foods.

post_author: fish
post_date: ground meats and variety meats should be cooked or frozen within two days; other beef
post_content: lamb or pork should be cooked or frozen within three to five days.

ID: • Products should be frozen if they cannot be used within the appropriate time period.

post_author: it does not matter if its date expires; foods that are kept continuously frozen are safe indefinitely.

ID: <li>To maintain quality when freezing meat and poultry in its original package
post_author: the package should be wrapped again with foil or plastic wrap.

ID: <li>Eggs can be stored in the refrigerator for three to five weeks after purchase. In general
post_author: canned goods remain in good condition if they are stored in a cool
post_date: clean and dry place.

post_author: grapefruit and pineapple retain optimum quality for 12 to 18 months.
poultry
post_date: fish and most vegetables retain optimum quality on the shelf for two to five years.

post_author: cans that are bulging
post_date: dented or rusting should be thrown away because they may harbor harmful bacteria.

ID: If the freshness of a food item is questionable
post_author: common sense should prevail. Consumers must judge the freshness and edibility of their food themselves. The best way to do so is by using the senses
post_date: namely smell and sight. Before an expired product (or any product for that matter) is consumed
post_date_gmt: it should be checked for mold
post_content: odor or any other indication that the item might be contaminated. Food that develops an off odor
post_title: flavor or appearance due to spoilage should be discarded."
post_excerpt: Food Expiration and Safety

post_content: Back in June of this year, the Journal of the American Medical Association released some interesting news: The 2015 Dietary Guidelines would lift the ban on dietary fat—previously the recommendation was to have no more than 35 percent of calories in one’s diet coming from fat.

ID: This change comes partially from the behavior of substitution and how simplifying problems typically lead to more problems with greater complexity.

post_author: since “fat contains about twice the calories per gram as carbohydrate or protein
post_date: it was also reasoned that low-fat diets would help prevent obesity

post_author: low-fat and low-calorie products became the norm; however
post_date: these products substituted dietary fat for refined calories and added sugar.

ID: Substituted things are typically not of the same quality as the thing they are substituting
post_author: and such is the case with products that tried to substitute fat. Rather than lowering obesity and the risk for cardiovascular disease
post_date: low-fat products ironically increased these numbers because everything boiled down to getting total fat to zero on the nutrition label.

ID: Obesity is a complex problem that has numerous causes working with each other to create the epidemic that still continues to this day. Even if an individual were to eat what is considered a healthy diet
post_author: this by itself won’t change everything. Indeed
post_date: those who go from one unhealthy practice to a healthy one might substitute another unhealthy practice for the one that they gave up
post_date_gmt: yet the substituted practice is actually worse than the one before it.

ID: For example
post_author: a person decides to substitute cakes and other desserts with fruit in an effort to curb added sugars and fat. But because there is a void in this person’s sweet tooth rather than eat sugar he/she will drink them instead as his/her consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages rise. This makes the problem worse because now the individual is actually consuming more added sugar than before
post_date: but considers it to be ok because he/she has stopped eating desserts.

ID: When it comes to your health there is no substitution. Processed and refined foods will always take a back seat to those that are unprocessed and unrefined
post_author: such as whole fruits
post_date: vegetables

Does meal frequency matter? If so, what is the healthiest eating pattern? Three square meals a day? Two big meals? Six small meals? Grazing throughout the day? No eating after 7:00 p.m.? The truth is that such eating patterns can have an impact on weight and overall health, but this impact is limited and is closely related to other dietary factors.

Common Eating Patterns

While there are proponents of a great variety of eating patterns, two of the most common are \three meals a day\" and \"small

ID: Conventional wisdom has long held that the \"three square meals a day\" (breakfast
post_author: lunch
post_date: and dinner) eating pattern is the optimal pattern for health
post_content: and weight management. Recent research does in fact confirm a number of benefits related to this pattern.

ID: A study published in the November 2011 Journal of the American Dietetic Association found that the consumption of three meals a day along with two snacks was associated with better long–term weight loss maintenance than other patterns. Another study by the University of Missouri
post_author: lead by Tim Heden
post_date: in 2012 found that the consumption of less frequent
post_date_gmt: larger meals may be “more advantageous metabolically” for obese women. In the study
post_content: the blood fat levels of eight obese women were measured on two occasions — after eating three meals and after eating six meals. Results showed that blood fat levels were lower when the women consumed three meals compared to six.

post_author: in another study published in Obesity in March 2011
post_date: Purdue University researchers found that
post_content: regular-sized meals with higher amounts of lean protein can make one feel more full than eating smaller
post_title: more frequent meals”. The researchers also found that eating more frequently had relatively no beneficial impact on appetite control. The larger meals led to reduced appetites
post_excerpt: and people felt satiated. Researchers emphasize that the three larger meals were restricted in calories and reflected appropriate portion sizes for weight loss.

post_author: More Frequent Meals

ID: Many individuals believe that eating smaller
post_author: more frequent meals throughout the day raises metabolism and helps to keep it raised
post_date: thereby helping individuals to lose or maintain weight. The fact is
post_content: that food intake has only a small impact on basal metabolism
post_title: and individuals who consume more calories in order to increase metabolism will end up with a net gain in calories rather than a deficit. EHE’s Jeff Novick offers the following example: the increase in metabolism during food digestion amounts to only 10 to 15 percent of the calories ingested. Therefore
post_excerpt: if an individual consumes a 300–calorie snack
post_status: he or she may \"burn\" 30 to 45 calories more than he or she would without the snack
comment_status: but would also end up with a net gain of 255 to 270 calories. Taking in a net of 255 to 270 calories to raise metabolism by 30 calories would not be beneficial in regard to energy balance.

post_author: the perceived weight loss benefits related to this eating pattern are not supported by scientific evidence. Researchers from the School of Human Kinetics at the University of Ottawa conducted a study of meal frequency that was published in the 2010 British Journal of Nutrition. Sixteen obese men and women participated in the study. Researchers found that
post_date: when individuals consumed the same amount of overall calories
post_date_gmt: there was no weight loss advantage to eating more frequent meals versus less frequent meals.

ID: While this eating pattern does not offer any real benefit in terms of metabolism or weight loss
post_author: it can be an effective means of avoiding feelings of extreme hunger that can lead to overindulgence and the gain of additional weight. However
post_date: that effectiveness can easily be negated if an individual does not control portions and/or consumes several meals containing foods that are calorie dense.

ID: There are many additional eating patterns
post_author: each with its proponents and detractors. Some eating patterns that have recently gained popularity involve fasting and/or short–term food deprivation to aid in weight loss. However
post_date: such eating patterns are not proven to be effective methods of losing weight. In a study published in the February 2013 edition of NeuroImage
post_date_gmt: researchers found that weight loss efforts are more successful when individuals consume healthy
post_content: low–fat/low–sugar foods during regular meals instead of going for long periods of time without any caloric intake. Another study published in the June 24
post_title: 2013 edition of The Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) Internal Medicine found that individuals who were practicing short–term food deprivation (i.e.
post_excerpt: skipping meals) bought 31 percent more high–calorie foods when grocery shopping.

post_author: in light of the toxic food environment in the U.S.
post_date: the frequency and timing of an individual’s meals are much less important than the types of foods consumed. In fact
post_date_gmt: when an individual adheres to a nutrient–rich
post_content: lower–calorie–dense diet
post_title: eating patterns are not as important as there is little danger of overeating. Conversely
post_excerpt: if an individual is consuming processed foods that are calorie–dense and nutrient–poor
post_status: he or she is much more likely to gain weight regardless of eating pattern.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider. Individuals with specific complaints should seek immediate consultation from their personal physicians.

This second “Maintaining Health…” blog is all about what we consume and understanding the value of our diets. By developing a deeper understanding of the role of food in our lives, we will be better prepared to make decisions that benefit our health.

Making Your Diet Trend Towards Healthy

In part 1
post_title: it was stated that a healthy diet places emphasis on <em>“reducing and/or eliminating the intake of refined
post_excerpt: processed
post_status: and packaged foods and moving toward an unrefined
comment_status: unprocessed plant–based diet that is centered on fruits
post_name: intact whole grains and legumes.” If one were to take a closer look at the quote
to_ping: “reducing and/or eliminating the intake of refined
post_modified: and packaged foods” is really the key element as these are the foods that undermine our health
post_modified_gmt: providing little-to-no nutritional value while contributing excessive calories to the diet.

ID: There are two types of grains: whole grains and refined grains. According to choosemyplate.gov
post_author: “Whole grains contain the entire grain kernel ― the bran
post_date: germ
post_date_gmt: and endosperm. Examples of whole grains include whole-wheat flour
post_content: bulgur (cracked wheat)
post_excerpt: whole cornmeal
post_status: and brown rice. Refined grains have been milled
comment_status: a process that removes the bran and germ. This is done to give grains a finer texture and improve their shelf life
ping_status: but it also removes dietary fiber
post_name: and many B vitamins. Some examples of refined grain products are white flour

ID: When we consume a refined grain
post_author: we are consuming calories without obtaining as many nutrients with all the benefits of the whole grain. Studies show that consumption of whole grains can help to protect individuals from developing many chronic diseases such as cancer
post_date: cardiovascular disease and diabetes. People who regularly consume whole grains also tend to have lower cholesterol levels and are less prone to obesity. Whole grain snacks include low–fat whole–grain crackers
post_content: pretzels and cereals. To snack the right way
post_title: individuals should look for food items that are labeled \"100% whole grain\" and are low in salt
post_excerpt: sugar and fat.

ID: Added sugar is another major problem in the common American diet
post_author: equally as insidious as refined grains but potentially more harmful. According to the American Heart Association (AHA)
post_date: added sugar can be found in: “soft drinks
post_content: candy

2017 is here and millions of Americans are reflecting on the personal changes that they want (or need) to make this year. Popular resolutions include vowing to lose weight, eat healthier, reduce stress, exercise more or quit smoking. There is just one problem: while all of this sounds good in January, many of us lose our resolve and our resolutions are long forgotten and abandoned by April. The simple truth is that New Year’s resolutions are easier to make than they are to keep because changing behaviors, particularly those that are long-standing habits, is easier said than done. Wanting to change is not enough. Success with a resolution demands more than wishful thinking; it requires patience, planning, and organization. The good news it is that it can be done! Many organizations recommend using the S.M.A.R.T. criteria to reach your goals and make lasting change. The acronym has several variations that are all similar. For our purposes we will use: specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-based.
  • Specific: The first step in moving toward change is to be very specific about what you want to achieve. Avoid vague, noncommittal resolutions to \lose weight\" or \"eat healthier\" or \"get out of debt.\" These goals are all too ambiguous and
post_excerpt: are rarely successful. For example
post_status: rather than deciding you want to lose weight
comment_status: decide how much weight you want to lose and in what time frame. Be specific.

ID: • Measurable: When you are specific about the change you want to make
post_author: you can break it down into smaller specific goals that can be accomplished — and tracked — on a daily or weekly basis. This allows you to measure your progress. If you’re trying to lose a specific amount of weight
post_date: a reasonable and healthy goal is to aim to lose one-to-two pounds per week. You could do that by planning out and tracking how many calories you will eat each day and how many minutes of physical activity you will do each day. Then you will be able to concretely monitor your progress and measure your successes and shortcomings and make adjustments accordingly.

ID: • Achievable: To make a lasting change the goals you set need to be reasonable and achievable. Setting a goal that requires little effort usually offers little motivation
post_author: but setting a goal that will be extremely difficult or even impossible to reach may be even more discouraging. The change you want to make should be challenging enough to motivate you
post_date: but not so challenging that you become frustrated because you may not possess the skills or resources to attain the goal. For example
post_date_gmt: quitting smoking cold turkey is not usually successful. Substituting nicotine gum for cigarettes on a regular schedule is much more likely to succeed. Regularly meeting realistic
post_content: achievable
post_title: short–term goals helps to build successful habits
post_excerpt: makes continuing to work toward the change easier

ID: • Relevant: While many of us can most likely name a number of things we would like to change and improve in our lives
post_author: it is important to remember that trying to make too many changes at once will almost certainly lead to failure. Instead
post_date: think about the change that would have the most meaning and impact in your life and start with that. If it is a change you’ve tried to make before but were unsuccessful
post_date_gmt: it is important to think about and pinpoint the root cause(s) of what has held you back in the past so you can shift away from the negative thoughts and behaviors that led to failure and instead choose your thoughts and behaviors wisely and deliberately so you can successfully change.

ID: • Time-based:Setting a timeline to achieve a major change may be unrealistic if the change will require a long-term commitment
post_author: however
post_date: it is certainly possible to pick a date and time to start the process. It is also possible to pick timeframes for your shorter-term goals that are the stepping stones to reaching the larger goal. Whatever the change
post_date_gmt: you must also make time in your schedule to work on it. If the change is to exercise regularly
post_content: you need to schedule specific days and times to workout. If it is to improve your diet
post_title: you must schedule time to plan healthy meals for the week ahead and to shop for the necessary items. If it is to quit smoking
post_excerpt: you must schedule breaks in your daily routine to help combat the stress that comes with nicotine withdrawal.

ID: It is also important that you anticipate setbacks from time to time and plan for them. If
post_author: for example
post_date: you have a big vacation planned or know that your family is planning a big
post_content: maybe that is a week that you need to adjust your schedule. There is no sense setting yourself up for failure; if you know that a particular week is going to be hard
post_title: acknowledge that and adjust your plan accordingly. Of course
post_excerpt: you should not give yourself every other week off
post_status: but a reasonable amount of slack is appropriate.

ID: Whatever your New Year’s resolutions are this year
post_author: remember that there are different ways to go about achieving your goals. It may take you several attempts using several different methods to reach your goals. For many people
post_date: this trial and error is often discouraging
post_date_gmt: causing them to give up. It is
post_content: therefore
post_title: important to continue moving toward your goal
post_excerpt: to try new techniques and find ways to stay motivated. Set small
post_status: attainable goals and reward yourself appropriately when achieving each one. Experts say that setting up a reward system is an excellent strategy to help you stick to a long–term goal. Perhaps the most important thing to do is to only make New Year’s resolutions that are truly important to you and that you will be motivated to achieve. Making a lasting change in behavior is rarely a simple process and will likely entail a substantial commitment of time
comment_status: effort and emotion. But where there’s a will there’s a way and you can successfully achieve lasting change!"

Each year, millions of Americans are diagnosed with digestive disorders that can affect their quality of life. These disorders can cause individuals to experience various forms of discomfort on a routine basis. In order to achieve optimal health and well–being, one’s digestive health must not be overlooked. Develop habits today that will help to improve and maintain your body''s digestive health. There are important steps that individuals can take to improve and/or maintain digestive health:
  • Do not smoke: Smoking can harm all parts of the digestive system. Smoking increases an individual’s risk of developing Crohn’s disease, damages his or her liver and may contribute to the development of gallstones. Smoking also weakens the lower esophageal sphincter which can exacerbate gastroesophogeal reflux. Research has shown that people who smoke cigarettes are also more likely to develop an ulcer.
  • Consume a balanced diet: Commitment to a healthy diet is one of the most important components of an individual’s overall health and well being. A diet that is considered to be ‘healthy’ is one that limits the intake of sodium, saturated fats, added sugars and sweeteners, solid fats and refined grains. It also emphasizes foods that are low in calorie density and high in nutrient density such as plant–based foods (i.e., fruits, vegetables, starchy vegetables, intact whole grains and legumes) and lean proteins. With a plant–based diet, fiber intake is high and saturated fat intake is typically low. Fiber is essential because it eases the passage of food through the digestive tract, and helps to prevent a number of conditions including GERD, IBS, obesity and diverticulitis. Fluid consumption — especially water — is also very important. Water helps to dissolve nutrients, encourages passage of waste through the digestive system and helps to soften stools.
  • Engage in regular physical activity: Regular physical activity helps to strengthen the muscles of the abdomen and stimulates the intestinal muscles to push digestive contents through the digestive system. Regular physical activity also helps to ward off constipation and other problems such as weight gain and stress.
  • Maintain a healthy weight: Obesity is linked to a number of digestive problems such as GERD, hemorrhoids and even esophageal cancer. By losing weight and maintaining a healthy weight, individuals can prevent many digestive issues.
  • Reduce stress: When individual is under stress, his or her digestion process can slow down and bloating, pain and constipation may result. The individual may need to empty his or her bowels frequently, and the stools may be more loose and watery. Stress can also exacerbate conditions such as peptic ulcers and IBS. In order to reduce stress, individuals should engage in regular exercise, enjoy adequate amounts of sleep and adhere to a healthy diet. There are many stress management techniques that can also be utilized such as deep breathing or visualization exercises, meditation, yoga, massage, hypnotherapy and/or counseling.
  • Take necessary medication(s): In general, medications are only used when symptoms have not adequately responded to more conservative measures such as dietary changes and stress management. Individuals should consult a physician to determine if medication is appropriate.
MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.
post_title: How Can I Improve My Digestive Health?

post_content: Poor oral and dental hygiene can lead to a variety of ailments including tooth decay, bad breath, gingivitis, and periodontal (gum) disease. According to recent research, however, there may also be a connection between an individual’s oral health and his or her overall health. Poor oral and dental health may increase an individual’s risk of developing other serious health conditions such as heart disease, diabetes, and stroke. The practice of good oral hygiene may therefore be more than just an important component of an individual’s oral and dental health; it may also be a key element of his or her overall preventive health regimen. Good oral hygiene and oral health are not difficult to attain. The American Dental Association (ADA) recommends that individuals brush their teeth, floss, visit a dentist regularly, and consume a healthy diet. Brush Teeth: Teeth should be brushed twice a day with a fluoride toothpaste and soft–bristled tooth brush. A tooth brush should be replaced every three or four months or sooner if the bristles are frayed. According to the ADA
post_title: the proper method for brushing teeth is as follows:

ID: • \"Place your toothbrush at a 45–degree angle to the gums.
• Gently move the brush back and forth in short (tooth–wide) strokes.

post_author: the inner surfaces
post_date: and the chewing surfaces of the teeth.

ID: <li>To clean the inside surfaces of the front teeth
post_author: tilt the brush vertically and make several up–and–down strokes.

ID: • Brush your tongue to remove bacteria and keep your breath fresh.\"

Floss: The ADA recommends that individuals floss between their teeth once a day. Flossing helps to remove plaque and food particles in places that a toothbrush cannot reach (between the teeth and under the gum line). While it is okay to brush before flossing or vice–versa
post_author: choosing to floss before brushing the teeth may allow fluoride from the toothpaste to reach between teeth more effectively.

ID: Schedule regular dental checkups: Regular visits to the dentist for a checkup and professional cleaning are important because a dentist can detect oral health problems early and help to prevent oral health problems altogether. Additionally
post_author: it is important for an individual to let the dentist know about any changes in overall health because a number of medical conditions can also affect oral health. Each individual should consult with his or her dentist to determine the appropriate frequency of visits.

ID: Consume a healthy diet: Adherence to a healthy diet is an important factor in oral health. According to the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics
post_author: an individual’s food choices can \"affect the development and integrity of the oral cavity and progression of oral diseases.\" The Academy’s position statement on oral health and nutrition states:

ID: <li>\"It is the position of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics that nutrition is an integral component of oral health. The Academy supports integration of oral health with nutrition services
post_author: education and research. Collaboration between dietetics practitioners and oral health care professionals is recommended for oral health promotion and disease prevention and intervention.\"

ID: A ‘healthy’ diet is one that reduces and/or eliminates the intake of refined
post_author: processed
post_date: and packaged foods
post_date_gmt: and emphasizes the consumption of unrefined and unprocessed plant–based foods such as fruits
post_content: vegetables
post_excerpt: intact whole grains

post_status: it is advisable to begin adding short spurts of running to the walking routine
comment_status: gradually building up the length and amount of time spent running until only short bouts of walking are necessary. RunnersWorld.com recommends gradually building up the length of time spent walking and running by no more than 10 percent each week.

ID: Patience is essential. Some people try to do too much too soon and quit before having a chance to experience the rewards of improved fitness. The body needs to adjust to the strain of running or any new physical activity. As the body adjusts
post_author: the duration and intensity of running can be increased gradually. Taking breaks to walk when building a running routine is important as it will help prevent injury and prevent an individual from doing too much too soon. Pay attention to signals that the body sends when running. Pain
post_date: shortness of breath
post_content: and nausea all signal that it is time to take a break. Exercise should not hurt. Mild soreness may occur but any exercise that causes sharp or continuous pain should be discontinued until the individual has a chance to consult with a doctor.

Such individuals will also likely benefit from a consultation with a trained fitness professional who can design an individualized program that takes all such needs into account.
The key to any running program

The term cognition encompasses mental processes related to attention, learning, memory and language as well as executive functions such as decision–making, goal–setting, planning and judgment. When an individual loses the ability to carry out these processes and/or perform these functions, cognitive impairment (also referred to as \cognitive decline\" or \"cognitive deficit\") is said to occur.

ID: Cognitive impairment currently affects approximately 16 million Americans. However
post_author: this number is expected to rise dramatically as the number of Americans aged 65 and older increases in the coming years.

ID: While there is no conclusive proof to support any particular course of action to prevent the development of cognitive impairment
post_author: researchers have found evidence that some risk factors can be modified

the brain needs a constant supply of oxygen and nutrients from the blood to work properly. There is now overwhelming evidence that suggests that the same lifestyle and dietary factors that contribute to heart disease also increase an individual’s risk of developing dementia and age–related cognitive impairment. Therefore
post_date: \"managing numbers\" — cholesterol levels
post_date_gmt: blood pressure and blood sugar — is vital as improving cardiovascular health may also reduce one’s risk of developing dementia.

ID: • Cholesterol levels: Excess cholesterol in the blood is dangerous as it can build up on the walls of the arteries and harden into plaque. The plaque can then cause a narrowing and/or blockage in the arteries that restricts the flow of blood and oxygen. When blood vessels in the brain become hardened
post_author: narrowed or damaged
post_date: brain cells can become damaged and die
post_date_gmt: resulting in vascular dementia. The most common cause of elevated cholesterol levels is a diet that is high in saturated fats
post_content: trans–fatty acids and dietary cholesterol (i.e.
post_excerpt: eggs
post_status: dairy products and fried and processed foods). Individuals can control high blood cholesterol by: adhering to a healthy diet that limits fat and cholesterol intake; consuming only enough calories to achieve or maintain a healthy weight; performing regular physical activity; increasing soluble fiber in the diet (e.g.
ping_status: beans and apples); avoiding tobacco and limiting alcohol consumption; and by consuming cholesterol–lowering foods that are rich in soluble fiber (i.e.

ID: • Blood pressure: High blood pressure (140/90 mmHg or higher) appears to be associated with an increased risk of the development of both vascular dementia and Alzheimer’s disease and is a major risk factor for heart disease
post_author: stroke
post_date: congestive heart failure and kidney disease. When an individual has high blood pressure
post_date_gmt: the heart must work harder to move blood throughout the body. Most individuals can control blood pressure by adhering to a healthy diet
post_content: performing regular physical activity
post_excerpt: managing stress
post_status: avoiding tobacco and limiting alcohol consumption.

post_author: high blood glucose levels (hyperglycemia) can damage nerves and blood vessels
post_date: thereby increasing an individual’s risk of developing dementia. Individuals with hyperglycemia or diabetes must carefully control their blood glucose levels through proper nutrition
post_content: loss of excess weight
post_title: monitoring of daily blood glucose levels and adherence to any prescribed medication regimen. Additionally
post_excerpt: individuals with type 1 diabetes must have insulin delivered to the body each day by either a pump or an injection. Some people with type 2 diabetes may also need insulin therapy to control their blood glucose. According to research results published in the August 13
post_status: 2013 edition of The New England Journal of Medicine
comment_status: higher glucose levels may be a risk factor for dementia

ID: • Smoking: A number of studies have found that smokers who are middle aged and older may have an increased risk of developing dementia. Smoking is also a major risk factor for heart disease. Studies have shown
post_author: however
post_date: that when an individual quits smoking
post_date_gmt: his or her heart rate and blood pressure begin to return to normal and many other risk factors for heart disease show improvement.

ID: • Alcohol consumption: Existing data is inconsistent and a definitive assessment of the relationship between alcohol use and dementia is not yet possible
post_author: but evidence increasingly suggests that light–to–moderate drinking may be protective against the onset of dementia. However
post_date: no one should begin drinking or drink more frequently based upon potential and inconclusive health benefits. The possible health benefits of moderate alcohol consumption apply only to moderate consumption and never to heavy drinking. Heavy and/or excessive drinking is a known risk factor for the development of dementia.

ID: • Physical fitness: Numerous studies have found a link between the performance of physical activity and improved cognitive function. According to the results of a study published in the December 2012 issue of Stroke
post_author: regular physical activity may decrease an individual’s risk of developing dementia by 40 percent
post_date: and may decrease the risk of a decline in thinking skills by as much as 60 percent. The researchers suggest that individuals (particularly individuals with vascular risk factors such as high blood pressure
post_date_gmt: stroke or diabetes) participate in moderate–intensity physical activity for at least 30 minutes three times a week to prevent cognitive impairment. Regular physical activity increases blood flow and oxygen to the brain
post_content: and increases the levels of brain chemicals that encourage the growth of nerve cells. Additionally
post_title: the performance of aerobic activity has been linked to enhanced memory skills
post_excerpt: while moderately–strenuous physical activity is strongly associated with healthy brain aging.

post_author: heart–healthy diet that is low in fat
post_date: rich in fruits
post_content: antioxidants and omega–3 fatty acids has been linked to improved cognition.

ID: • Mental fitness: When an individual exercises his or her brain by learning new things or pursuing activities that are intellectually stimulating
post_author: brain–cell networks may be strengthened. Recent studies have found that people who engage more frequently in activities that involve significant information processing have a much lower incidence of dementia.

ID: • Stress management: When stress is chronic or unmitigated
post_author: it can damage the brain and impair memory. When faced with a serious stressor
post_date: the brain triggers the adrenal glands to release powerful stress hormones such as cortisol and adrenaline. Repeated or long–term exposure to these hormones is toxic to nerve cells in the hippocampus. While the goal of eliminating stress entirely from life is unrealistic
post_date_gmt: it is important for an individual to learn effective coping strategies.

ID: • Social engagement: Numerous studies have shown that staying socially connected is an important aspect of cognitive health and may help protect against cognitive impairment and dementia. Conversely
post_author: social isolation is associated with numerous health problems and a shorter lifespan. Social activity is also closely linked to feelings of \"self–efficacy
post_date: \" the sense that one’s actions make a difference and that life has meaning. The reasons are not entirely clear
post_date_gmt: but some experts believe that self–efficacy may be related to a greater resilience to stress.

ID: • Adequate sleep: A growing body of evidence suggests that a full night of restful sleep is critical for memory consolidation and the ability to retain information. In studies
post_author: people who are deprived of sleep generally score significantly worse on memory and cognitive tests
post_date: and the deficits may not be reversible even after the participants resume restful sleep.

ID: • Underlying health problems: Certain causes of cognitive impairment are related to treatable health issues such as medication side effects
post_author: vitamin B12 deficiency and depression. It is important for individuals with an underlying medical problem to receive proper medical attention and treatment.

ID: • Head trauma: Some studies have shown a link between moderate
post_author: severe and repeated mild traumatic brain injuries and an increased risk of AD or other forms of dementia years after the original head injury(s). Individuals can prevent head trauma by wearing a seat belt
post_date: using a helmet when participating in sports and by \"fall–proofing\" their homes.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_author: How Do I Prevent Cognitive Impairment and Dementia?
post_date: The term cognition encompasses mental processes related to attention, learning, memory and language as well as executive functions
post_content: open

The knees are essential to just about every movement that an individual makes. When the knees are healthy, individuals are able to perform tasks with ease and participate in a wide range of activities. When the knees are damaged, however, even the simplest tasks can seem very difficult. This article will focus on ways to prevent knee injury. While not all knee conditions can be prevented, there are steps that individuals can take to reduce their risk:
  • Maintain a healthy weight: Overweight and obesity places increased pressure and stress on the knees and increases an individual’s risk of ligament and tendon injuries as well as osteoarthritis. Individuals can reduce their risk of developing osteoarthritis — or lessen severity of symptoms if already diagnosed — by maintaining a healthy weight or by losing weight if overweight or obese.
  • Exercise regularly: Exercises that are designed to strengthen the quadriceps and hamstrings are vital to the health of the knees as weak muscles are a leading cause of knee injury. Balance and stability training will also help the muscles around the knees to work together more effectively. As individuals strengthen their muscles with exercise, they will also strengthen their bones. It is important for individuals suffering from chronic knee pain or osteoarthritis to consult a healthcare professional before beginning an exercise regimen as high–impact activities should likely be avoided in favor of swimming, water aerobics or other low–impact exercises.
  • Warm up and cool down: It is important to warm up and cool down before and after working out by performing walking, bending and stretching exercises to reduce the risk of injury. By stretching the quadriceps muscles and hamstrings, an individual can reduce tension on the tendons and relieve pressure on the knee during physical activity.
  • Wear proper footwear: To maintain balance and leg alignment, individuals should wear shoes that fit properly, are in good condition and are appropriate for the activity being performed. Most experts recommend that individuals purchase new athletic shoes every three months or after 500 miles of wear. Individuals suffering from flat or overpronated feet (feet that roll inward) can wear special shoe inserts (orthotics) to help alleviate these problems.
  • Wear protective gear: Individuals should wear protective equipment such as kneepads and shin guards as appropriate when participating in sports or other activities.
  • Pay attention to signals: Pain signals that it is time to take a break. Exercise should not hurt. Mild soreness may occur, but any exercise that causes sharp or continuous pain should be discontinued until an individual can consult a physician.
Healthy knees are essential for mobility and the performance of a wide variety of functions. When the knees are unhealthy, relatively simple actions like walking across the room, climbing stairs and getting in and out of the car can all become a challenge. Take the steps now to take proper care of your knees so that you can maintain or improve your lifestyle and enjoy a healthy and active life.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_date: While not all knee conditions can be prevented, there are steps that individuals can take to reduce their risk

Sleep needs are largely individual — some people can thrive with less sleep than others. However, different age groups generally require different amounts of sleep. Babies need up to 18 hours of sleep each day, while most adults require 7 to 9 hours. However, the 2011 Sleep in America poll conducted by the National Sleep Foundation revealed that 63 percent of adult Americans sleep less than 7 hours a night
post_title: and 15 percent sleep less than 6 hours on weeknights.

ID: Inadequate sleep can take a toll on an individual’s mind
post_author: body and overall health. It can lead to drowsiness
post_date: poor concentration
post_content: impaired physical performance
post_title: irritability and mood swings. The CDC has also found that long-term insufficient sleep is associated with a number of chronic diseases and conditions including high blood pressure
post_excerpt: diabetes
ping_status: depression and increased mortality. A lack of sleep is not only associated with the onset of these diseases
post_password: it may also complicate their management and outcomes.

ID: Individuals are exhibiting signs and symptoms of inadequate sleep when they are:
• Having difficulty getting out of bed in the morning
• Having difficulty staying focused and alert in meetings or classes
• Needing to nap to get through the day
• Falling asleep while watching TV or relaxing in the evening
• Routinely falling asleep within five minutes of lying down
A physician should be consulted if these symptoms are routinely present. When an individual feels that he or she is sleeping for an adequate period of time but still experiences these symptoms
post_author: a sleep disorder may be affecting quality of sleep. The quality of sleep is just as important as the quantity - an individual whose sleep is frequently interrupted or cut short is not getting quality sleep.

ID: Sleep health should be seen as being just as important as mental and physical health; after all
post_author: it plays a key role in both. Avoid neglecting your sleep when you are busy and then ‘catching up’ when you have more free time. Make your sleep health a priority by practicing proper sleep habits every day.

ID: >MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_author: How Much Sleep Is Enough?

Sound sleep is restorative for the brain and body—it affects the way that an individual looks, feels, and performs each day and can have a major impact on overall quality of life. The practices, habits, and environmental factors that help an individual achieve sound sleep are referred to as proper “sleep hygiene.”

ID: The practice of proper sleep hygiene includes the following elements:
<li>Making sleep a priority by keeping a consistent bedtime and waking schedule
post_author: seven days a week

ID: <li>Ensuring that the bedroom is pleasant and conducive to sleep by keeping it dark
post_author: quiet
post_date: comfortable and cool (computers
post_date_gmt: televisions and work materials should be kept out of the bedroom and the discussion of emotional issues with a partner should be avoided before sleep)

ID: <li>Creating a bedtime routine that is relaxing (e.g.
post_author: reading a book or listening to soothing music before sleep) • Exercising at least three hours before bed (such exercise can help an individual to fall asleep faster and sleep more soundly)

ID: <li>Avoiding caffeine and nicotine for four to six hours before bedtime (the stimulating effects of caffeine in coffee
post_author: colas
post_date: teas and chocolate can take as long as eight hours to wear off fully)

ID: <li>Recognizing the effects of alcohol (while it may help an individual to fall asleep faster
post_author: alcohol disrupts sleep after a few hours as the body begins to metabolize the alcohol)

ID: • Finishing dinner several hours before bed and avoiding foods that cause indigestion
<li>Balancing fluid intake so that thirst is quenched for the night
post_author: but fluid intake is not so great that an individual must wake up during the night to urinate

ID: <li>Avoiding daytime naps (if an individual feels that he or she must nap
post_author: the nap should be kept short and occur before 5:00 p.m.)

ID: <li>Getting enough exposure to natural light (individuals should try to be exposed to natural sunlight for at least 30 minutes each day and
post_author: if possible
post_date: wake up with the sun shining or use very bright lights in the morning)

ID: <li>Going to sleep when truly tired and not forcing sleep (if an individual cannot fall asleep after 20 minutes
post_author: he or she should get up
post_date: go to another room
post_date_gmt: and do something relaxing such as reading or listening to soothing music until tired enough to get back into bed and fall asleep)

ID: Everyone has woken up on the wrong side of the bed at least one time in their lives
post_author: and must know that sacrificing sleep is a no-no—walking zombies are for the movies! By keeping good sleep hygiene you will ensure a wakeful start to every day.

A regular physical examination is a vital tool for the assessment of an individual’s current health and for the early detection of preventable diseases. The exam also provides an opportunity for an individual and his or her doctor to develop a personalized health plan that focuses on healthy lifestyle choices and appropriate behavior modifications. While it can be easy to forego exams, especially when one is feeling healthy, the power of exams to help individuals live longer, healthier lives should not be underestimated.

Why Have Regular Physical Exams?

According to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), all adults — even seemingly healthy ones — should undergo regular physical examinations at their healthcare provider’s recommended frequency. When an individual has regular exams, his or her physician can compare measurements of weight, blood pressure, cholesterol and body mass index (BMI) over the years and address changes as needed. Regular physical exams also provide the following key benefits: Disease screening. Screening tests play a major role in the exam process. Even before risk factors are identified and/or symptoms are recognized, screening tests help to detect diseases in their early, most treatable stages and can even prevent disease. Many conditions and diseases are highly treatable when detected early. Without screenings, however, many conditions will go unnoticed because they do not produce symptoms until a critical level is reached. High blood pressure, for instance, is a silent disease that does not exhibit symptoms. Yet over time, high blood pressure can cause more and more damage to every part of the body. Similarly, high blood sugar and high cholesterol levels typically do not produce symptoms until advanced stages. Preventive screenings are performed for dozens of health issues and typically follow age and gender–specific guidelines. Such guidelines can be confusing however, as recommendations may vary between organizations and may change as new information becomes available. While general guidelines can provide a ‘ballpark estimate’ of what to be screened for and when, it is important for all individuals to develop a partnership with a knowledgeable healthcare provider who can personalize screening recommendations according to each patient’s unique needs. In addition to finding disease in an early, treatable stage, the results of screening tests can help people to take steps to manage risk factors and reduce the likelihood that they will develop a life–threatening disease or disabling condition. Assessment of risk factors. Lifestyle behaviors, family health history and measurements of blood pressure, BMI, cholesterol and glucose levels are all important indicators of an individual’s risk of developing certain medical conditions. Lifestyle behaviors such as diet, activity level, safe sex practices, stress level and drug, alcohol and tobacco use should all be discussed candidly during the exam. Family history can influence the risk of chronic diseases such as heart disease, stroke, diabetes and various cancers. Any new conditions or diseases that have occurred in an individual’s family since his or her last physical exam should be discussed. It is imperative that individuals provide the most up–to–date and truthful information to their doctor in order to receive the most accurate assessment. Lifestyle modification. Achieving a healthy weight, maintaining an active lifestyle, consuming a healthy diet with adequate fruits and vegetables, getting enough sleep, avoiding or minimizing alcohol intake and not smoking are behaviors that have been proven to be essential to a long and healthy life. Physicians can address these behaviors with patients and both parties can then discuss related changes, opportunities and obstacles. For example, when a physician tells a patient that he or she needs to lose weight, it is important that the physician explains why it is necessary and helps the patient understand the consequences of overweight and obesity. The patient will gain more knowledge about the ways in which overweight or obesity affects his or her health, and can then work with the physician to develop a plan for making necessary changes. Vaccination updates. It is important for individuals to receive recommended immunizations to protect against serious, preventable diseases. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there are a significant number of illnesses, disabilities and deaths that result from diseases that could easily have been prevented by vaccination. Specific immunization recommendations depend on a number of factors including age, lifestyle, high–risk conditions, type and locations of travel and previous immunizations, so it is important that each individual discusses his or her personal vaccination plan with a physician. Physician/patient relationship. The most important part of a physical exam is the exchange of information between an individual and his or her doctor. Individuals should prepare for a physical exam ahead of time by collecting important information for the doctor including a list of questions and current concerns, a list of changes that have occurred since the last exam (including changes in family health history) and a list of current medications and supplements that they are taking. It is important for all individuals to develop a partnership with a knowledgeable and trusted healthcare provider who can effectively discuss medical questions and concerns. When a trusting relationship is formed, individuals are more likely to visit their doctor when they are ill and are more likely to comply with the doctor’s orders in general. The best way to prolong life is to take measures to prevent illness whenever possible. Having regular physical exams and leading a healthy lifestyle are the two most important preventive measures that you can control. If it is time for your regular physical exam, make your health a priority and schedule your exam today.
MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_content: Cognitive fitness is as important to an individual's overall quality of life as physical health is, and it demands similar attention. Being quick, having good recall, and delaying mental fatigue are all benefits of a brain-healthy lifestyle, and these improvements essentially make you “smarter” since enhanced mental faculties lead to enhanced mental performance. According to the Dana Foundation
post_title: the following exercises and activities promote a brain-healthy lifestyle.

ID: The performance of physical activity closely related to cognitive function. There have been countless studies over the past few years that have shown that regular exercise promotes health. Exercise increases the levels of brain chemicals that encourage the growth of nerve cells. The performance of aerobic activity has been linked to enhanced memory skills
post_author: while moderately strenuous physical activity is strongly associated with healthy brain aging. Exercise the mind: When an individual exercises his or her brain by learning new things or pursuing activities that are intellectually stimulating
post_date: brain-cell networks may be strengthened. Recent studies have found that people who engage more frequently in activities that involve significant information processing have a much lower incidence of Alzheimer’s disease. Such activities include reading newspapers
post_date_gmt: playing challenging games like Scrabble® and going to museums. Additionally
post_content: longer formal education is associated with mental sharpness among older people
post_title: possibly because continued learning creates a neural reserve of denser
post_excerpt: stronger nerve-cell connections that increase the brain’s ability to compensate for age-related changes in neural structure and function.

ID: The consumption of a balanced diet that is rich in antioxidants and omega-3 fatty acids has been linked to improved cognitive fitness. Additionally
post_author: a diet that is rich in whole grains such as brown rice and whole wheat bread or pasta supports overall cardiovascular health
post_date: which is closely linked to mental health.

ID: A growing body of evidence suggests that a full night of restful sleep is critical for memory consolidation and ability to retain information. In studies
post_author: people who are deprived of sleep generally score significantly worse on memory and cognitive tests
post_date: and the deficits may not be reversible even after the participants are allowed to sleep.

ID: Scientists are making tremendous progress in studying cognitive fitness and understanding the degree to which you can influence the state of your brain. Although many questions remain
post_author: the hope is to learn how and why lifestyle choices and activities directly affect the brain. For now
post_date: it is encouraging to know that you can do many things every day that may help to improve your cognitive fitness – now and in the future.

Living a healthy life is big on everyone’s radar from getting more sleep, to eating a nutritious diet, and doing enough exercise. But the New Year’s resolution trial period always seems to end at around two weeks. So this post will offer some tips on how to stay in the game for all four quarters and reap the rewards of finishing off a year in the ascension.

Planning to Suceed

One of the first things that individuals should do for a healthy life is plan for it. And while making a to-do list is nice and all, it doesn’t always get it done when it’s time. No, a real plan involves knowing what is holding you back from your health goals at the start and having things in place that keep you going when times get rough. An easy and common obstacle that many people fail to overcome is holiday get-togethers. While Thanksgiving and Christmas are far off, they will inevitably come around meaning that the reverie that prevails with being around family, friends, and food will block out a lot of the discipline that it takes to remain focused on health. Massive amounts of sodium, calories, alcohol, and other things will be consumed by many who feel entitled to being unhealthy, but that shouldn’t be you…and it won’t if you plan.

Don't Undervalue the Short Game

Looking ahead is a way for adults to put themselves in a favorable position. In fact, those who fail or simply don’t bother to look ahead are generally criticized as needing to mature. But to get to tomorrow you must live today. Any change takes time to make into a habit, and with health it takes even longer to see positive outcomes. Instead of giving up or tapering off after an unknown time, individuals should focus their New Year’s health-related resolutions on the day-to-day. If you’ve made a plan to get healthy and know what it takes then completing those objectives everyday will ensure that you get to the end of the year with progress made.

Mindset Determines Trajectory

The biggest pitfall for New Year’s health-related resolutions is the reward aspect. Many people feel like they should reward themselves for doing good. This is an extremely slippery slope as once unhealthy habits—habits that have been formed for years—start gaining acceptance, whether it’s once a year, once a month, or once a day then the doors are open for it to become part of one’s lifestyle. The sacrifice of going without and knowing that the change has lasted one more day should be the reward, and while it is excruciating at first, the longer an individual delays gratification the more likely that delay becomes the reward in and of itself.

The Bottom Line – For Your Health!

As the song in the musical goes, “Change never comes easy.” New Year’s resolutions have been broken by so many people so many times that it has become a farce. This is unacceptable as a resolution requires resolve. If your resolution this year is to live a healthy lifestyle then you must plan ahead, live day-to-day, and let the work you put towards your goals be its own reward.
MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), older adults who are at risk of falling should perform balance exercises at least three days a week. Balance training can be as simple as standing on one foot for a few seconds, and then gradually increasing the length of time for more difficulty. Individuals should begin by holding on to a sturdy chair for support, and in time try it without holding on. From there individuals may progress to standing with one foot in front of the other to alter the base of support, and then shifting their body weight in different directions and alternate lifting the feet from the floor. Other balance exercises include backward walking, sideways walking, heel walking, toe walking and standing from a sitting position. Tai chi, a form of martial arts developed in China, has also been shown to improve balance. While balance training is vital for fall prevention programs, any exercise that preserves bone mass, and improves endurance, muscle strength and flexibility, also helps to prevent falls and related injuries. In fact, exercise, in general, can and should be a part of everyday life for older adults. While the type and level of activity can vary greatly depending on an individual’s abilities, the fact that everyone benefits from some form of exercise is undisputed by medical experts. One of the most noticeable effects of exercise among older adults is an increase in mobility and independence. Exercise increases mobility by decreasing body weight, increasing strength and reducing joint stiffness. As joints experience less pain and an increased range of motion, movements such as walking or performing basic tasks around the house become easier, thus increasing independence.

The Bottom Line—For Your Health!

According to the CDC

post_status: develop a fear of falling. This fear can cause some individuals to limit their activities
comment_status: which leads to reduced mobility and decreased physical fitness
ping_status: which in turn increases their actual risk of falling. Fortunately
post_password: falls and fall-related injuries are not an inevitable part of growing older. Older adults can help maintain their independence and decrease their risk of falling by exercising regularly and focusing on balance and strength training exercises designed to decrease their chances of falling.

Over a series of blog posts, we’re going to explore a relatively overlooked topic: how does one maintain health once initial health goals are met? As the saying goes, getting to the top (becoming healthy) can ultimately be the easy part when all is said and done; staying on top (maintaining one’s health for life) is the hard part. Before we worry about staying at the top, however, let’s get there first. Let’s start by becoming un-unhealthy! It’s no secret that America faces a health problem; the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reports that: “During 2009–2010
post_title: approximately 17% of children and adolescents and 36% of adults were obese.”

post_date: heart disease
post_content: some cancers

ID: <em>“A well–balanced diet with emphasis on reducing and/or eliminating the intake of refined
post_author: processed
post_date: and packaged foods and moving toward an unrefined
post_date_gmt: unprocessed plant–based diet that is centered on fruits
post_content: vegetables
post_excerpt: intact whole grains and legumes.”

post_author: the CDC recommends:

ID: “2 hours and 30 minutes (150 minutes) of moderate-intensity aerobic activity (i.e.
post_author: brisk walking) every week and muscle-strengthening activities on 2 or more days a week that work all major muscle groups (legs
post_date: hips
post_content: abdomen
post_excerpt: shoulders

ID: It would be easy to follow the above guidelines in an ideal scenario

post_date_gmt: it’s all about consistency. If you want to stay healthy then you must commit to it absolutely.

You’ve probably heard or seen the phrase “Please drink responsibly” or have read the studies purporting the benefits of moderate alcohol consumption and thought to yourself
post_title: “I knew a couple of beers wasn’t that bad.”

ID: But to do something in moderation requires one to know what is considered extreme
post_author: and when it comes to alcohol consumption
post_date: considering recent trends
post_date_gmt: what may appear as moderate drinking could quietly be a binge drinking environment in reality.

ID: Alcohol is also known as ethanol
post_author: and is a neurotoxic
post_date: psychedelic chemical compound that is formed by the fermentation of sugars and yeasts. It is absorbed in both the stomach and small intestine where it is metabolized by liver enzymes. When alcohol is broken down and absorbed by the body its properties produce an intoxicating effect on the individual with the effect becoming more pronounced the higher one’s blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level.

ID: The National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) states that
post_author: “A standard drink is any drink that contains about 14 grams of pure alcohol (about 0.6 fluid ounces or 1.2 tablespoons).” This translates to 12 oz of a beverage containing 5 percent alcohol
post_date: 5 oz of a beverage containing 12 percent alcohol
post_date_gmt: and 1.5 oz  of a beverage containing 40 percent alcohol all constituting one “standard drink.” And according to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans
post_content: moderate drinking is up to one standard drink per day for women and up to two standard drinks per day for men. While this may seem easy enough to abide by
post_title: the problem occurs when a standard drink serving (of 12 oz for example) doesn’t come with standard alcohol content for the serving size.

ID: The Health Services at Brown University state that:
<em>“Understanding the rate of metabolism is critical to understanding the effects of alcohol. In general
post_author: the liver can process one ounce of liquor (or one standard drink) in one hour. If you consume more than this
post_date: your system becomes saturated
post_date_gmt: and the additional alcohol will accumulate in the blood and body tissues until it can be metabolized.”

post_author: craft beers “whose sales grew 22 percent to $19.6 billion in 2014 and continued a four-year streak of double digit growth
post_date: is driving a sea change in American palates with heavier doses of alcohol.”

ID: What this means is that Americans crave the type of beer that comes with higher alcohol content
post_author: yet the serving sizes of these craft beers are typically 12 oz. So if you drink a 12 oz beer with an alcohol by volume (ABV) of 10 percent
post_date: then you’ve just had two standard drinks in one sitting and there is roughly 14 grams of pure alcohol floating in your system waiting to be metabolized.

post_author: “binge drinking as a pattern of drinking that brings blood alcohol concentration (BAC) levels to 0.08 g/dL. This typically occurs after 4 drinks for women and 5 drinks for men—in about two hours.” And that heavy drinking is
post_date: “drinking 5 or more drinks on the same occasion on each of 5 or more days in the past 30 days.”

ID: As you may have noticed these higher levels of drinking are defined by BAC and not how many beer bottles you’ve accumulated. For example

post_date_gmt: these two beers would cause your BAC to go up to 0.055g/dL as opposed to 0.027g/dL as it would with two “standard” drinks.

An individual’s genetic makeup has a lot to do with how they live their life: It determines if they will be predisposed to certain behaviors and diseases, and if they will inherit certain traits. Genes are so influential to animals, plants, and microorganisms (which all pass along their genes to their offspring) that the manipulation of them has become an area of great study, and great concern because the consequences of passing on engineered genes have unknown consequences so far.

Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs)

According to the Non-GMO Project
post_title: GMOs “are living organisms whose genetic material has been artificially manipulated in a laboratory through genetic engineering
post_excerpt: or GE.” And while this source is admittedly biased
post_status: there is basis for concern as they go on to state in their FAQ that:

ID: <em>“Most developed nations do not consider GMOs to be safe. In more than 60 countries around the world
post_author: including Australia
post_date: Japan
post_date_gmt: and all of the countries in the European Union
post_content: there are significant restrictions or outright bans on the production and sale of GMOs. In the U.S.
post_title: the government has approved GMOs based on studies conducted by the same corporations that created them and profit from their sale. Increasingly
post_excerpt: Americans are taking matters into their own hands and choosing to opt out of the GMO experiment.”

ID: So why do GMOs persist if they are considered unsafe by many? The answer is that being able to create organisms that have desired traits
post_author: such as crops that resist herbicides and animals that grow larger and faster
post_date: is profitable
post_content: and can lead to scientific breakthroughs
post_title: such as cures for presently incurable diseases. But these benefits come into conflict by purported issues that arise from genetic engineering
post_excerpt: such as more pesticides used on crops and leading to people being more prone to allergies and cancer. However
post_status: there are no conclusive studies that correlate GMOs to these negative claims.

post_author: the natural end result of being able to manipulate the genes of organisms is to be able to do it with people. With that said
post_date: there has been a notable rejection of this potential use of genetic engineering from the Center for Genetics and Society (CGS). With an upcoming International Summit on Human Gene Editing
post_date_gmt: the CGS released an open letter detailing why they have chosen to take this stance. Of particular note are the themes of inequality and the lack of control that will pervade such a scenario once people have control of what genes get passed on.

post_author: “GMO seeds are used to plant 90 percent of corn
post_date: soybeans
post_date_gmt: and cotton grown in the U.S.” This means that Americans are almost guaranteed to have consumed and will continue to consume GMO products. There are proponents on both sides of the GMO debate
post_content: and while there are no conclusive studies connecting GMOs to many of the negative claims that come from those that oppose them
post_title: the fact remains that many prominent countries have made it clear that they want nothing to do with GMOs. On top of that
