post_content: Wearable technology (or “wearables”) have exploded onto the scene and have become the must have item for the holidays. Whether you’re rocking a Fitbit wristband or an Apple Watch, wearables have become a symbol of cool. But when used properly they can also symbolize good health. The selling point for wearables is in the trackers, or put another way in gathering data on particular health metrics. These devices are commonly used to track things such as steps, calories burned, heart rate, and even sleep hours. And when users log-in to their wearables’ website they can view this data on their dashboard. It’s almost like opening up the menu in a video game and viewing your character’s stats, but instead of leveling up in the virtual world you do so in the real one. Pretty cool! However, getting these stats don’t come cheap as this technology is essentially asking people to do what research has been telling them to do for years, which is to eat right and exercise. With that said, wearables have changed the conversation from a lecture to more of a challenge. Wellness programs within organizations have been getting a big push in the last decade as “lifestyle diseases” have become an overwhelming burden being responsible for 7 out of every 10 deaths annually and accounting for 86 percent of healthcare costs
post_title: according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. And since incentives seem to be the way to go for organizations to promote wellness
post_excerpt: tracking health metrics through a popular gizmo is just the medium to achieve this goal.

ID: But employees win out too as health challenges issued by the organization (e.g.
post_author: to reach 10
post_date: 000 daily for a month) allows employees to get creative to meet these goals and gives them the impetus to create their own challenges. Now when individuals go to work and see their co-workers rocking wearables a bond is formed as the shared experience of working towards a health goal creates a sense of unity and belonging. Wearables then become a source of pride
post_date_gmt: but only as far as the motivation to meet health goals is present.

ID: Wearables are uniquely placed in an area where health promotion is needed in an accessible format. However
post_author: novelty is short-lived where lasting change isn’t. In order for individuals and organizations to get the most out of wearables both must rise to the challenge of leveling up their health.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

Does an individual’s outlook on life affect his or her health? Are optimists healthier than pessimists?

Optimism and Health

Numerous studies have shown that individuals who are optimistic tend to live longer and enjoy numerous health benefits including better overall health. Research highlights include:
  • In a study published online in Psychological Bulletin on April 17, 2012, researchers from the Harvard University School of Public Health reviewed data from more than 200 previous studies and found that a positive psychological outlook appears to reduce the risk of heart attacks, strokes and other cardiovascular events. Specifically, factors such as optimism, life satisfaction and happiness are associated with a reduced risk of cardiovascular disease regardless of an individual’s age, socioeconomic status, body weight and smoking history.
  • In a study published in the February 28, 2011 online Archives of Internal Medicine, researchers at Duke University Medical Center tracked the psychological and physical health of hospitalized heart disease patients over a 15-year period. Researchers found that individuals who were optimistic (as determined by survey responses) about their diagnosis, treatment and recovery were more likely to be alive after 15 years than individuals with lower expectations. The researchers noted that the level of optimism displayed by patients did not have to be extreme to have an effect.
Optimists also tend to be adept at managing stress. Research has shown that high levels of stress can exacerbate existing illnesses and contribute to the development of conditions such as heart disease, high blood pressure, depression and obesity. Effective stress management is associated with many health benefits.

What is the Bottom Line?

Many studies have been conducted that support the premise that optimism is associated with better health outcomes, and while it is not yet possible to say that good health necessarily predicts an optimistic outlook or if an optimistic outlook necessarily predicts good health, the results remain the same: when you do good you feel good and vice-versa.
MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.
post_title: What Are The Health Benefits Of Optimism?

post_content: Yoga is a complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) mind–body practice that typically combines physical postures and breathing techniques with meditation or relaxation. There are many styles, intensities and forms of yoga ranging from slow and gentle to athletic and vigorous. Ashtanga: Ashtanga yoga is a fast-paced, intense style of yoga characterized by a highly vigorous, nonstop sequence of poses. It is commonly called \power yoga\" because it demands flexibility
post_title: stamina and strength. Ashtanga yoga is most appropriate for individuals who are already athletic and want to add flexibility
post_excerpt: balance and concentration to their exercise routines.

ID: Bikram: This intensely physical form of yoga is also known as \"hot yoga\" because it is performed in a heated 100–degree room in order to increase flexibility. The Bikram method involves a set sequence of 26 yoga poses and two breathing exercises that is performed twice within a single 90–minute class. Every Bikram class follows the same sequence of 26 poses.

Hatha: Hatha yoga is the most commonly practiced form of yoga in the United States. It emphasizes physical postures or exercises (“asanas”) with the goal of balancing the opposites in one's life. In the U.S.
post_author: Hatha yoga encompasses many of the physical types of yoga and is usually associated with a slower-paced class that includes simple breathing and meditation exercises.

ID: Iyengar: This type of yoga focuses on symmetry
post_author: proper alignment and precise movements. In yoga
post_date: the word \"alignment\" describes the precise way in which the body should be positioned during the performance of each pose in order for the individual to obtain the maximum benefits of the pose and avoid injury. Iyengar yoga usually emphasizes holding poses over a long period of time and encourages the use of props such as yoga blankets
post_date_gmt: blocks and straps in order to bring the body into alignment.

post_author: Jnana Yoga is the practice of knowledge. This form of yoga emphasizes deep contemplation as practitioners seek Jnana (or \"wisdom\") through meditation. The goal is to be ‘one’ with a higher power.

ID: Kundalini: This is one of the more spiritual types of yoga. Although the Kundalini sequences can be physically intense
post_author: this form of yoga emphasizes breathing
post_date: meditation
post_date_gmt: mudras (symbolic gestures) and chanting. It is designed to release a form of energy (“Kundalini”) that is believed by practitioners to be stored at the base of the spine. This type of yoga appeals to those who are up for both mental and physical challenges.

ID: Viniyoga: This type of yoga links breath and movement in flowing exercises that are adapted to each individual. The Viniyoga tradition acknowledges that each individual has unique needs and abilities and believes that yoga practice should
post_author: therefore
post_date: be adapted to fit the particular situation of each person. The long
post_date_gmt: deep stretches of this style of yoga are ideal for beginners and people who want to focus on flexibility
post_content: injury recovery

ID: Vinyasa: Vinyasa yoga can be very diverse. It is usually a more vigorous style of yoga based on the performance of a series of poses that are synchronized with the breath. However
post_author: the pace can vary and there is no one particular sequence that instructors must follow (each instructor will likely teach in a different manner).

ID: These are only a few of the more than 100 different forms of yoga practiced in the United States today.

Depressive disorders are very complex and occur for a variety of reasons. While depression can strike anyone regardless of age, background, socioeconomic status, or gender, depression rates for women are twice as high as those for men. Experts believe that depression occurs as a result of a combination of genetic, biological, environmental, and psychological factors. Genetic Factors: Some types of depression tend to run in families. First–degree relatives (parents, siblings, and children) of individuals with major depressive disorder are two to three times more likely to develop the condition than individuals without a family history. Biological Factors: There are several biological factors that are believed to contribute to depression: neurotransmitter imbalance, hormonal changes such as those related to thyroid problems, menopause, and other conditions, and physical changes to the brain. Environmental Factors: Traumatic events such as the death of a loved one, financial problems, a difficult relationship, or other high-stress situations can lead to depression. Continuous exposure to violence, neglect, abuse or poverty as well as the development of medical conditions such as heart disease, cancer, and HIV can cause stress and make daily life difficult and, in turn, lead to depression among those trying to cope. Psychological Factors: An individual’s vulnerability to depression can also depend on his or her psychological make–up. Specifically, individuals who have low self–esteem, who consistently view themselves and the world with pessimism and/or who are easily overwhelmed by stress appear to be more vulnerable to depression.

What is the Bottom Line?

If you suspect that you or a family member may be suffering from depression, it is imperative to seek care from a licensed mental health professional as soon as possible.
MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_content: Distracted driving\ is the act of driving an automobile while also performing an activity that could divert the driver’s attention away from his or her primary task: driving.

ID: • Using a cell phone or smart phone

post_author: CD player or MP3 player
a website created by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA)
post_date: there are three types of distractions:

ID: • Visual: An individual takes his or her eyes off the road
• Manual: An individual takes his or her hands off of the wheel
• Cognitive: An individual takes his or her mind off of the task of driving
Many distractions fit into more than one category
post_author: and all distractions endanger the driver
post_date: passengers and bystanders. According to the National Safety Council (NSC)
post_date_gmt: distracted driving has joined alcohol and speeding as a leading factor in car accidents that result in fatalities and/or serious injuries.

ID: Using a cell phone (hands–free or handheld)
post_author: a navigation system or any other device while driving requires the brain to multi–task — a process that it cannot perform safely while an individual is driving. In fact
post_date: according to the NSC
post_date_gmt: multi–tasking is a myth. The human brain does not perform two tasks at the same time. Instead
post_content: the brain alternates between one task and another. Since the brain can alternate between tasks very quickly
post_title: people believe they are completing two tasks simultaneously. In reality
post_excerpt: however
post_status: the brain switches its focus between tasks so that only one action is accomplished at a time. In many instances
comment_status: a driver’s response to a sudden unexpected hazard such as another driver’s behavior
ping_status: a work zone or the presence of an animal or object in the roadway is the critical difference between a crash and a close call. When the brain is experiencing an increased workload due to multi–tasking
post_password: the processing of this unexpected information slows and a driver is much less likely to respond to a hazard in time to avoid a crash.

post_author: 24 percent of all motor vehicle crashes involve cell phone use. Drivers who use cell phones have a tendency to \"look at\" but not \"see\" up to 50 percent of the information in their driving environment
post_date: resulting in \"inattention blindness.\" The NHTSA estimates that
post_date_gmt: at any given time during daylight hours
post_content: approximately 800
post_title: 000 Americans are using a cell phone while driving. Texting (or emailing or performing another action with a smart phone) while driving is particularly dangerous because it combines all three categories of distraction simultaneously: visual
post_excerpt: manual and cognitive. When an individual texts
post_status: his or her eyes are off the road for 4.6 seconds. At 55 miles per hour
comment_status: 4.6 seconds is the equivalent of driving the length of a football field.

ID: While texting is a very serious problem
post_author: talking on the phone is just as dangerous. In fact
post_date: statistics show that individuals talking on cell phones are involved in more crashes than individuals who are texting (of course
post_date_gmt: this could also mean that individuals are much more likely to talk on the phone while driving than to text while driving). In 2010
post_content: an estimated 160
post_title: 000 car accidents involved drivers who were texting or emailing
post_excerpt: while 1.1 million crashes involved drivers who were talking on cell phones.

ID: According to a recent AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety survey
post_author: 83 percent of respondents said that drivers using cell phones is a \"serious\" or \"extremely serious\" problem. In spite of this
post_date: more than half of the respondents admitted to talking on a cell phone while driving during the previous 30 days. This behavior was performed \"often\" or \"very often\" by 17 percent of respondents. Unfortunately
post_date_gmt: even when people are aware of the risks and dangers of a particular action
post_content: they may not easily change their behaviors.

ID: Additional data regarding the dangers of using a cell phone while driving is extensive. According to Distraction.gov:
• Distracted driving was reported to be a factor in 11 percent of fatal car accidents involving drivers under the age of 20.
• Individuals who text while driving are 23 times more likely to be involved in a car accident.
• Drivers under the age of 25 are 2 to 3 times more likely than older drivers to send text messages or emails while driving.
• Forty percent of American teenagers say that they have been in a car when the driver used a cell phone in a way that put people in danger.
• Drivers who use hand–held devices are four times more likely to get into crashes serious enough to injure themselves.
• Headset cell phone use is not substantially safer than hand–held use.
• Driving while using a cell phone reduces the amount of brain activity associated with driving by 37 percent.
Accidents caused by distracted driving are preventable. Distracted driving does not just happen
post_author: it is a choice — a choice that causes thousands of needless injuries and deaths each year. The most effective way to prevent accidents caused by distracted driving is for individuals to take responsibility for their actions and focus only on the road when driving.
there are individuals who will continue to engage in dangerous driving behavior and additional methods must be used as deterrents. According to the NHTSA
post_date: High Visibility Enforcement (HVE) is one such method. With HVE
post_date_gmt: police officials have a strong visual presence in a given area and are proactive in the enforcement of laws related to distracted driving. When the perceived risk of getting caught by law enforcement increases
post_content: the likelihood that people will engage in unsafe driving behavior decreases. Along with education and personal responsibility
post_title: HVE (along with related laws and consequences) has been shown to be an effective method of deterring distracted driving and reducing highway traffic fatalities.

post_author: it is worth noting that cell phone use is not the only form of distracted driving. Drivers face many distractions behind the wheel. Every time that an individual takes his or her focus off of the road
post_date: he or she puts lives in danger. An accident takes only one split second and the consequences can be devastating.

ID: To see the devastation that distracted driving can cause firsthand
post_author: please visit Distraction.gov. YOU are the first line of defense against distracted driving. Turn off your cell phone when you get behind the wheel and do not engage in any activity that distracts you from the task of driving. Additionally
post_date: if the driver of a vehicle that you are a passenger in is engaged in a distracted driving behavior
post_date_gmt: inform the driver that you do not feel safe. The life that you save may be your own."

additional aspects of a family health history that may indicate an increased risk of disease include:

It is important to remember that a family health history reflects more than just shared genes; it often also reflects a shared environment

post_author: maintaining an active lifestyle

post_title: and not smoking are behaviors that have been proven to be essential to a long and healthy life. Physicians can address these behaviors with patients and both parties can then discuss related changes
post_excerpt: opportunities and obstacles.

post_author: there are a significant number of illnesses

The information age can broadly be defined by the famous Steve Jobs quote about “…standing at the intersection of computers and humanism.” This is to say that the prevalence of data processing machines in a society that bonds through the passing of information is where we are now, and will be for the foreseeable future. While the ability to communicate and collaborate instantly across vast distances has been a boon, the access this has granted us to each other and to large data stores has allowed for a certain issue to arise: How do people with limited working memory behave when their lives have been integrated with machines which have unlimited recall?

What is Working Memory?

Working memory is the mechanism that allows individuals to recall and organize critical pieces of information, usually simultaneously, so that said information can be applied to a certain task. A common example used to illustrate working memory is mental arithmetic where a person hears two numbers and must add, subtract, multiply, or divide these numbers in their head and produce an answer. As the numbers grow larger, the ability for the individual to process this data and generate an accurate solution diminishes. This example can be contrasted with a computer which can take exponentially large numbers and perform calculations on them instantly. In the APA’s “A workout for working memory
post_title: ” two different theories regarding the limits of working memory were presented. On the one hand you had the theory of working memory being limited to seven different pieces of information at one time (such as recalling up to seven digits in a sequence)
post_excerpt: with anything greater having to be chunked (e.g.
post_status: dividing a 10-digit number into chunks of five) for recall. This theory was contrasted with the idea that individuals can only retain one item in working memory
comment_status: and the “n-back” test was employed to prove this. The n-back test

ID: <em>“The participants [in the task] read a series of numbers
post_author: presented one at a time on a computer screen. In the easiest version of the task
post_date: the computer presents a new digit
post_date_gmt: and then prompts participants to recall what number immediately preceded the current one. More difficult versions might ask participants to recall what number appeared two
post_content: three or four digits ago.”

post_author: the recall times varied when recalling the previous digit in a sequence and recalling the digit that was presented four sequences ago. In the end
post_date: however
post_date_gmt: the article revealed that a study was able to improve recall times after participants practiced the n-back test for 10 hours in a five day span
post_content: meaning that working memory can be improved. But is there a cost?

ID: In a study found on the National Institute for Biotechnology Information
post_author: researchers utilized the stress placed on individuals during the n-back test and monitored subsequent cognitive performance. The results were interesting. As you can imagine
post_date: the recall times among the individuals increased as they were tasked with recalling numbers further back in sequence; however
post_date_gmt: what happened when individuals had to recall numbers four sequences back and then were asked to recall a number only two sequences back? The study finds that:

ID: “Overloading the working memory system with a high-load 4-back task induced a significant decline in subsequent working memory function and robust decreases in brain activity in various regions including relatively large areas of the pre-frontal cortex.”
With so much information being consumed by individuals at one time (count how many tabs you have open in your internet browser)
post_author: it can be argued that many people place high-loads on their working memory at a pretty consistent rate. On top of that
post_date: information consumption and processing doesn’t only happen at work. As these high-loads of information recall have been shown to have a negative effect on cognitive performance
post_date_gmt: individuals should try doing one thing at a time.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider.

post_author: Working Memory in the Information Age
post_date: Working memory is the mechanism that allows individuals to recall and organize critical pieces of information, usually simultaneously, so that said information can be applied to a certain task.
post_content: open

A culture of health in the workplace is critical as most of us spend a significant portion of our lives at work, and the unhealthy behaviors we practice in the office (e.g., inactivity, poor nutrition, poor stress management) can have a profound impact on our overall health.‘Workplace wellness’ has long been a buzzword in the media and a hot topic around the water cooler. In recent years, however, more and more companies are getting serious about the issue and are offering wellness programs to address employee health and wellbeing. In June of this year, National Employee Wellness Month – a campaign to help “business leaders learn how companies successfully engage employees in healthy lifestyles”- had over 200 sponsors. Workplace wellness programs are a win-win for labor and business. By avoiding disease and catching problems before they develop into chronic medical conditions
post_title: employees improve their lives and employers save on medical expense and gain productivity from less sick leave.  In fact
post_excerpt: according to a Harvard University study
post_status: “medical costs fall about $3.27 for every dollar spent on wellness programs
comment_status: and absentee day costs fall by about $2.73 for every dollar spent.”

ID: A recent study by Rand Corp. revealed that about half of all businesses in America have some form of company-sponsored wellness activity. Larger corporations include broad wellness programming in their employee benefits package. Benefits managers across industries understand the appeal of a workplace wellness program to attract quality candidates and retain staff. A discounted gym membership or a granola bar in the vending machine will no longer suffice to enlist top talent. Workers will not be satisfied with a nutritious recipe in the monthly newsletter or daily email with “good living” platitudes. Employees have come to expect a complete wellness program offering
post_author: and forward-thinking business leaders understand that a productive workforce requires a healthy working environment.

ID: Now that the idea of workplace wellness has become widely accepted
post_author: ‘wellness’ needs to move from a catch-all phrase to a sophisticated approach to preventive healthcare in which employer and employee embrace and operate within the same culture of health.

ID: MEDICAL DISCLAIMER: The information is not intended to constitute medical advice and is not a substitute for consultation with a physician or other health care provider. Individuals with specific complaints should seek immediate consultation from their personal physicians.

post_author: Workplace Wellness Creates Healthy Business
post_date: Workplace wellness programs are a win-win for employer and employee.
post_content: open

Proving that red is always in fashion, EHE International, a national provider of comprehensive physical exams celebrating its centennial in 2013, is commemorating the 10th anniversary of its Red Dress Heart Health Awareness Campaign.

Red Dress Campaign was created in 2003 to promote National Wear Red Day® and raise awareness about the prevalence of heart disease - the #1 killer of women. The centerpiece of the Campaign is the EHE International Red Dress photo.

This year's photo, which features twenty-eight EHE International women wearing stunning red evening gowns, was taken in front of the \Rhythms of Infinity\" wall at 30 Rockefeller Plaza and will be on display in a window at 10 Rockefeller Plaza throughout February.

ID: The window will also highlight a decade of EHE International's support of this very important women's health issue.\"As a national leader in preventive healthcare
post_author: EHE International is dedicated to reminding women to protect their heart health and take action before heart disease strikes\" said Deborah McKeever
post_date: president of EHE International.

ID: \"Many people think that heart disease predominantly affects men. For 100 years
post_author: we have taken a proactive approach to preventing heart disease among both men and women. While it is never too late to make changes to prevent and control the risk factors for heart disease
post_date: the earlier in life that a woman commits to healthy living complemented by regular annual examinations and age and health appropriate screening tests

ID: National Wear Red Day® promotes wearing red as a symbol
post_author: and provides an opportunity for men and women to unite in support of this life-saving awareness movement.In addition to the annual Red Dress photo

<span style=\font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\"><strong>NEW YORK
post_excerpt: 2015) − EHE International
post_status: the recognized leader in preventive healthcare
comment_status: today announced the appointment of Roy Ramthun as chief of policy & regulatory affairs. Ramthun brings more than 25 years of healthcare policy experience to his new role having previously served as a healthcare policy advisor for the George W. Bush Administration in 2003
ping_status: where he led the U.S. Treasury Department’s implementation of health savings accounts (HSAs) and spearheaded Medicare Part D (or the Medicare prescription drug benefit ).

ID: “We welcome Roy’s experience and leadership to the EHE community
post_author: ” said Deborah McKeever
post_date: president and COO of EHE International. “In his new role as chief of policy & regulatory affairs
post_date_gmt: he will be responsible for leveraging EHE’s comprehensive preventive healthcare experience with his own public policy experience to deliver effectvie healthcare strategies to businesses and executives. His experience will play a pivotal role in extending our track record of innovation
post_content: while helping us grow and adapt to the changing healthcare landscape. Roy’s leadership will help ensure that we continue to provide a high-level of quality and service
post_title: which have been our hallmark for more than 100 years.”

ID: He has previously served on the staff of the U.S. Senate Committee of Finance and the U.S. Health Care Financing Administration
post_author: now known as the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. He also spent eight years with Humana Inc. and two years leading the West Health Policy Center.

ID: Ramthun holds a master’s degree in public health from the University of North Carolina and a bachelor’s degree from the University of Michigan.
“I believe the way EHE provides preventive healthcare is a model for the nation
post_author: ” said Ramthun. “We could do much as a country to improve patients’ use of preventive services
post_date: especially for those Americans at risk for costly chronic diseases and conditions.”

<span style=\font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\"><strong>NEW YORK
post_excerpt: 2015) − A new study titled “Using Google Street View to Assess Environmental Contributions to Pedestrian-Injury Risk
post_status: ” which collected and examined data of 532 intersections across all five boroughs in New York City using Google Street View has pioneered a groundbreaking method for researching pedestrian-injury risk factors on a much larger scale and at far lower cost than on-site inspections.

ID: The study was conducted by Andrew Rundle
post_author: who serves on the Medical Advisory Board of EHE International
post_date: a New York City-based consultancy in preventive medicine
post_content: Stephen Mooney
post_title: a doctoral student in epidemiology at the Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health.

ID: “This study and others that I hope will replicate and build upon have the potential to prompt public officials to continue to approve and fund infrastructure improvements to design better streets. Using this information
post_author: we can help save untold numbers of lives and greatly reduce the number of serious injuries
post_date: ” said Deborah McKeever

ID: The study’s unique methodology was aimed at ascertaining the feasibility of using information technology to make the process of analyzing intersections more efficient using less manpower
post_author: ultimately enabling vastly more intersections to be analyzed for safety hazards. “If you’re going to visit each intersection in person to collect data
post_date: it’s essentially difficult to study injury risk factors on a large scale in one city or across multiple cities within the budget of a typical research study. This approach accelerates research on how to improve neighborhoods to keep pedestrians safe” said Mooney.

ID: Using collision data from public databases and other statistics the researchers identified nine underlying characteristics between the causes of traffic deaths and injuries and there they are happening.
The study found that the count of pedestrian injuries at intersections was associated with the presence (or absence) of marked crosswalks
post_author: pedestrian signals
post_date: nearby visual advertising (billboards)
post_date_gmt: and bus stops. Other metrics analyzed included curb cuts
post_content: sidewalks
post_excerpt: and “traffic calming devices
post_status: ” such as curb extensions and speed bumps.

ID: Rundle added that a further benefit of intersection-safety hazards thus being identified and remediated would be that pedestrians would not only be safer
post_author: but also feel safer. “That perception of increased safety from traffic might in turn encourage more outdoor physical activity
post_date: with consequent physical and mental health benefits

ID: Expenditures on pedestrian-safety infrastructure upgrades may prove to be a particularly cost-effective way to improve public health. That’s no small consideration
post_author: given that an estimated 70
post_date: 000 pedestrians were injured or killed by motor vehicles in the United States in 2013 alone. Independent of the Rundle-Mooney study
post_date_gmt: New York City has developed plans to improve pedestrian safety citywide. Under N.Y. Mayor Bill de Blasio’s ambitious “Vision Zero” initiative for ending traffic deaths and injuries on the city’s streets
post_content: the Big Apple has installed some 1
post_title: 500 pedestrian signals and re-engineered dozens of roads and intersections.

ID: Rundle and Mooney’s findings are to be published in the American Journal of Public Health
post_author: The full report can be read online ahead of print at http://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/abs/10.2105/AJPH.2015.302978.

NEW YORK CITY (March 1, 2014)—The Colon Cancer Challenge Foundation (CCCF), a New York-based nonprofit dedicated to reducing colorectal cancer incidence and death throughout the United States, is making it easier to talk and learn about colorectal cancer with the Super-Awesome Colon-O-Tron, an interactive, educational game in the Rockefeller Plaza window. The window was generously donated by EHE International to make people aware of the disease and help them get educated and take action. The Super-Awesome Colon-O-Tron is making colorectal cancer something people will talk about with an eye-catching game encouraging people to stay lean, eat clean and get screened. The Colon-O-Tron will be in the 155-foot window at 10 Rockefeller Plaza through March 31. \Many people don't realize colorectal cancer is the second leading cancer killer of women and men in this country or how preventable and treatable it is. We're thrilled EHE International would partner with us to help everyone who passes through Rockefeller Plaza become better educated about this disease during Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month
post_excerpt: CCCF executive director.

ID: The Colon Cancer Challenge Foundation began in 2004 with its signature event
post_author: the Colon Cancer Challenge 5k run/walk
post_date: and now begins its second decade by reaching out to more people than ever through the window and two Challenges in 2014.

ID: It is because colorectal cancer is so under recognized as a health risk in America that EHE International's donation is crucial to support bringing awareness and education to the cause.
\"We are happy to do our part to help raise awareness on colon cancer and partner with the Colon Cancer Challenge Foundation
post_author: \" said Deb McKeever
post_date: president of EHE International.

post_author: the agency that designed the Colon-O-Tron
post_date: got involved after one of their employees was diagnosed with colon cancer in her 20s. Her involvement with the Colon Cancer Challenge Foundation spurred their commitment to fighting colorectal cancer.

ID: For more information about the Super-Awesome Colon-O-Tron
post_author: visit colonotron.org/play. To learn about the Colon Cancer Challenge and the CCCF
post_date: visit www.coloncancerchallenge.org.

ID: The Colon Cancer Challenge Foundation (coloncancerchallenge.org) is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization registered in New York state and listed by the Federal IRS as a public charity dedicated to reducing colorectal cancer incidence and death. Its mission includes supporting research into the causes and cures for colorectal cancer
post_author: increasing public awareness
post_date: educating the public about the importance of early detection and forming strategic partnerships in the fight against colorectal cancer.

NEW YORK, NY (March 14, 2016) − EHE International, the recognized leader in preventive medicine, today congratulates Alfred I. Neugut, M.D., MPH, Ph.D., on his receipt of the Joseph F. Fraumeni Jr. Distinguished Achievement Award. Dr. Neugut accepted the award from the American Society of Preventive Oncology yesterday at ASPO’s 40th anniversary meeting in Columbus, Ohio. “Dr. Neugut is one of the nation’s leading cancer experts, and we’re proud to have him as the director of the EHE Medical Advisory Board,” said Deborah McKeever, president and COO of EHE International. “Alfred deserves this award, and we join the American Society of Preventive Oncology in thanking him for his contributions to cancer research and prevention.” Neugut is the Myron M. Studner professor of cancer research and professor of medicine and epidemiology at Columbia University; associate director for population science and leader of the Prevention, Control and Disparities Program for the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center at Columbia; and co-director of the Cancer Prevention Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital. The ASPO Distinguished Achievement Award is named for Dr. Joseph F. Fraumeni Jr., the former director of the National Cancer Institute’s Division of Cancer Epidemiology and Genetics. About EHE International Since 1913, EHE International has been dedicated to helping organizations improve health care, reduce costs and manage risks. Its Centers of Excellence in Preventive Healthcare protocols are specifically designed for early detection of preventable disease and associated risk factors. The exam is supported by a full year of post-exam management and care coordination that includes personal health coaching, in-network physician referrals, patient engagement and resources to support population health management. EHE International is the only preventive healthcare program available nationally. Its clinically based educational and social-engagement platforms are the preferred choice among America’s leading employers. EHE provides each client with free, HIPAA-compliant access to the health outcomes data it collects. Through our independent research advisory board, EHE provides analytical benchmark data that helps employers gauge the overall health status and culture of their organizations. For more information, contact EHE International, 10 Rockefeller Plaza, 4th Floor, New York, NY 10020; call 212.332.3700; or visit eheintl.com."

post_content: NEW YORK, NY (February 1, 2016) − EHE International will bring attention to prime of life neurodegeneration to hundreds of thousands of people by featuring CurePSP in a window display at Rockefeller Center in New York City throughout February. Prime of life neurodegeneration comprises a spectrum of untreatable, fatal brain diseases that typically strike during middle age when people often have families, careers and active lives. More than 150,000 people in the U.S. alone are affected by these diseases.

ID: “We are excited to be featured at this landmark location that is seen by people from around the world every day
post_author: ” said David Kemp
post_date: President of CurePSP. “This visibility will help us to raise awareness of neurodegeneration
post_date_gmt: which is the great healthcare crusade of the 21st century. We are very grateful to EHE International for the opportunity.”

ID: “EHE International is delighted to help CurePSP gain attention for this important cause
post_author: and the efforts which are underway to find a treatment or cure for these devastating diseases
post_date: ” added Deborah McKeever

ID: The CurePSP display shows a woman’s silhouette with a crumpled paper “brain” representing a primary cause of prime of life neurodegeneration
post_author: the chain-reaction “misfolding” of brain proteins. Viewers will also see a link (www.unfoldpsp.org) where they can learn more about prime of life neurodegeneration.

ID: CurePSP is the leading advocacy organization for prime of life neurodegenerative diseases including progressive supranuclear palsy
post_author: corticobasal degeneration
post_date: multiple system atrophy
post_content: frontotemporal dementia and chronic traumatic encephalopathy. The foundation provides patient and family services
post_excerpt: and research funding. Findings from its research will likely have implications for other common neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s.

ID: CurePSP is the leading nonprofit advocacy organization focused on prime of life neurodegeneration – a spectrum of fatal brain disorders that often strike during a person’s most productive and rewarding years. Currently there is no treatment or cure for these disorders which affect more than 150
post_author: 000 people in the U.S. alone. Since it was founded in 1990
post_date: CurePSP has funded more than 160 research studies primarily in progressive supranuclear palsy and the related disease corticobasal degeneration
post_date_gmt: and is the leading source of information and support for patients and their families
post_content: other caregivers
post_excerpt: doctors
post_status: and allied healthcare professionals. CurePSP is based in Timonium
ping_status: with an office in New York City. Please visit http://www.psp.org for more information.

NEW YORK, April 15, 2013 -- EHE International, a nationally recognized leader in preventive medicine and annual physical exams, celebrates its 100th anniversary in 2013 with the release of a new book, 100 Years of Preventive Health: The History of EHE International. The book chronicles the company's rich history of helping people live longer, healthier lives. \For 100 years
post_title: EHE International has been the standard-bearer in preventive health
post_excerpt: \" said Deborah McKeever
post_status: EHE president. \"This book is a testament to EHE's lasting legacy in health care. Over the last century
comment_status: our organization has adapted to changing times but has never wavered from our core mission: the conservation of human life and the promotion of health and longevity by the systematic application of medical science for the early detection of life-threatening disease through annual physical exams.\"

ID: When Harold A. Ley and Irving Fisk launched EHE International (formerly known as the The Life Extension Institute) in 1913
post_author: Americans had an average life expectancy of just 47 years
post_date: and X-rays and surgical anesthesia were poised to revolutionize health care. Through the Great Depression
post_date_gmt: two World Wars and 17 presidents – including one who became the chairman of the EHE board
post_content: President William Howard Taft ; and one who followed the EHE diet
post_title: President Woodrow Wilson – stunning advancements in technology and science have completely changed the way that health care is delivered. But 100 years and millions of exams later
post_excerpt: EHE remains the leading advocate for preventive health and the leading provider of physical examinations that identify disease and the development of health risks in the earliest and most treatable or manageable stages.

ID: \"100 Years of Preventive Health: The History of EHE International tells the story of EHE and preventive care in the U.S. with pictures and captivating narrative that highlight how far we've come as a country and the role EHE has played along the way
post_author: \" said McKeever.

ID: As highlighted in 100 Years of Preventive Health: The History of EHE International
post_author: EHE was among the first in the U.S. to:

ID: <li>Identify that 23 percent of draftees at the end of World War I were unfit for service due to preventable health conditions that could have been avoided through diet and oral hygiene (Dr. Fisk
<li>Discover the link between smoking tobacco and chronic diseases such as heart ailments and cancer 40 years before the U.S. Surgeon General warned of the dangers of smoking (1921
post_author: What it Costs to Smoke Tobacco).

ID: <li>Examine lost employee productivity due to preventable illness
post_author: concluding that lost man-hours were enough to complete 400 destroyers for the U.S. Navy (1944
post_date: Dr. Johnson).

ID: <li>Expand public health discussions to include sexual health
post_author: including the first look at the [sexual] habits of gay Americans (Dr. Harry J. Johnson

ID: <li>Declare the full body scan to be an unsafe preventive screening tool three years before Columbia University found that the amount of radiation in one full body scan was equivalent to the amount of radiation received by Hiroshima survivors 1.5 miles from the atom bomb blast core (2001
post_author: EHE Medical Advisory Board).

ID: <li>Discover that the incidence of colorectal cancer is as prevalent among adults aged 40 to 49 as it is among adults aged 50 and above (2008
post_author: EHE Medical Advisory Board).

ID: <li>Discover the correlation between heart disease and obesity risk factors due to frequent travel among executives (2011
post_author: Dr. Andrew Rundle ).
EHE will continue its tradition in historic research by publishing the largest study to date on the effect that a spouse or partner's health has on the other. The study will draw data from 6
post_date: 000 couples.

ID: \"100 Years of Preventive Health: The History of EHE International is our tribute to the men and women of yesteryear who set forth the EHE mission and led us to where we are today. As we enter our next century
post_author: we pledge to honor and preserve that great tradition
post_date: \" said McKeever.

ID: To learn more or to request a copy of 100 Years of Preventive Health: The History of EHE International please visit us online at http://eheintl.com/ehe-book/.

Drexel University College of Medicine has been designated a Vanguard National Center of Excellence in Women's Health by the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services

NEW YORK, NY (October 2, 2014)—EHE International, the recognized leader in preventive medicine and annual physical exams, today released this statement to congratulate AMERICAN Cast Iron Pipe Company and BP America for receiving the 2014 C. Everett Koop National Health Award, which recognizes population health promotion and improvement programs. “The C. Everett Koop National Health Awards is an opportunity to honor companies who understand the critical correlation between employee health and company performance. AMERICAN Cast Iron Pipe Company and BP America have demonstrated their commitment to employee wellbeing with innovative wellness programs that not only improve the overall health of the company, but also advance a culture of health for others to emulate. As a proud supporter of The Health Project, EHE International congratulates this year’s winners for their role in raising awareness of the tremendous benefits of building a cost-effective wellness program that makes employee wellbeing the cornerstone of business success.” The Koop Award is presented by The Health Project, a private-public organization formed to bring about critical attitudinal and behavioral changes in the American healthcare system, principally through the promotion of programs with demonstrated effectiveness in influencing personal health habits and the cost effective use of healthcare services. Named for the late Surgeon General of the United States, who was a founding honorary chairman of The Health Project, the C. Everett Koop National Health Award recognizes organizations whose health programs have a proven record of improving employee health and reducing healthcare costs. EHE International is a sponsor of The Health Project. This year’s recipients will be honored at the Health Enhancement Research Organization (HERO) Forum in San Diego, CA. Dee Edington, Ph.D., will deliver the keynote address at the Forum to discuss his vision of “Shared Values, Shared Results,” which looks at how the health management strategies in organizations have helped drive top-line revenue over time by encouraging meaningful work. About EHE International  Since 1913, EHE International has been the recognized leader in preventive medicine. Its clinical protocols are specifically designed for early detection of preventable disease and associated risk factors, supported by robust personal coaching and health management tools and resources. EHE International is the oldest and largest preventive medicine specialist and its clinically based educational and social engagement platforms are the preferred choice among America's leading employers. For more information, visit eheintl.com.

New York, NY (October 1, 2013) — Throughout the month of October, visitors to Rockefeller Center in the heart of midtown Manhattan will get an unexpected lesson on Alzheimer's disease, the sixth-leading cause of death in the U.S. Thanks to the generosity of EHE International, a recognized national leader in employee and individual preventive healthcare plans, a 115-square foot exhibit containing important information about the disease and the free services offered by the New York City Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association will be on view in the EHE display window at 10 Rockefeller Plaza from October 1, 2013 until October 31, 2013. This display features the Alzheimer's Association \Celebrity Champions\" video
post_title: a three minute photo montage showcasing celebrities who support the Alzheimer's Association including David Hyde Pierce
post_excerpt: Bradley Cooper
to_ping: Wayne Brady and the cast of \"Friday Night Lights\" among others.

ID: Other display panels include important information about where to go for help
post_author: and startling statistics – including the fact that every 68 seconds someone in the United States develops Alzheimer's disease; by mid-century
post_date: it will be every 33 seconds. Currently
post_date_gmt: there are more than 5 million Americans with Alzheimer's and more than 250
post_content: 000 live in the five boroughs of New York City. The display urges anyone who needs help or information to visit the Chapter's web site at www.alz.org/nyc or to call the 24-Hour helpline at 800-272-3900.

ID: \"EHE International is happy to donate the window in Rockefeller Center for the month of October to the Alzheimer's Association. Our goal is to empower the Alzheimer's Association by helping them enlighten
post_author: inform and raise awareness for the disease\" stated Deborah McKeever
post_date: President of EHE International.

ID: \"Alzheimer's is a disease that doesn't discriminate. Whether you have the disease
post_author: know or care for someone with it
post_date: or are a part of the medical community
post_date_gmt: the disease affects us all in some way
post_content: \" said Lou-Ellen Barkan
post_title: President and CEO of the Alzheimer's Association
post_excerpt: New York City Chapter. \"We want to thank EHE International for the very generous donation of their display window and for giving us this opportunity to reach thousands and thousands of people who may need our help.\"

ID: The New York City Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association offers many resources for people with Alzheimer's and their caregivers. Among these are:

post_author: information and counseling for people in the early stages of Alzheimer's;

ID: • A 24-hour Helpline with assistance in more than 170 languages;
<li>The MedicAlert ® Foundation + Alzheimer's Association Safe Return ® Program
post_author: a nationwide wanderer's safety program that assists in the safe and timely return of individuals with dementias who wander and become lost.

ID: For more information about the New York City Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association go to www.alz.org/nyc.

post_author: New York City Chapter is to create and promote comprehensive and humane care for persons with Alzheimer's disease and related disorders
post_date: to provide support for their families and professional caregivers
post_date_gmt: and to eliminate Alzheimer's disease through the advancement of research. The Chapter meets this mission in the community through increasing public awareness
post_content: providing education

NEW YORK, NY (June 1, 2014) — One in three Americans is at risk for kidney disease. This month, the National Kidney Foundation (NKF) is asking visitors to Rockefeller Center if they are the one. Thanks to a donation from preventative healthcare company EHE International, during the month of June the NKF will use a high-profile window display space at 10 Rockefeller Center to promote kidney disease awareness. \Most people never think about kidney disease and yet 73 million Americans are at risk. Anyone who is over 60 or who has high blood pressure
post_title: diabetes or a family history of kidney failure

comment_status: NKF Chief Executive Officer. “The message is simple. If you are at risk

post_author: simple message to passersby and features kidney disease statistics and ways to support the awareness

New York, N.Y. – February 1, 2012 – The women of EHE International, the leader in preventive healthcare since 1913, are at it again in their red dresses to raise awareness for heart disease. This year, the ladies in red are joined for the first time by the men of EHE International to bring attention to National Wear Red Day. The group comes together for the ninth consecutive year to shed light on the number one killer of Americans: heart disease. The fashionable red attire of the employees symbolizes the importance of maintaining a healthy heart. This year's photo captures the beauty of a range of people promoting the cause in the elegant New York Palace Hotel. The setting complements the glamour of EHE International employees as they gather to highlight the importance of proper care for their hearts. \With one in every three deaths being caused by heart disease
post_title: it was important to add men into the equation
post_excerpt: \" said Deborah McKeever
comment_status: of this year's Red Dress campaign. \"Wearing a red dress or red tie is a powerful first step that men and women can take to show they are taking responsibility for their heart health.\" McKeever said that EHE International encourages all its employees regardless of gender to celebrate the campaign by wearing an item of red clothing on February 3rd.

ID: February 3 is National Wear Red Day®. This day promotes the Red Dress symbol and provides an opportunity for everyone to unite in a life-saving awareness movement by showing off a favorite red dress
post_author: shirt
post_date: or tie.

NEW YORK, December 1, 2012 – A window display at Rockefeller Plaza this month will give the gift of hope this holiday season to children fighting cancer across the country by raising awareness and educating the public. The display was created to shed a light on the state of childhood cancer and empower the general public to make a difference in the life of children battling cancer. The window space at 10 Rockefeller Plaza, donated by EHE International, will house the display throughout December. Cancer is the leading cause of death by disease in children in the United States. Each year in the United States approximately 13,500 children and adolescents are diagnosed with cancer. Over 40,000 children and adolescents are currently in treatment for cancer today. The average age of death for a child with cancer is 8, causing a child to lose approximately 69 years of expected life; yet, only 4 percent of the National Cancer Institute's federal budget goes to childhood cancer research. Dena Sherwood, Founder of Arms Wide Open Childhood Cancer Foundation (AWOCCF) says, \We are so thankful to EHE International for giving us this opportunity to raise awareness for these amazingly brave and strong children.\" She explains
post_title: \"Awareness is the key and the first step to putting an end to childhood cancer. Through awareness
post_excerpt: the funding will come; the funding to provide trials and less toxic treatments to these children
post_status: the treatments they so desperately need in order to survive.\" It is AWOCCF's goal to raise awareness and educate the public
comment_status: in order to be a voice for children fighting cancer so that they may receive the greatest gift this holiday season ... HOPE!

ID: \"EHE International is happy to donate the window in Rockefeller Center for the month of December to the Arms Wide Open Childhood Cancer Foundation. Together we hope to enlighten
post_author: inform and educate the public about the specific needs of the over 46 children that are diagnosed every school day with cancer
post_date: \" said Deborah McKeever

Arms Wide Open was founded in 2009 by Dena Sherwood

New York – March 2, 2012 – A window display at Rockefeller Plaza this month will emphasize the lifesaving value of colorectal cancer screening, reaching almost 250,000 people per day with this important public health message. A collaboration between the Entertainment Industry Foundation's National Colorectal Cancer Research Alliance (EIF's NCCRA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)'s Screen for Life: National Colorectal Cancer Action Campaign, the display provides facts about colorectal cancer screening to dispel common misconceptions that might cause people to forego a screening test. The window space at 10 Rockefeller Plaza, donated by EHE International, will house the display throughout March, National Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month. Of cancers that affect both men and women, colorectal cancer is the second-leading cancer killer in the U.S., yet is highly curable when caught early and often entirely preventable with screening. EIF's NCCRA, co-founded by Katie Couric, works to raise awareness about the importance of getting screened and supports groundbreaking research to improve the way colon cancer is prevented, detected and treated. \EHE International is happy to donate the window in Rockefeller Center for the month of March to the EIF National Colorectal Cancer Research Alliance. Together we hope to inform and raise awareness about the importance of screenings
post_excerpt: President of EHE International.

ID: \"While it's very gratifying that the colorectal cancer death rate has been declining steadily over the past few years
post_author: there's still so much to be done
post_date: \" said Lisa Paulsen
post_date_gmt: Entertainment Industry Foundation President and CEO. \"About one-third of adults who should be screened for colon cancer have not been
post_content: so we're always grateful for opportunities like this to spread the message that screening saves lives.\"

New York – May 3, 2012 – Rockefeller Plaza Window Display Educates Public About Tuberous Sclerosis Complex A window display at Rockefeller Plaza this month will help educate the general public about a devastating and rare genetic disease called tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). The display, created by the Tuberous Sclerosis Alliance, briefly describes TSC and highlights the very first TSC Global Awareness Day, which occurs May 15. The window space at 10 Rockefeller Plaza, donated by EHE International, will house the display throughout May, National TSC Awareness Month. TSC is a genetic disease that causes tumors to form in vital organs, primarily the brain, eyes, heart, kidney, liver, skin and lungs. It is also the leading genetic cause of both epilepsy and autism. Around 1 million people worldwide are known to have TSC, with approximately 50,000 in the United States. \EHE International is happy to donate the window in Rockefeller Center for the month of May to the TS Alliance. Both organizations hope the display helps increase awareness of this devastating disease
post_excerpt: President of EHE International.

ID: \"There is currently no cure for TSC
post_author: \" explained Kari Luther Rosbeck
post_date: TS Alliance President and CEO. \"However
post_date_gmt: recent research discoveries and the approval of new drugs to treat the disease mean we are making strides to improve the lives of everyone touched by TSC. But much work remains
post_content: and we are grateful to EHE International for helping us tell our story.\"

post_author: the TS Alliance is the only national organization dedicated to finding a cure for TSC
post_date: while improving the lives of those affected through the stimulation and sponsorship of research; the development of programs
post_date_gmt: support services and resource information; and the development and implementation of public and professional education programs designed to heighten awareness of TSC. For more information

New York, N.Y. – April 22, 2013 – EHE International, a nationally-recognized leader in preventive medicine and annual physical exams, today announced that EHE President and COO, Deborah McKeever, has joined the Women's Committee for Hope, a group of female leaders committed to advancing the mission of the American Cancer Society's Hope Lodge in NYC. The Women's Committee for Hope launched in October 2012 to support Hope Lodge NYC, a lodging and support center in midtown Manhattan for cancer patients and their caregivers who have travel challenges to and from their homes. The facility helps to reduce the financial and emotional stresses of seeking cancer treatment in New York City's world-class hospitals by providing free lodging. It is the flagship facility of a network of 31 Hope Lodges nationwide. Since Hope Lodge NYC opened its doors in November 2007, it has served over 9,000 people from 47 states and 32 countries. \I'm honored to have been invited to serve on the Women's Committee for Hope and look forward to working with these great women to advance the important cause of the Hope Lodge NYC
post_title: \" said McKeever. \"EHE has long been an advocate for preventive health as a provider of annual physical exams for the early detection of life-threatening diseases such as cancer. It's a great joy to expand that advocacy role and play a part in more people's fight against cancer.\"

New York, N.Y. – April 12, 2012 – The International Association of Healthcare Professionals, The Leading Physicians of the World association publication brings world-renown cardiologist on board The International Association of Healthcare Professionals has chosen Herbert A. Insel, MD, FACC, to represent the cardiology section of their association publication, The Leading Physicians of the World. The selection of Dr. Insel is a significant representation of his enthusiasm and dedication to the field of cardiology. He is considered to be one of the best cardiologists in practice for the past 28 years. Dr. Insel is a senior cardiologist at EHE International and serves on the company's Medical Advisory Board. He also maintains a private practice in Manhattan. He is known as one of the premier cardiologists in New York City and his specialty is preventive cardiology. Dr. Insel frequently lectures on this topic and has often published tips on routine exercise, eating healthy and maintaining a heart healthy lifestyle. Additionally, he has promoted these same principles on numerous media outlet and is well known among his peers and patients as an avid participant in the lifestyle he recommends. \The entire staff of EHE International and I are thrilled that one of our own physicians was selected to represent cardiology in this publication. Dr. Insel's constant devotion to his patients is exceptional and his contribution to the medical profession outstanding. Together with Dr. Insel

New York, N.Y. – May 2, 2012 – Dr. Lori Reder and Dr. Charles Perry Join EHE International's Team of Medical Professionals in Stamford, CT EHE International is proud to announce two new physicians joining their offices in Stamford, Connecticut. Dr. Lori Reder has worked in EHE International's Morristown, New Jersey office for the past three years. Prior to joining EHE International, Dr. Reder maintained an internal medicine practice with Overlook Hospital in Summit, New Jersey. She is affiliated with the American College of Physicians, New Jersey Medical Society and Overlook Hospital Primary Council. She received AMA Physician's Recognition Award from 1993 to present. Dr. Reder earned her medical degree from Georgetown School of Medicine and is board-certified in internal medicine. Dr. Charles Perry joins EHE International after affiliations with New-York Presbyterian Hospital, Tisch Hospital-NYU Medical Center and Northern Westchester Hospital. Dr. Perry's professional societies include: American Medical Association, Medical Society of the State of New York and New York City Medical Reserve Corps. He earned his medical degree from the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons and is board-certified in internal medicine. \Drs. Reder and Perry are great additions to our physician staff in Stamford and are in keeping with the overall professionalism of our more than 100 doctors around the country\" said Executive Vice President

New York, NY, APRIL 2, 2013—As the leader for research in ALS, the devastating brain disorder also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, Project A.L.S. has been selected by EHE International to raise awareness about ALS and related brain diseases in a 103-square foot window display in Rockefeller Plaza. The interactive Project A.L.S. exhibit debuts today in the major international thoroughfare, and will be available to the public for the month of April. The participatory exhibit focuses on ALS, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and the closely related brain diseases that will affect 1 in 25 Americans by the year 2020. Scientists agree that if we can understand and treat ALS, we will have new insight into cures for the range of brain diseases. The display window, donated by EHE International, highlights the growing epidemic of brain disease by literally giving viewers a window into the human brain with information about brain disease and opportunities for visitors to participate in stopping its spread. \People need to realize that brain disease is going to touch each one of us
post_title: \" said Project A.L.S. President and Co-Founder Meredith Estess. \"Project A.L.S. is grateful to EHE International for the opportunity to educate the public on a problem that has grown to an epidemic of devastating proportions.\"

NEW YORK, September 1, 2014 – The Bachmann-Strauss Dystonia & Parkinson Foundation will be featured in a large window display at 10 Rockefeller Center throughout the month of September, showcasing its call to action—“Help Raise Awareness and Get Proper Care.” This opportunity to inform the public about dystonia, a debilitating movement disorder affecting some 500,000 men, women and children in North America, was made possible by a generous donation from EHE International. “EHE International is America’s oldest and largest health organization dedicated to proactive management of health. We are happy to donate our window to an organization that is raising awareness about dystonia and Parkinon’s disease, which aims to get patients the best possible care,” said Deborah KcKeever, President of EHE International. “Together, we hope to spread awareness and promote education about this disease, and help save lives.” Dystonia causes painful, uncontrollable spasms, twisting movements and irregular postures, affecting many parts of the body. Because few physicians are familiar with the symptoms of dystonia, many patients suffer for years before getting a diagnosis. Dystonia has a close connection to Parkinson’s disease, which affects 6 million people worldwide. Some 40% of people with Parkinson’s disease also have dystonia. The window exhibit will present facts and statistics about dystonia and Parkinson’s disease as well as descriptions of everyday challenges facing dystonia sufferers. It will also demonstrate the Foundation’s commitment to supporting research to develop improved therapies and cures. A large television monitor will outline how different types of dystonia affect various parts of the body and how dystonia, compared to other movement disorders, lacks awareness and research funding. The window display was designed and installed by Fashion Institute of Technology alumnus Sean Madden (Visual Presentation and Exhibit Design). We would like to acknowledge Mr. Madden’s time and commitment to this project. The call to action includes a special invitation for patients: “We’re Here to Help…Get World-Class Care at One of Our Dystonia and Parkinson’s Disease Centers of Excellence.” These centers, established with grants of $400,000 each from the Foundation, bring together multidisciplinary teams to provide patients with coordinated care in a single location. The centers are located at Mount Sinai Beth Israel in New York; the University of Alabama at Birmingham; the University of California, San Francisco; and the University of Florida in Gainesville. For more information, visit www.dystonia-parkinson.org/centers.

ID: “I am thrilled that our Foundation was given this opportunity to bring attention to dystonia and its connection to Parkinson’s disease
post_author: ” said Foundation President Bonnie Strauss. “Our biggest goal is to raise awareness about dystonia and Parkinson’s disease so patients can be diagnosed and treated earlier to obtain the best care possible. We’re also strongly committed to raising much-needed funds for research to ultimately find a cure.”

ID: The Bachmann-Strauss Dystonia & Parkinson Foundation is an independent
post_author: nonprofit
post_date: 501(c)(3) organization established in 1995 by Louis Bachmann (1916-2000) and Bonnie Strauss to find better treatments and cures for the movement disorders dystonia and Parkinson’s disease and to provide medical and patient information. The Foundation funds scientific and clinical research and helps raise awareness of dystonia and Parkinson’s disease among the general public and the medical community. For more information

NEW YORK
post_excerpt: 2014)—EHE International
post_status: the recognized leader in preventive medicine and annual physical exams
comment_status: today announced its proud support and sponsorship of American runner David Fouse in the 2014 \"Himalayan 100 Mile Stage Race.\" Starting Oct. 16 in Maneybhanjang
post_password: and extending over a five-day period
post_name: David and his fellow runners will complete a 100-mile course that takes them to altitudes of 12
to_ping: 000 ft. with spectacular views of four of the top five world's largest mountains

ID: \"The Himalayan 100 Mile Stage Race is an opportunity for EHE International to bring attention to the importance of encouraging employees to engage with their physicians to establish a baseline of one's physical health
post_author: \" said Deborah McKeever
post_date: president and COO of EHE. \"David is able to pursue his dream of running in a race in the shadows of Mt. Everest because he was able to tailor his fitness goals after a thorough examination from an EHE physician. As David's exclusive sponsor
post_date_gmt: EHE hopes his example will inspire others to take charge of their health so that they can pursue their own individual goals.\"

post_author: David works full-time at a public-relations firm outside <span class=\"xn-location\">Washington
post_date: D.C.
post_date_gmt: and is the father of five children. While fitness has always been a part of David's life
post_content: he recently noticed that he was more fatigued and sore after his normal workouts. Earlier this year David completed a full-day physical exam at EHE's <span class=\"xn-location\">McLean
post_excerpt: location
post_status: where he learned that his body was healthy enough to endure the rigors of high-altitude running.

ID: \"I was concerned that my fatigue and soreness were symptoms of something more serious
post_author: \" David said. \"My first inclination was to do what too many 40-something Americans do
post_date: which is to cut back on living an active lifestyle. But after my physical at EHE
post_date_gmt: I learned that the only thing wrong with me was that I didn't have the body of an 18-year-old anymore. Otherwise
post_content: there was no reason I couldn't maintain my fitness regime – and even step it up a notch.\"

ID: Running a 100-mile race through the Himalayas isn't for everyone. But too many U.S employees must choose between their job and living an active lifestyle. That they often choose to forgo physical activity to the detriment of their health is one reason EHE International has chosen to sponsor David and tell his story.
Employers who create a positive and healthy work environment generally see fewer employee sick days
post_author: and help build a workforce that is healthier
post_date: happier
post_date_gmt: and more productive. Whether it's a 100-mile race or a basic lifestyle improvement
post_content: it's time for companies to ask their employees

NEW YORK, June 5, 2012 /PRNewswire/ -- A window display at Rockefeller Center this month reminds us of the importance of sun protection while enjoying time outdoors. This public health message is a collaborative effort among the SHADE Foundation of America, the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) SunWise program, and the National Park Service (NPS). The display provides information about the health effects of overexposure to the sun, and demonstrates how everyone can put \Slip
post_excerpt: Slap and Wrap\" into action: Slip on a shirt
comment_status: Slap on a hat and Wrap on sunglasses. The window space at 10 Rockefeller Plaza
post_password: will house the display throughout the month of June
post_name: which also coincides with Great Outdoors Month.

post_date: President of EHE International. \"Together

post_date_gmt: it is essential to communicate the message of prevention. SHADE thanks EHE International for the opportunity to use the window to educate the public about being SunWise while spending time outdoors
post_content: especially in our wonderful national parks.\"

The SHADE Foundation of America is dedicated to the eradication of melanoma through the education of children and the community in the prevention and detection of skin cancer and the promotion of sun safety. www.shadefoundation.org
