<span id=\hs_cos_wrapper_post_body\" data-hs-cos-general-type=\"meta_field\" data-hs-cos-type=\"rich_text\">NEW YORK (Sept. 24
post_excerpt: the nationally recognized leader in preventive medicine and annual physical-exam screenings
post_status: today announced the appointment of Shaun Francis as EHE’s chief executive officer. Mr. Francis is the chairman of EHE’s board
post_password: who announced her retirement this month after 25 years of service.

ID: <!--more--> “On behalf of the board and all of EHE
post_author: I would like to personally thank Ms. McKeever for her 25 years of commitment to EHE and exceptional service to our clients
post_date: ” Mr. Francis said. “She has led this organization to new heights
post_date_gmt: and I look forward to continuing and building upon the solid foundation that’s in place. It’s a privilege to lead a company that is a trailblazer in preventive health care
post_content: and I’m excited to work with the EHE team to achieve our goal of becoming the nation’s pre-eminent wellness organization.”

post_author: EHE was acquired by Summit Partners and DW Healthcare Partners with a clear vision of expanding the EHE platform of preventive healthcare delivery. EHE is America’s oldest and largest health organization devoted to the proactive management of health through annual physical exams. Since the company’s founding in 1913
post_date: EHE has conducted their exam protocol for hundreds of corporations’ employees and partners to manage their healthcare costs through the early detection of preventable diseases and management of risk factors that drive those diseases.

ID: “Shaun’s extensive business and healthcare experience makes him uniquely well-suited to oversee EHE’s continued growth
post_author: ” said Mark deLaar
post_date: a managing director from Summit Partners. “As the nation’s largest provider of preventive medical exams
post_date_gmt: EHE is in a strong position to bring preventive care to the forefront of the national healthcare discussion.”

ID: “EHE operates in an exciting and complex regulatory environment that Shaun understands well. Over the past few months as chair of EHE’s board
post_author: Shaun has gained critical insights and articulated a clear path forward for the company to build on its 100 years of success
post_date: ” adds Andrew Carragher
post_date_gmt: founder and managing director from DW Healthcare Partners.

post_author: Shaun Francis became CEO at Medcan
post_date: one of the world’s largest providers of preventive health care in Toronto
post_date_gmt: Canada. Prior to his role at Medcan
post_content: Mr. Francis was one of the founding employees and Senior Vice President of Strategy and Business Development for Dallas-based Broadlane
post_excerpt: a leading business process outsourcer for over 900 American hospitals. Mr. Francis also worked for Morgan Stanley’s New York and Toronto investment banking division where he managed equity
comment_status: and acquisitions transactions. Shaun earned his MBA from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania and a Bachelor of Science with honors and merit from the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis

ID: In addition to the new CEO appointment
post_author: EHE welcomed three new top executives to its growing organization. Brian Lantier joins as chief financial officer (CFO)
post_date: Bill Stauffer as chief operating officer (COO) and Tom Maraday as executive vice president (EVP) of business development. The expansion moves EHE to an even greater leadership position in preventive care.

ID: Prior to joining EHE as CFO
post_author: Mr. Lantier was with Wellspring Capital Management and was the CFO & COO of Summit Golf Brands
post_date: a sports apparel company. Previously
post_date_gmt: he worked with AlixPartners' Turnaround & Restructuring practice and The Staten Group
post_content: a boutique consulting firm focused on private equity portfolio companies. Mr. Lantier began his career as a naval officer and aviator
post_title: completing multiple wartime deployments supporting Operations Enduring Freedom and Iraqi Freedom. He also served as the Chief of Flight Operations at Sikorsky (subsidiary of UTC) where he was responsible for helicopter flight testing on behalf of the U.S. Government. Mr. Lantier graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy with a Bachelor of Science in Aerospace Engineering and received a Master of Business Administration from Harvard Business School.

ID: Mr. Stauffer joins EHE as its new COO. With more than a decade in the health and wellness industry
post_author: he was previously the executive-in-charge of operations and member experience at Equinox Fitness Clubs and SoulCycle
post_date: an indoor-cycling studio. He was also the COO for the premier juice-bar brand
post_date_gmt: Juice Generation. Mr. Stauffer earned his B.A. in marketing from Hofstra University and his M.S. in international business from State University of New York Maritime College.

ID: Mr. Maraday brings more than three decades of preventive healthcare experience as the new EVP of business development. Prior to joining EHE
post_author: he served as vice president of business development for Bright Horizons Family Solutions Inc. Before that
post_date: he spent 22 years with Plus One Health Management Inc. in a variety of sales
post_date_gmt: operating and leadership roles. Mr. Maraday earned a B.S. in human performance and nutrition from Southern Connecticut State University and has earned a number of industry-recognized certifications from Columbia University and the Human Performance Institute.

ping_status: Mexico Ironman race this past weekend. Commonly referred to as one of the most difficult sporting events in the world
post_password: the race is made up of a 2.4-mile swim

ID: <span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\">“The Ironman is an opportunity for EHE International to recognize those individuals who push themselves day after day in pursuit of a dream
post_author: ” said Deborah McKeever
post_date: president and chief operating officer of EHE International. “For some

ID: <span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\">David works full time and is the father of five. Unlike professional athletes
post_author: he pursued his Ironman dream while maintaining the responsibilities of a business executive
post_date: father and husband. EHE sponsored David with the goal of inspiring others to pursue their dreams — whether it’s to run a 5k or to lower your blood pressure — EHE can help.

ID: <span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\">“I’m so grateful to EHE for their programs and services in preparing for Cozumel
post_author: ” David said. “Prior to 2015 I had never competed in an Ironman

post_date_gmt: by helping me reach my goals
post_content: EHE helped me encourage and challenge friends and colleagues to pursue their own goals for healthy living. I hope that more companies and their executives will contact EHE and become a prevention and health workforce advocate in their own areas of influence.”

ID: <span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\">Competing in an Ironman is not for everyone. But too many U.S. employees must choose between their job and living an active lifestyle. When they see the C-suite engaging in healthy behaviors
post_author: employees become more aware of their own health
post_date: which is one reason EHE International has chosen to sponsor David and tell his story.

ID: <span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\">Employers who create a positive and healthy work environment generally see fewer employee sick days
post_author: and help build a workforce that is healthier
post_date: happier

Komen Greater NYC will showcase its work to save lives and eradicate breast cancer as a life-threatening disease in a highly coveted 10 Rockefeller Center display window, showcasing faces of breast cancer survivors and providing important messages about the disease. “One out of every eight women will be diagnosed with breast cancer in her lifetime,” stated Linda Tantawi, CEO of Komen Greater NYC. “Everyone, male or female, knows someone or is someone who has been affected by breast cancer. It is an equal opportunity disease knowing no boundaries – not gender, geography, income level, or race. This generous donation by EHE International allows us to literally frame our mission to save lives and eradicate breast cancer forever.”

NEW YORK, NY (January 4, 2016) − EHE International will ring in the new year supporting blood cancer awareness featuring the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society® (LLS) in a window display at Rockefeller Center in New York City throughout January. Photos featuring eight blood cancer survivors including adults, children, and their families are displayed with facts about LLS’s impact in funding research to advance lifesaving treatments and cures, and providing critical support and information to patients and families. “LLS has invested more than $1 billion in research to advance breakthrough therapies and cures for blood cancer patients, and has contributed to increasing survival rates; since the early 1960s, five-year survival rates for many blood cancer patients have doubled, tripled, and even quadrupled.

post_content: Long Island, NY (June 01, 2016) -- The Marty Lyons Foundation, Inc. has been invited by EHE International to use its Rockefeller Center window to showcase its mission throughout the month of June. From Wednesday, June 1 through Thursday, June 30, nearly 250,000 people per day will see inspiring images and learn about the mission of the Marty Lyons Foundation through the display at 10 Rockefeller Center.   The Marty Lyons Foundation, headquartered on Long Island, was founded in 1982 by legendary New York Jets player Marty Lyons. Since its establishment, it has provided and arranged for over 7,100 special first and second wishes to children, ages 3 to 17, diagnosed with life threatening or terminal illnesses, many of whom have experienced episodes of remission. Utilizing heartwarming photos, the window display at 10 Rockefeller Center in the Today Show Plaza between West 48th Street and West 49th Street will showcase the real life stories of children who have received special wishes through the efforts of the Foundation. In addition to information about the nonprofit’s mission, there will be a viewing screen in the center of the display with slides of many wish recipients, as well as the man who started it all, Marty Lyons, in action from his days as a star football player with the New York Jets. “The window display at Rockefeller Center will be a magnificent and powerful communications vehicle for relating our mission to the public. We are very grateful to EHE International for the opportunity to showcase the good works of our Foundation. Spreading joy and creating important memories throughout our 10 chapters in 13 states is a rewarding experience for me, staff members, volunteers and our generous supporters. This window display in the heart of New York City will show the public what the Foundation is about and give them a glimpse of many of the bright moments in the lives of our wish children,” said Lyons. EHE International has been a leader in preventive care and wellness services for over 100 years. “EHE International is proud to support the Marty Lyons Foundation through this donation of our window. The display will create awareness of the Foundation’s dedicated efforts to grant wishes for children and families facing unimaginable hardship,” said Deborah McKeever, President of EHE International. For additional information and to support the Marty Lyons Foundation’s wish granting program please call (631) 543-9474 or visit: www.martylyonsfoundation.org.

post_author: a 12-year veteran of the New York Jets football team and member of the legendary New York Sack Exchange

post_date_gmt: which provides wishes to children (ages three to seventeen) who have been diagnosed as having terminal or life threatening illnesses. They are unique in that they will consider granting a second wish to a deserving child. Incorporated in 1982
post_content: over the last 34 years
post_excerpt: 100 wishes. They are proud to have 10 chapters covering 13 states. For more information about the Foundation

NEW YORK, NY (August 1, 2014)—Throughout the month of August, the National Ovarian Cancer Coalition will be featured in the highly coveted 10 Rockefeller Plaza showcase window. The space is being donated by EHE International, an historic preventative healthcare company, dedicated to proactive health care management. The eye-catching window display, designed in partnership with Stephen Pannone of DesignOjo, presents colorful flip-flops symbolizing women’s footsteps, in a ratio that denotes the alarmingly low ovarian cancer survival rate beyond five years. “The five-year survival rate for women diagnosed with the disease is only 44%. The associated impacts on families and communities make ovarian cancer More Than a Woman’s Disease®. We thank EHE International for affording NOCC the opportunity to increase awareness, which is essential to saving lives,” comments David Barley, CEO of the National Ovarian Cancer Coalition. Termed “the silent killer,” ovarian cancer continues to be the deadliest of all gynecologic cancers, affecting 1 in 72 women in their lifetime. There is no screening test for the disease, and it is undetected by a Pap test. The symptoms can be vague, and mimic those of unrelated conditions. As a result, most cases are diagnosed in later stages of the disease when the prognosis is poor. Symptoms of ovarian cancer can include: bloating or sudden weight gain, persistent pelvic or abdominal pain or pressure, trouble eating or feeling full quickly, and feeling the need to urinate urgently or often. Helping to raise awareness about these signs and symptoms is integral to the mission of the NOCC . Where awareness exists, so does hope. In that spirit, the window also features the PSA entitled, “Know Your Risk for Ovarian Cancer,” with Valisia LeKae, Grammy and Tony Award Nominated Broadway Star, NOCC National Spokesperson, and Ovarian Cancer Survivor. The video, provided by Mount Sinai’s Ovarian Cancer Risk Assessment Program, highlights the importance of knowing your risk as a key to prevention. Also highlighted is the NOCC’s Run/Walk signature fundraising event, hosted by more than 20 offices nationwide in September, which is Ovarian Cancer Awareness Month. These, and other events throughout the year, support the NOCC’s ongoing efforts to promote research, raise awareness, and provide education about ovarian cancer, which can lead to earlier detection and higher survival rates. “EHE International is proud to support the National Ovarian Cancer Coalition’s efforts to raise awareness about ovarian cancer,” said Deborah McKeever, President of EHE International. “Together, we hope to spread awareness and promote education about this insidious disease, and help save lives.” About the National Ovarian Cancer Coalition Since its inception in 1995, the National Ovarian Cancer Coalition (NOCC), a designated 501(c)3 organization, has been committed to raising awareness about ovarian cancer, and providing support, education, and hope for women affected by the disease, and their families. The NOCC remains steadfast in its mission to save lives by fighting tirelessly to prevent and cure ovarian cancer, and to improve the quality of life for survivors. For more information, please visit www.ovarian.org

NEW YORK, JANUARY 14, 2013- Body Mass Index (BMI) is a reliable indicator of obesity-related health risks, according to a new study conducted by EHE International Medical Advisory Board member Dr. Andrew Rundle. The study was published January 12 in Obesity Research and Clinical Practice. The study compared the merits of body mass index (BMI) to other measures of body size and adiposity as a predictor of obesity-related cardiovascular health risks. When compared with other measures including waist circumference (WC), waist-to-height ratio (WtH), percent body fat (%BF), fat mass index (FMI) or fat-free mass index (FFMI), the researchers found BMI to be as good an indicator of clinical risks as the other measures of body size or composition. \There has been a lot of controversy recently over whether BMI
post_title: which is based simply on weight and height
post_excerpt: is a good clinical indicator of obesity-related health risks
post_status: especially when compared to more complex measures and newer technologies
ping_status: an Associate Professor of Epidemiology at the Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health. \"I wanted to see how well BMI performs compared to other proposed measures
post_password: and our research shows that BMI performs well as a predictor of health risks. If your BMI is high
post_name: chances are good it's because you have an excess of fat tissue and that you have other health risks. The data conclusively supports clinicians making recommendations for furthertesting and treatment based on BMI measurements
to_ping: and patients heeding recommendations based on BMI.\"

ID: Dr. Rundle conducted the research with colleagues Stephen J. Mooney and Aileen Baecker . They analyzed cross-sectional measurements of height
post_author: weight
post_date: waist circumference
post_content: blood pressure measurements
post_title: cholesterol levels and fasting glucose levels among more than 12
post_excerpt: 000 adults using information from EHE International's database of patients. EHE is a 100-year-old
post_status: nationally-recognized leader in preventive medicine and annual physical exams.

ID: \"EHE was very pleased to participate in this study
post_author: \" said Debbie McKeever
post_date: president of EHE International. \"The successes of BMI in predicting health risks are an important finding that will help doctors practice better preventive medicine and allow patients to take a more proactive role in understanding and managing their health.\"

ID: • BMI is the strongest predictor of blood pressure
<li>Waist circumference and waist-to-height ratio performed better at predicting fasting glucose levels
post_author: an important factor used to diagnose diabetes

ID: • BMI is roughly comparable to other measures at predicting cholesterol levels
• Variables stratified by race and ethnicity had no significantly stronger associations

New York, NY, November 1, 2013 – Throughout the month of November, Lung Cancer Awareness Month, visitors to Rockefeller Center in the heart of midtown Manhattan will be educated on the number 1 cancer killer of Americans - more than colon, breast and prostate cancers combined. Thanks to the generosity of EHE International, the Lung Cancer Research Foundation (LCRF), will have a 115-square foot exhibit window containing important information about lung cancer. The exhibit will be on view at 10 Rockefeller Plaza from November 1, 2013 until December 3, 2013. The window display includes information about the disease, the innovative research being conducted, and startling statistics – including the fact that lung cancer is responsible for 1/3 of all cancer deaths in the US. The display urges anyone who wants to help support national research studies and activities focused on developing advances for better treatment, screening, and prevention of all cancers of the lung to visit the LCRF's web site at www.lungfund.org.

ID: \"EHE International is delighted to donate the window space at Rockefeller Center to help educate people about the deadliest cancer in America during Lung Cancer Awareness Month
post_author: \" says Deborah McKeever
post_date: President of EHE International. \"We are very grateful to EHE for the opportunity to educate the public this devastating disease
post_date_gmt: \" says Sara Kirkwood of the Lung Cancer Research Foundation. \"Lung cancer research has been chronically underfunded compared to other cancers and the LCRF has been working to change this. This window display will give us the opportunity to deliver our message of hope through research\" said Kirkwood.

ID: In addition to the display in November
post_author: LCRF will be hosting its annual lung cancer awareness luncheon
post_date: \"Perspectives on Lung Cancer: The Future of Lung Cancer Therapy\" on Thursday November 14
post_content: New York
post_title: NY. During the luncheon LCRF will be announcing 16 new research grants and will present the 2013-2014 Scientific Merit and Lynn Tarnopol Investigator Awards.

Rockefeller Plaza Window Display Raising Awareness for Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis Generously Donated by EHE International NEW YORK, July 3, 2012 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- For diseases that often go unnoticed, it may take a life-sized great white shark to capture people's attention. The Greater New York Chapter of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America (CCFA) unveiled a 115 square-foot display at 10 Rockefeller Plaza with a call to action to find cures for inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD). The display, on view July 3-30, 2012, highlights the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation and their work to find cures for Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis and to improve the lives of adults and children affected by these diseases. The window space was donated by EHE International, America's oldest and largest preventive health company. \EHE International is happy to donate the window in Rockefeller Center for the month of July to the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation. Together we hope to enlighten
post_title: inform and educate the public about the specific needs of over 1.4 million Americans suffering from Inflammatory Bowel Diseases
post_excerpt: \" said Deborah McKeever

post_date: donated its services to create the window's dynamic design

post_title: \"The window was designed to draw a parallel between pain
post_excerpt: danger and the unknown. Crohn's and Colitis are relatively unknown and largely misunderstood. I wanted BOLD to lend support in helping to spread the message about these little-known diseases and draw attention to this worthwhile organization. I couldn't be more honored to be a part of this project for CCFA.

ID: Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are painful
post_author: medically incurable illnesses that attack the digestive system. Crohn's disease may attack anywhere along the digestive track
post_date: while ulcerative colitis inflames only the large intestine (colon). Symptoms may include abdominal pain
post_content: rectal bleeding
post_excerpt: weight loss and fatigue. Many patients require hospitalization and surgery. Most people develop the diseases between the ages of 15 and 35; however the incidence is increasing in young people.

post_date: families and medical professionals; and a summer program
post_content: provides a safe and supportive camp community to children with IBD.

post_content: NEW YORK, NY (April 1, 2016) − A Stand Up To Cancer (SU2C) window display at Rockefeller Plaza will reach nearly 250,000 people per day to take action in the fight against cancer for the month of April. Featuring Academy Award-Winner Eddie Redmayne, the display is adapted from a public service announcement (PSA) by Stand Up To Cancer, a program of the Entertainment Industry Foundation (EIF) and a 501 (c)(3) organization that, “raise funds to accelerate the pace of groundbreaking translational research that can get new therapies to patients quickly and save lives now.” The SU2C display shows Redmayne running head-on toward the viewer in the visual style of an action film while bold text reiterates the fact that more than 1,600 people in the U.S. die each day from cancer. That sobering statistic and the dynamic image together convey the urgency of getting new, more effective therapies to patients who desperately need them. SU2C facilitates collaboration by “Dream Teams” of leading scientists who work together to translate advances in the laboratory into new treatments for patients at an accelerated pace. Since Stand Up To Cancer was launched in 2008, more than 1,100 scientists from over 130 institutions around the world have collaborated through SU2C.     “This is an incredibly promising moment in cancer research, but we risk losing that momentum if we don’t act now to support the scientists on the front lines of this fight and their life-saving work,” said EIF President and SU2C Co-founder Lisa Paulsen. “We’re so grateful to EHE International for the opportunity to share that message with the millions of people who will pass by this display.” “EHE International is proud to be a longtime supporter of Stand Up To Cancer’s impressive campaign,” said Deborah McKeever, president of EHE International. The window space at 10 Rockefeller Plaza, donated by EHE International, will house the display throughout the month of April. The display was created as part of SU2C’s Act Now, Save Lives, Stand Up To Cancer campaign, which is an exclusive short film and set of photographs shot by renowned photographer and film director Greg Williams. The campaign features Eva Mendes, Tom Hardy, Idris Elba, Benedict Cumberbatch and Michelle Dockery, among others, in addition to Redmayne. About Stand Up To Cancer Stand Up To Cancer (SU2C) raises funds to accelerate the pace of research to get new therapies to patients quickly and save lives now. SU2C, a program of the Entertainment Industry Foundation (EIF) and a 501(c)(3) charitable organization, was established in 2008 by film and media leaders who utilize the industry’s resources to engage the public in supporting a new, collaborative model of cancer research and to increase awareness about progress being made in the fight against the disease. As SU2C’s scientific partner, the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) and a Scientific Advisory Committee led by Nobel Laureate Phillip A. Sharp, Ph.D., conduct rigorous, competitive review processes to identify the best research proposals to recommend for funding, oversee grants administration, and provide expert review of research progress. Current members of the SU2C Council of Founders and Advisors (CFA) include Katie Couric, Sherry Lansing, Lisa Paulsen, Rusty Robertson, Sue Schwartz, Pamela Oas Williams, Ellen Ziffren, and Kathleen Lobb. The late Co-founder Laura Ziskin executive produced Stand Up To Cancer’s Sept. 5, 2008 and Sept. 10, 2010, broadcasts. Lisa Paulsen and Pam Williams were executive producers and the other CFA members were co-producers of the 2014 telecast. SU2C was formally launched on May 27, 2008. Sung Poblete, Ph.D., R.N., has served as SU2C’s president since 2011. For more information on Stand Up To Cancer, visit www.standup2cancer.org.

post_content: NEW YORK, December 2, 2013 — The Max Cure Foundation (MCF) will take over the giant display window at 10 Rockefeller on The Today Show Plaza just steps away from the Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree. This opportunity to highlight Max Cure and its mission to advance the fight against pediatric cancer was made possible by EHE International.The 115 square foot exhibit will contain childhood cancer facts and will feature MCF's Dunk Your Kicks program. This campaign is a fun way of teaching philanthropy throughout the community by asking people to donate their old sneakers. MCF sells the \"kicks\" to an international recycler. Monies received to MCF will go towards advancing their mission. The recycler then sells the sneakers in emerging market countries in the Affordable Clothing Market.

post_author: 000 people globally are living with ALS
post_date: a progressive neurodegenerative disease that causes muscle weakness
post_content: and ultimately
post_title: respiratory failure. There is no effective treatment
post_excerpt: and no cure.

ID: Zumba's \"Together We Dance to Cure ALS\" campaign features three options to support Augie's Quest's mission to end ALS: attend a \"Together We Dance to Cure ALS\" Zumbathon® event in cities worldwide; purchase limited edition apparel and accessories; or make a donation.
Through the support of Zumba and other initiatives
post_author: Augie's Quest has raised nearly $40 million for ALS TDI since 2007 in support of finding effective ALS treatments. This has enabled scientists at ALS TDI to screen more than 100 molecules to see if they affected the progression of the disease
post_date: ultimately leading to a Phase II clinical trial that is currently ongoing on a potential treatment for the disease.

ID: \"Zumba has been a key global partner with Augie's Quest since the beginning
post_author: and we are honored to have their continued support
post_date: \" says Augie Nieto
post_date_gmt: who heads Augie's Quest and is chairman of the board at ALS TDI. \"I know as people walk by the window display in Rockefeller Center
post_content: they too will be inspired to join in our fight against ALS.\"

ID: \"EHE is delighted to donate the window space at Rockefeller Center to help raise awareness of ALS and promote and encourage participation in funding research for treatments and a cure
post_author: \" says Deborah McKeever
post_date: President of EHE International.

ID: For more information or to get involved in Zumba's \"Together We Dance to Cure ALS\" campaign benefiting Augie's Quest

post_date: and the hashtag #NoLimits. The LCD screen in the center of the display will play a looping video that shows how UCP of NYC is helping New Yorkers to realize their own potential and lead fulfilling lives. This window

post_password: which translates to 1 in 3 women and 1 in 2 men. A cancer diagnosis is a life changing event that often brings with it feelings of anxiety
to_ping: and CSC firmly believes that these feelings are something that no one should have to go through alone.

This campaign is a continuation from CSC’s Spring Celebration in April where guests were invited to pose before a wall with the same words featured above them while holding a title card detailing their relation to cancer. From mother to son
post_content: and many more
post_title: this campaign highlights the fact that cancer affects more than just the patient diagnosed

ID: About the Cancer Support Community
<span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\">The mission of the Cancer Support Community (CSC) is to ensure that all people impacted by cancer are empowered by knowledge
post_author: strengthened by action and sustained by community. In 2009
post_date: The Wellness Community and Gilda's Club joined forces to become the Cancer Support Community. The combined organization
post_date_gmt: with more than 50 years of collective experience
post_content: provides the highest quality social and emotional support for people impacted by cancer through a network of more than 46 licensed Affiliates
post_title: more than 120 satellite locations and vibrant online and telephone communities
post_excerpt: touching more than one million people each year.

ID: Backed by evidence that the best cancer care includes social and emotional support
post_author: the Cancer Support Community offers these services free of charge to men
post_date: women and children with any type or stage of cancer
post_date_gmt: and to their loved ones. As the largest professionally led nonprofit network of cancer support worldwide
post_content: the Cancer Support Community delivers a comprehensive menu of personalized and essential services including support groups
post_excerpt: exercise
post_status: art and nutrition classes and social activities for the entire family. Through cutting-edge psychosocial
ping_status: the Cancer Support Community's Research and Training Institute is helping CSC change the future of cancer care through education and training. The Cancer Support Community's Cancer Policy Institute ensures that the voices of 14.5 million cancer survivors and their families are heard in the nation's capital and state and local legislatures across the country. In 2014
post_password: the CSC network delivered nearly $40 million in free services to patients and families. The Cancer Support Community is advancing the innovations that are becoming the standard in complete cancer care. So that no one faces cancer alone<sup>®</sup>. For more information

post_content: <span id=\hs_cos_wrapper_post_body\" class=\"hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text\" style=\"\" data-hs-cos-general-type=\"meta_field\" data-hs-cos-type=\"rich_text\"><span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\"><strong>NEW YORK (May 1
post_title: 2015) − The Lupus Research Institute launched May Lupus Awareness Month with the unveiling of a powerful “Window on Lupus 2020” display in NYC’s Rockefeller Plaza donated by EHE International.

ID: The display will be seen by about 250
post_author:
000 people each day throughout the month of May. The bold design drives home the devastating effects of lupus on women in their twenties – the decade when lupus is most often diagnosed – and promotes the value of innovative research that seeks to stop organ damage caused by the condition.
 
“Twenty is the age when the future beckons with the brightest promise
post_date: ” noted Margaret Dowd
post_date_gmt: LRI President and CEO. “But for many young women diagnosed with lupus
post_content: the future can hold the threat of serious consequences – the potential for a stroke
post_excerpt: kidney disease. And we want people with lupus to know that there is hope in their future as we work to achieve our 2020 milestone to help prevent organ damage and progression.”
to_ping:
463px\"/>



The window signage urges young women to talk with their healthcare professional if they have common symptoms of lupus such as persistent fatigue and fevers
pinged:
swollen joints and/or skin rash. Visitors can learn more about lupus and the many awareness activities throughout May on the LRI website at LupusResearchInstitute.org.
 
“EHE International proudly supports the Lupus Research Institute’s efforts to raise public awareness of lupus by offering a high-traffic platform in Rockefeller Plaza
post_modified_gmt: President of EHE International. “Lupus is often overlooked
post_content_filtered:
and the visibility afforded by this eye-catching window display can help increase diagnosis and prompt treatment.”
 
About Lupus
Frequently misdiagnosed and misunderstood
post_parent: lupus is a destructive and potentially life-threatening autoimmune disease affecting more than 1.5 million Americans; nine out of 10 people with lupus are women. Lupus is a leading cause of kidney disease
menu_order:
and stroke among young women.
 
About the Lupus Research Institute
The Lupus Research Institute (LRI)
post_type: the world’s leading private supporter of novel research in lupus
post_mime_type: pioneers discovery and champions scientific creativity as it has successfully demonstrated the power of innovation to propel scientific solutions in this complex autoimmune disease. Founded by families and shaped by leading scientists
comment_count: the Institute has generated more than $200 million for novel lupus research
column24: delivering many of the decade’s most pivotal breakthroughs
column25: transforming treatment and advancing toward prevention and a cure. For more information
column26:
visit LupusResearchInstitute.org.

post_title: 2015) − The Multiple Sclerosis Foundation (www.msfocus.org) has teamed up with EHE International to unveil its latest awareness campaign this month with a window display at Rockefeller Plaza. It will feature a collage of people living with MS along a nerve tree beside the campaign slogan “Help Keep Our Connections Strong #4MSF.” This world renowned venue with its high visibility will place this window display before a very large daily audience
post_excerpt: promoting greater awareness of MS.

ID: As there are a string of powerful stories coming from patients
post_author: families and friends connected to MS
post_date: the concept for the Rockefeller window aims to share messages of support from people with MS and their loved ones to others coping with the condition. These exchanges between those so deeply affected by MS will create an emotional gateway into the real lives of people and will be presented on a video stream in the center of the window
post_date_gmt: highlighting notions of encouragement and positivity.

ID: “MSF is proud to display this new campaign for the thousands who visit Rockefeller Plaza each day
post_author: ” said MSF Development Director
post_date: Nathalie Sloane. “No one should have to live with this debilitating disease and ever feel alone. This campaign will give rise to a global sense of community for those living with MS
post_date_gmt: and aligns greatly with the values of MSF
post_content: to provide physical
post_excerpt: and social support for those affected by MS. MSF strives to ensure the best quality of daily life for those coping with MS through implementation of an extensive array of patient services which are offered free of charge.”

ID: <span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\">“EHE international is delighted to make this gift to MSF. Through education and comprehensive resources MSF provides programming and support for people living with MS to maintain their health and well being
post_author: ” says Deborah McKeever
post_date: President of EHE International.

ID: <span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\">Multiple sclerosis is a chronic neurological disorder where the immune system destroys the protective covering of nerves
post_author: disrupting the transmission of messages that communicate a desired action from the brain
post_date: through the spinal cord
post_date_gmt: to various parts of the body. The course of the disease varies greatly from person to person. Common symptoms of MS include fatigue
post_content: weakness
post_excerpt: balance problems
post_name: 000 persons are impacted by MS in the United States.

ID: <span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\">For questions about any of the MSF's programs
post_author: call (888)MSFOCUS(673-6287) or email support@msfocus.org.

ID: About The Multiple Sclerosis Foundation
<span style=\"font-family: helvetica; font-size: 16px;\">The Multiple Sclerosis Foundation (www.msfocus.org or 888-MSFOCUS) is a national
post_author: publicly-funded
post_date: 501(c)(3) non-profit organization headquartered in Ft. Lauderdale
post_date_gmt: Florida. The mission of the Multiple Sclerosis Foundation is to provide nationally accessible programs and support services to those persons affected by MS to help them maintain their health
post_content: safety
post_excerpt: and personal well-being; and to heighten public awareness of multiple sclerosis in order to elicit financial support for the MSF's programs and services and promote understanding for those diagnosed with the illness. post_content: <span id=\hs_cos_wrapper_post_body\" class=\"hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text\" style=\"\" data-hs-cos-general-type=\"meta_field\" data-hs-cos-type=\"rich_text\"><strong>New York
post_excerpt: 2014) – The Skin Cancer Foundation takes Rockefeller Center by storm this May
post_status: thanks to a generous donation from preventative healthcare company EHE International. For one month (May 1 – 31)
comment_status: the company has donated the coveted window display space at 10 Rockefeller Center. The Foundation is using this space to showcase its Go with Your Own Glow™ campaign

ID: “Tanning is dangerous and comes with consequences
post_author: including accelerated skin aging
post_date: and even skin cancer
post_content: MD
post_title:
Senior Vice President of The Skin Cancer Foundation. “The Foundation would like to thank EHE International for this donation. What a great opportunity to further raise awareness about learning to love and embrace your natural skin tone.”

More than 90 percent of the visible changes commonly attributed to skin aging are caused by the sun. Further
post_excerpt:
about 86 percent of melanomas can be attributed to exposure to the sun’s harmful UV rays.

The Foundation’s Go With Your Own Glow™ campaign was created in 2008 and features beautifully illustrated print public service advertisements developed to encourage women to love — and protect — their skin
post_status:
whatever its natural hue. Go With Your Own Glow™ relies not just on health and safety information but also on fashion and beauty trends to convey the message that tanning is unhealthy and no longer in style.

The window display art depicts a woman tanning on a beach towel. This image is supported by the tongue-in-cheek tagline
comment_status:
“Keep Tanning. You Look Great in Leather.” It was designed in partnership with advertising agency Laughlin Constable.

“EHE International is proud to support The Skin Cancer Foundation’s efforts to raise awareness
post_name:
we hope to spread the word that tanning is risky and passé.”

Editor’s Note: Hi-res images of the window display art are available upon request.

About The Skin Cancer Foundation

The Skin Cancer Foundation is the only global organization solely devoted to the prevention
to_ping: early detection and treatment of skin cancer. The mission of the Foundation is to decrease the incidence of skin cancer through public and professional education and research. Since its inception in 1979
pinged: the Foundation has recommended following a complete sun protection regimen that includes seeking shade and covering up with clothing
post_modified: including a wide-brimmed hat and UV-blocking sunglasses
post_modified_gmt: in addition to daily sunscreen use. For more information

post_author: Contact
post_content: closed

Executive Management

Dr. David Levy Chief Executive Officer Dr. Levy is an accomplished physician executive with a record of achievement in complex systems involving patients and a range of organizations. He is a renowned strategic thinker who has executed effective strategies for his own enterprises and a diverse set of public and private sector entities. Drawing on a vast network of business relationships, Dr. Levy brings global best-in-practice solutions to the healthcare industry. At Franklin Health, Dr. Levy used his insights to create a scalable business that helped patients and families receive better, more satisfying care. As strategy leader at PwC, he led the effort to recommend public health and hospital reform for the Louisiana Recovery Authority after Hurricane Katrina. Dr. Levy then directed the team that helped California’s Department of Public Health re-engineer the state’s catastrophic surge response system. In both engagements, he successfully managed all of the stakeholders – including hospitals, private providers, payers, professional associations, and organized labor. At PwC, Dr. Levy elevated the firm's worldwide healthcare practice to prominence by navigating an intricate matrix of domestic and international governance arrangements. His leadership helped PwC become an acclaimed solutions provider across all healthcare sectors in more than 30 countries. Dr. Tania Elliott, MD FAAAAI, FACAAI Chief Medical Officer Dr. Tania Elliott brings a wealth of knowledge and extensive experience to EHE that will help support our position as an innovative health and wellbeing leader. She is a board-certified Allergist and Internist and has published multiple papers on allergic skin disease, immunology, and telemedicine. Most recently, Dr. Elliott was a part of the national telehealth company, Doctor on Demand, where she served as both a telemedicine physician seeing thousands of patients through real-time face to face video consultations, and as the Company’s Medical Director. She is a nationally recognized leader in the telemedicine, technology and innovation space. Dr. Elliott is a firm believer in providing her patients with clear, useful information and resources to empower them to make healthy lifestyle choices. She is regularly featured on Dr. Oz, Rachael Ray, Live! With Kelly and Michael, Dr. Phil, and as a co-host of the Emmy award-winning The Doctors TV show. She graduated from Jefferson Medical College, completed her Internal Medicine Residency at Mount Sinai Hospital, and fellowship in Allergy and Clinical Immunology at Winthrop University Hospital. She is an Associate Attending at NYU Langone Medical Center in New York City. Brian Lantier Chief Financial Officer Brian is the chief financial officer (CFO) of EHE. Prior to joining EHE, Mr. Lantier was with Wellspring Capital Management and was the CFO & chief operating officer of Summit Golf Brands, a sports apparel company. Previously, he worked with AlixPartners' Turnaround & Restructuring practice and The Staten Group, a boutique consulting firm focused on private equity portfolio companies. Mr. Lantier began his career as a naval officer and aviator, completing multiple wartime deployments supporting Operations Enduring Freedom and Iraqi Freedom. He also served as the Chief of Flight Operations at Sikorsky ( a subsidiary of UTC) where he was responsible for helicopter flight testing on behalf of the U.S. Government. Mr. Lantier graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy with a Bachelor of Science in Aerospace Engineering and received a Master of Business Administration from Harvard Business School. Joy Altimare Chief Engagement and Brand Officer Joy Altimare is a brand strategist with nearly 20 years of experience across a range of highly competitive, rapidly evolving marketplaces. She has a proven track record, creating profitable solutions centered around engagement and consumer behavior change. Throughout her career, Joy has been an expert advisor and resource for organizations tackling growth, innovation, and technology challenges and positioning themselves as positive disruptors within their category. Prior to joining the healthcare space, Joy worked with leading agencies such as Ogilvy+Mather, GREY, and Publicis on preeminent brands like L’Oreal, Verizon, and Colgate-Palmolive. She then shifted into a role at publishing giant Conde Nast, transferring her skills to the media world. Joy helped the company bridge the divide between its traditional roots and digital future, providing strategic insight as the industry’s terrain changed. Joy now directs EHE’s innovative engagement strategy as Chief Engagement and Brand Officer. In the role, she leads the alignment of EHE’s unique preventive care product with a frictionless, patient-centered process designed to drive results and satisfaction. Her team discovers key motivators of behavioral change, utilizing them to expand EHE’s reach and maximize its value to patients. Joy lives in NYC with her beautiful family. Tom Maraday Chief Development Officer Tom Maraday brings over three decades of health and wellness experience as EVP at EHE. Prior to joining EHE, Mr. Maraday served as vice president of business development for Bright Horizons Family Solutions, Inc. Before that, he spent 22 years with Plus One Health Management, Inc. in a variety of sales, operating and leadership roles. Mr. Maraday earned a B.S. in human performance and nutrition from Southern Connecticut State University and has earned a number of industry-recognized certifications from Columbia University and the Human Performance Institute.

post_author: Centennial Highlights
post_content: closed

Patients share their personal stories about the impact that the EHE Preventive Health Program has had on their lives – from changing the way they manage their health to even saving their lives.
EHE saved my life. - Christian

post_author: they've helped me to be able to know my body. - David

ID: EHE made me feel like I have a relationship with my doctor. I feel that she truly has a vested interest and desire for me to be at my optimal health. - David

post_author: there was a follow-up appointment that I needed to make outside of EHE. I likely would have put it off
post_date: but I was contacted by Sidonia from EHE’s referral team and she was quite supportive. She set everything up for me with a facility that was close to my home. However
post_date_gmt: when I arrived for the follow-up appointment
post_content: I saw that the new doctor’s office had misplaced my information. I was frustrated and ready to turn around and go home. I then called Sidonia
post_title: and she was wonderful. She took care of everything while staying with me on the phone. I can’t say enough positive things about Sidonia and the ways that the EHE referral department handles their clients.

ID: I have never really enjoyed doctor’s visits and have always been apprehensive in scheduling them. When I started working for my current company though
post_author: I had heard really good things about EHE so I decided to schedule an appointment and give it a try. In a nutshell
post_date: I was treated like royalty! It was like no other medical experience that I have ever had. It was a very professional atmosphere and it seemed that once I was done with one test
post_date_gmt: I was on to the next…everything was mapped out and timed perfectly. I have used this positive experience to change things in my life…I’m walking more
post_content: handling stress better and eating healthier. A lot of this is thanks to my Health Coach and the goals that we have set up.

ID: I was pleasantly surprised at the high level of professionalism and comfort that I experienced while undergoing an annual physical with EHE. Everyone that I encountered was extremely attentive and pleasant and
post_author: even though it was a necessarily lengthy procedure as far as time is concerned
post_date: I felt that all aspects of my experience (tests
post_content: filling out forms
post_title: etc.) were handled very efficiently. Even after the appointment
post_excerpt: I received follow-up emails with great information containing not only detailed personal data but also many high-quality resources that I could utilize to promote my health and fitness. Thank you EHE for making this appointment as easy and informative as possible.

ID: The [EHE] exam seemed to go as normal
post_author: but the radiologist
post_date: Dr. Hamilton
post_date_gmt: noticed something out of the ordinary in my chest x-ray. There was a mass in my chest that had not been there in previous years. Dr. Hamilton didn’t know what it was
post_content: but he was convinced that there was definitely something there sitting on the top of my heart that needed to be removed. In order to have it removed
post_excerpt: my insurance company needed me to have two more opinions
post_status: so I went to see two physicians that my insurance covers. EHE arranged a CT scan for me. The scan confirmed what Dr. Hamilton had seen
comment_status: much to the amazement of the other physicians. Within three weeks
ping_status: I had open heart surgery and the growth was safely removed … I can honestly say I feel that my physical saved my life.

We’ve all heard it a million times before… Americans need to start eating healthier! You know it’s true and you’re totally on board, but despite your best attempts you haven’t been able to convince your family to eat healthier. So, what can you do? Do you resign yourself to the fact that healthier meals just aren’t in the cards at your house? Definitely not! Where there’s a will there’s a way! Here are a few of my tips on how you can incorporate healthier versions of recipes into your meals and replace unhealthy snacks with healthier alternatives—mostly unbeknownst to your unwilling family! Start with Breakfast Are you or your kids addicted to sugary cereals in the morning? Try mixing in a little bit of a whole-grain, nutrient-rich, healthy cereal. Start with just a small amount the first few times, then, over time as tastes adapt, begin adding a bit more of the healthy cereal and a bit less of the sugary cereal. Some popular cereals also offer lower-sugar or whole-grain versions—just store them in plastic containers if you don’t want your kids to know. If toast or bagels are popular in your house buy white whole wheat bread or bagels in place of regular white bread or bagels—they look the same as the white versions and have the same taste and texture, but have the nutritional benefits of whole wheat.  Just make sure the package says “100 percent whole grain\ or lists \"whole wheat\" as the first ingredient.  This is a smart idea for bread for sandwiches and hamburger and hot dog buns too.

ID: When you have extra time and can make pancakes for breakfast
post_author: replace white flour with whole wheat flour or white whole-wheat flour (which is most like regular white flour). Or
post_date: if you’re worried everyone will notice the difference
post_date_gmt: start by using half whole wheat flour and half regular white flour to get used to the difference. To make them even healthier
post_content: use skim milk in place of whole milk. Or begin by replacing whole milk with 2% milk for a more gradual change.

ID: Smoothies! You can make healthy low fat and low calorie smoothies at home and no one will notice if you add a carrot or spinach or cauliflower to the recipe (just don’t let them in the kitchen when you’re making it!)
Does getting your family to eat vegetables feel like a battle you’ll never win?  Incorporate vegetables into meals with them never knowing:

post_author: dice or puree cooked or uncooked vegetables in your food processor and add them to recipes for tacos
post_date: meatballs
post_content: soups
post_title: stews and chili. You can also add them to sauces for pasta or as the base for making homemade pizzas.

ID: Does your family love mac and cheese? Peel and grate some zucchini and mash up some cooked cauliflower and add it to the cheese sauce.
Add grated zucchini or squash to muffin mixes.

post_author: mash in some steamed cauliflower
post_date: or better yet completely substitute mashed cauliflower for mashed potatoes. Cauliflower has only 29 calories per cup compared to the 130 calories in a medium potato. Cauliflower is also packed with vitamin C.

ID: Here’s another cauliflower idea. Try baked cauliflower buffalo wings in place of their deep fried chicken wing counterpart. The cauliflower version is delicious and much healthier.
To cut back on saturated fats
post_author: substitute ground turkey for ground beef in burgers
post_date: meat loaf
post_content: and tacos. Or
post_title: start by buying extra lean ground beef instead of regular to cut back on calories and fat. Also
post_excerpt: remember to remove skin from poultry before cooking.

ID: Do you love french fries (who doesn’t!) Try baked sweet potato fries instead-they’re delicious!
Buy “low fat” or better yet \"fat free\" dairy products—they provide the same nutrients as full–fat versions but have fewer calories and lower or no solid fat. If your family drinks whole milk now
post_author: start by switching to 2%
post_date: then gradually change to 1% and then skim. The same goes for yogurt
post_date_gmt: sour cream and cottage cheese—if you currently consume the full fat versions of these switch to low-fat versions before making the change to fat-free. Instead of ice cream
post_content: buy low-fat frozen yogurt or sorbet.

post_author: unflavored applesauce in recipes that call for oil-it’s easy and much healthier.

ID: Don’t forget about your spice rack! Experiment with different herbs and spices to add delicious flavor to meals—they can replace calorie and fat laden sauces and gravies.
You don’t have to grab a handful of potato chips to get you through until dinner or as a late night snack. There are definitely healthier and more satisfying alternatives. Here are a few.

Do you like cheese and crackers? Use low-fat whole grain crackers or better yet try using apple slices in place of cheese. Another option is to try apple slices with a little all natural peanut butter on them.
Air popped unbuttered popcorn can be a tasty treat when sprinkled with cinnamon or dark chocolate shavings or some parmesan cheese.

post_author: a flavorful low-fat dip can make eating raw vegetables like carrots
post_date: celery
post_date_gmt: peppers and broccoli a tasty treat.

ID: Freeze some grapes and snack on those when you have a craving for something sweet (don’t worry--they don't become rock solid when frozen!).
If you can get yourself and your kids past the green color of kale
post_author: try substituting home-made kale chips sprinkled with a little salt for potato chips. If that doesn’t work
post_date: try buying the baked versions of potato chips and tortilla chips—it’s a step in the right direction.

ID: We all want our families to be healthy
post_author: and we all know that eating a healthy diet is one of the best ways to make that happen. And
post_date: it sounds good in theory
post_date_gmt: but the hard part is actually getting our families to cooperate. But as you can see there is no reason to lose hope! While you won’t be able to overhaul your family’s diet overnight
post_content: you can make small healthy changes they won’t even notice. So start today and incorporate healthier versions of recipes into your daily life and replace unhealthy snacks with healthier alternatives. You’ll be glad you did!"

NEW YORK, NY – Whether it was warning Americans about the perils of childhood obesity in the 1930s or the health consequences of smoking in the 1940s, or even leading the charge for preventive colonoscopies in the early 2000s, EHE International has remained ahead of its time throughout its history. Today, the company celebrates its centennial and honors the guiding vision of its founders and the dedication of its employees by releasing 100 Years of Preventative Health – the History of EHE International, a book chronicling the company's evolution and significant contributions to the field of preventive health.

Since EHE International's founding in 1913, the organization (the nation's largest provider of physical examinations) has remained true to its core mission: detecting life-threatening illnesses in an early, treatable stage and preventing disease by promoting good heath practices. Set against a backdrop of major milestones in American life, this 120-page book engagingly interweaves EHE International's rich history with the personal stories of those who were inspired to join the organization in support of its mission, including former U.S. president and first chairman of EHE International's board, William Howard Taft.

\This book is our tribute to the men and women of yesteryear who set forth the mission and led us here – and to those of today who help to ensure tomorrows for all of our patients
post_title: \" said EHE International President Deborah McKeever.

ID: 100 Years of Preventative Health – the History of EHE International is published by The Donning Company Publishers and is available at eheintl.com."
post_author: EHE International Releases Historical Keepsake Book

post_content:
The first time I tried a box garden, I wasn't sure what to plant. I decided to go to my local farmers market and told them what my family enjoys eating and asked if any of those vegetables grow well in our area. I was in luck because lettuce, carrots, peppers, radishes, and tomatoes were on the list, and my family loves salad. And bonus, this mix of vegetables plants happens to be easy to care for!  We decided to start with a small box garden to give it a trial run the first year we did it. From my experience as a beginner box gardener, here are a few tips to get started.
  • Box garden, well, in a box! If you don’t want to invest too much time, you can purchase a kit that comes complete with pre-measured and cut lumber and hardware-how handy! Avoid building a boxed garden on a wooden deck as the weight might be too much for the deck to bear. If you build directly on a concrete patio be sure to raise the box garden so there is proper drainage.
  • By design box gardens need little space. Make sure the location you choose will get an appropriate amount of sunlight and is close to a water source. Fill the box garden up to about three inches from the top with a good-quality mix of nutrient-rich soil and compost that is best suited for the plants you want to grow. Make sure it is level and smooth once filled. Keep the soil moist, but be careful not to over-water your garden.
  • Spacing of plants can be closer than a normal garden but don’t overdo it on the seeds. Standard seed packets will have way more than you need as I found out when I used a whole packet of carrot seeds and grew these teeny tiny carrots the size of my pinky. Your first season may be an experiment.
  • Family project. My kids loved running to the garden to snip the lettuce and pull the radishes for the ultimate fresh salad. We were even inspired to make our own fresh dressing (recipe below). Take turns with watering, weeding and harvesting. The pride of gardening is contagious and so is the love of salads. We are eating more salad than ever—even froze some tomatoes for the winter months.
Now, to keep the squirrels away! Have you tried a box garden? What has worked for you, and what hasn't? BASIC VINAIGRETTE SALAD DRESSING                Ingredients (4 servings) 1/4 cup red wine vinegar, 2 tablespoons dijon mustard, 1 tablespoon minced shallot 1/4 teaspoon salt, 2/3 cup EVOO, Salt and pepper                               Preparation In a bowl, whisk together all ingredients except EVOO. Slowly drizzle in EVOO, whisking constantly; season with salt and pepper.

C-Reactive Protein is produced in the body in response to inflammatory processes and can increase the risk of a heart attack.

Vascular screening includes carotid ultrasound to detect carotid artery narrowing; abdominal aorta ultrasound to detect bulging of the abdominal aorta (abdominal aortic aneurysm); and an ankle brachial index (ABI) to detect peripheral arterial disease.

post_content:
I’m heading to New Orleans soon for vacation and I’ve been wondering how I’m going to eat all the delicious food the city has to offer without gaining 10 pounds!  Fortunately, I think I’ve found the answer. It turns out that there are a ton of walking tours I can take to stay active. I can tour the French Quarter, the Garden District, St. Louis Cemetery…. I can even take a ghost tour. Now I won’t have to feel guilty when I have a beignet with my coffee every morning at breakfast! I’m really excited about my new discovery. I had never considered a walking tour before, but since my interest was piqued, I’ve done a little digging. So, if you, like me, are new to the world of walking tours, here’s some information you might find helpful:
  • Walking tours are available just about everywhere--New York, Montreal, San Antonio, Tuscany, and even Tuscaloosa! Big cities aren’t the only place you can take a walking tour—there are many small historic towns across the world that also have a lot to offer. All it usually takes to find one is a quick web search or a call to the local tourism office for information. For larger cities buying a guidebook can also help.
  • You can opt for a self-guided tour or you can hire a guide. The benefit to having a knowledgeable tour guide is that you don’t have to do any research or planning--all you have to do is show up. The tour guide will make sure you see all the main sights there are to see as well as the not so well-known gems that only a local would know about. You will also be able to ask questions which may not be easily answered using a guide book. Another bonus is that a guide can give you tips on more places to visit, what to avoid, and where to eat. A self-guided tour is also an option—it just requires more advanced planning and it allows you to explore at your own pace.
  • Guided tours don’t have to be expensive! I was surprised to find out that many guided tours don’t charge a set fee—they often require a reservation, but they only ask that you leave an appropriate tip for your guide based on what you thought the tour was worth. This encourages tour guides to provide the best possible experience. If you’re visiting a major city, a helpful site to find free walking tours is Free Tours by Foot.

ID: <li>Walking tours come in different shapes and sizes! They can be short or long
post_author: easy or difficult. And
post_date: depending on your destination
post_date_gmt: there may be multiple kinds of walking tours to take. Many larger cities have a variety of options —you can focus on history one day
post_content: architecture the next
post_excerpt: food
comment_status: etc. By the end of your trip you’ll be an expert!

ID: Walking tours seem to be a great way to get an up close look at an unfamiliar place with the added bonus of plenty of fresh air and exercise! It’s also occurred to me that I don’t have to travel far to go on a walking tour…. it’s finally springtime…a perfect time for me to get up close and personal in my own area. I live in a small historic town in upstate New York and it turns out there are quite a few walking tours I never knew existed. So don't think you have to travel far afield to take advantage of walking tours. If you don't have a trip planned
post_author: play tourist in your own town--you may discover things you never knew existed!"
post_date: Walking Tours
post_content: publish
post_excerpt: open

post_content: Are you bored with your exercise routine? Tired of staring at the TV while on the elliptical or treadmill? Did you play sports your whole life until the reality of adulthood and a 9 to 5 job brought playing to a grinding halt? If any of these scenarios sound familiar to you, it might be time to shake up your routine and join an adult sports team! Even if you’ve never set foot on a court, field or diamond, if there’s a sport you’ve always wanted to play but never learned, joining an adult sport league can be a great way to learn a new skill, exercise and have fun! If this sounds like something you’d like to try, you most likely have a lot of questions. What sport should you play? Where are you going to find a team? What if you’ve never played before? Read on for some tips on what you could play, where to look and what to expect.

ID: The good news is that depending on where you live and work
post_author: there are often quite a few sports and activities to choose from--volleyball
post_date: softball
post_content: soccer and even kickball
post_title: dodgeball and ultimate frisbee! Start by checking with your local YMCA or your city’s parks and recreation department—they often have leagues already set up. There’s usually a fee to play but it is relatively inexpensive. Another possibility is to ask if your job has any workplace sponsored teams you could join. And if those don’t yield results
post_excerpt: do an internet search for phrases like “adult basketball league in (your city)” or “coed softball league in (your city)” as these will often produce good results.

ID: If you’re just a beginner and worried about not being good enough for a team
post_author: don’t let that stop you! Some leagues have different levels of play available from beginner to more advanced. My city for example
post_date: has beginner
post_date_gmt: intermediate and advanced divisions in its volleyball league.  Start out in the beginner league and as you improve you can move on to the next level of play. Or start with something that doesn’t require a lot of athletic prowess
post_content: like kickball! You can go to WAKA and put in your zip code to see if there are any leagues near you! (I just did it and found 1 locally and 2 others within an hour of my house!)

ID: Although joining a team may sound appealing
post_author: you may be wondering if it is really practical. Between work and family obligations who has the time for this? But remember that everyone else is dealing with time constraints too
post_date: so you can probably find something that will work with your schedule.

ID: If you’re still not convinced to give it a try
post_author: consider these benefits of joining an adult sports league that you may not have considered. You can:

ID: Meet new people and expand your social circle: Joining a team is a great way to meet people and make new friends. You already know you share at least one interest with the other members of your team
post_author: so it’s a good way to break the ice and get to know your teammates even better. There’s nothing quite like the camaraderie you build through teamwork on the playing field.

ID: Relieve stress: Playing in a basketball game or a beach volleyball game (or whatever your sport of

choice is!) can be a great way to de-stress and blow off steam after a long day at work. It gives you the opportunity to get away from it all and escape from the routine of the workweek and the worries of daily life. I think we could all use a healthy escape like this from time to time!

Have fun!: The importance of play doesn’t end with childhood. Sometimes we forget this as we grow older. Play bring joy and who doesn’t want more joy in their life? When you’re having fun playing a team sport you are engaged and connected and these feelings can be a tremendous boost to your mental health.
Variety: Going to the gym every day or for a jog is certainly admirable and great for your health
post_author: but it’s also good to mix things up once in a while. When you play a team sport you’ll add variety to your workouts
post_date: you’ll get a change of scenery and you may have so much fun that you forget you’re exercising!

post_author: you can’t overlook the very important fact that when you are physically active you are healthier. And we are all more likely to be physically active and stay physically active when we enjoy what we are doing! That’s why joining a sports league may be just the thing--not only will you get moving and reap the physical benefits of exercise
post_date: you’ll have fun doing it!"
post_date_gmt: Should You Join an Adult Recreational Sports Team?

post_content: Seasonal allergies touch the lives of most of us at some point. According to the CDC, 20 million adults in the US have been diagnosed with hay fever in the past 12 months.

ID: Spring seasonal allergies can start as early as February and can last well into the summer. Trees that produce large amounts of pollen are one of the main triggers. A particularly rainy spring or mild winter can cause trees and plants to grow more rapidly
post_author: producing larger amounts of pollen and leading to a more severe allergy season. This can also cause an increase in the growth of mold spores which are another major allergen.
red or swollen eyes

ID: • Allergic Shiners (dark circles under the eyes as a result of congestion)
• Itchy throat or roof of the mouth

Anyone can develop seasonal allergies during various stages of life. A child may grow out of their allergies by adulthood. Allergens triggering major reactions may diminish or increase from season to season. And moving from one climate to another could cause you to develop allergies that perhaps you were never aware of.

One of the best ways to ease the affect of your seasonal allergies is to keep an eye on the pollen and mold spore counts which are normally announced in newspapers or news broadcasts during the allergy season.
Keep your windows closed during the season and run the air-conditioner during days with particularly high pollen counts. You may also consider a home air filter or air purifier.

post_author: but your allergic reactions can be minimized. The best form of prevention is understanding what triggers or causes your allergies. Visiting an allergist can help you determine your triggers and prescribe treatment. An allergist may prescribe medications or help you with advice on avoiding allergens such as remaining in an air-conditioned area during days with particularly high pollen counts.

ID: Seasonal allergies may be something you have to live with over the course of your life
post_author: but you don’t have to suffer. By preparing for the season
post_date: understanding your triggers
post_date_gmt: and through the use of medications or avoidance
post_content: you can make your seasonal allergies much more bearable.

post_content: A physical examination is more than a check-up; it’s one of the best ways to boost longevity and health in the long term by committing to preventative care and medical screenings. Proactive measures help you and your doctor identify potential health risks
post_title: making it easier to avoid and interrupt chronic illness before it takes hold. This is why it is important to see your doctor for annual physical exams.

ID: We know that visiting the doctor is intimidating for many
post_author: and we encourage you to confront any fear you may be feeling and make the appointment. Your doctor is a partner in creating good long-term health outcomes
post_date: and the peace of mind which comes from taking positive action is worth the nerves and effort.

ID: While overcoming fear of doctor’s visits sounds great in theory
post_author: in practice it feels overwhelming for some at first. Anxiety about medical care is common
post_date: and can be difficult to manage at times. When calling to make your medical appointments
post_date_gmt: it is helpful to communicate your concerns to the individuals responsible for scheduling. Maybe you have a fear of needles
post_content: and you want to ensure you are seen by your doctor’s best and most sensitive phlebotomist. By communicating your needs to your care providers
post_title: you give them the opportunity to accommodate you and make your visit as comfortable as possible.

ID: Happy Side Effect of a Physical Examination
It is important to remember that scheduling an annual physical examination is just one part of making the commitment to self-care and better health choices. Lifestyle habits such as exercise
post_author: proper sleep habits / hygiene
post_date: nutrition
post_content: and medical care are all key to supporting your health over time.

ID: As you learn to find ways to commit to lasting change
post_author: you can be sure that your efforts will pay off. Benefits such as better sleep
post_date: healthier body weight
post_content: and better mental clarity result from taking charge of your health and well-being.

ID: <strong>Some Things to Consider Before Your Physical Examination
• Preventative care will help decrease and ease anxiety over time by protecting your health in the long term.
<li>A proactive approach to health care includes developing healthier lifestyle habits such as exercise
post_author: sleep hygiene
post_date: and stress management which contribute to the prevention of many chronic and degenerative diseases.

ID: • Preventative medical screenings help protect your financial future. Illness is far less expensive to prevent than it is to treat.
• Annual medical screenings actually reduce your time spent in the doctor’s office by decreasing the likelihood of more complex illnesses developing over time.

post_author: and commit to it at least three times per week.

ID: • See your doctor regularly for physical exams.
<li>Eat a nourishing and balanced diet based in whole
post_author: natural
post_date: and minimally processed foods.

ID: <li>Do not smoke. If you do smoke
post_author: talk with your doctor about the right smoking cessation program for you.

ID: • Drink alcohol in moderation or not at all.
<li>Get at least seven to eight hours of sleep each night. Turn off your phone and electronic devices at least one hour before bed
post_author: and sleep in a well darkened room.

ID: Remember that your health and peace of mind are worth the effort it takes to protect them
post_author: so we encourage a proactive approach. Know that any anxiety you may feel about seeing your doctor is understandable
post_date: however
post_content: a preventative health care approach will decrease health related anxieties
post_excerpt: and increase your wellness and longevity for years to come.

post_author: Benefits of a Physical Examination as Preventative Health Care
