post_author: EHE Guidelines for Good Health After Hurricane Harvey
post_content: open

post_excerpt: Cropped shot of a doctor a giving his patient advice during a consult

post_content:
Your EHE Exam — What to Expect Your EHE clinical exam is convenient and comprehensive. The process is designed to give enrollees unparalleled insight into their health, as well as a well-defined path toward improvement. Here’s an overview of what to expect.   Before Your Appointment Once you are enrolled as an eligible patient and added to the EHE system, you will receive an email explaining how to complete your online EHE + Me profile (including medical history) and schedule your exam. A week before your visit, EHE will send an appointment reminder and any relevant preparation instructions.   Day of Exam After checking in at reception, you will have an entrance interview with an EHE clinician, who will review exactly which tests and screenings are scheduled and answer any questions. With first-time visitors, we go into more detail to ensure every aspect of the clinical experience is understood. The next step is typically laboratory testing, followed by screening procedures, and then your physical exam and conversation with the doctor. The EHE physician will discuss the results of your screenings, family history, specific concerns, and aspects of your routines and lifestyle. For returning patients, the doctor may review notable trends or changes since previous visits. The visit ends with a brief exit interview, during which a clinician answers any follow-up questions and facilitates potential post-exam care. You will receive a report with your exam results within 10 business days.   Exam Components EHE exams are always tailored to your specific needs (in terms of gender, age, special medical considerations, etc.), but a standard clinical screening protocol guides the process for all enrollees, whether they’re seen at an EHE clinic or by an affiliated doctor in the EHE physicians network. The standard clinical screening protocol includes (but is not limited to) these components:
  • Comprehensive physical exam
  • Electrocardiogram (EKG)
  • Body composition assessment (including Body Mass Index)
  • Vision screening
  • Hearing test
  • Pulmonary function test (spirometry)
  • Pelvic exam with Pap smear (for women)
  • Laboratory testing & analysis (see below)
Additional age-determined screening procedures include: Cardiac stress test every three years for patients 40-49, every other year for patients over 50
  • Mammography for women over 40
  • Colonoscopy for patients over 40
  • Vascular health screening every other year
Standard laboratory testing includes:
  • Complete blood count (CBC) with differential & platelets
    • Screening for anemia, leukemia, inflammation, infection, etc.
  • Comprehensive metabolic panel (glucose, kidney function, electrolytes, etc.)
  • Liver function
  • Lipid panel
  • Iron and total iron binding capacity (TIBC)
  • Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
  • Blood type (first visit only)
  • 25-hydroxy Vitamin D test
  • Complete urinalysis
  • Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) for males over 40
  • Cardio C Reactive Protein for patients over 40
  Comprehensive Consultation The EHE visit will also include discussion of broader issues pertaining to lifestyle. The clinician will ask you about your tobacco and alcohol consumption, eating and exercise habits, and other aspects of your health that may be areas of focus for post-exam care. This consultation also engages diet and nutrition, stress/anxiety/depression, relevant sexual health screenings for men and women, immunization recommendations, and other concerns.

What to Expect EHE care begins with the exam. But you have the opportunity to make that initial visit just the starting point — not the end — of their journey to improved health. Post-exam care is available to all EHE enrollees. Those who take advantage are in the best position to make meaningful, lasting progress toward healthier lives. Here’s an overview of what to expect with your post-exam care.   Your Exam Report: What Does It Mean? Post-exam care is activated after you’ve completed your EHE exam and received your report. There are three general report classifications: normal findings, health risks, and significant findings. Only a small percentage of patients (about 1%) fall into the normal findings category. In these cases of near-optimal health, there is no specific need for EHE to engage you for additional care. Your records stay in the system for future physical exams and reference by your primary care physician. You are more likely to be among the majority of enrollees whose reports include health risks. For these individuals, testing signals one or multiple warning signs. These indicators could be blood pressure or cholesterol that falls outside the healthy range, elevated stress measures, pre-diabetic glucose levels, poor eating or lifestyle habits, etc. If you have health risks, you are a prime candidate for personal health coaching (see below). Your report could also show significant findings, in which case you need to take active measures to avoid health problems. There could be mammogram or colonoscopy or EKG abnormalities, severely high cholesterol, or a variety of other screening results requiring medical attention. Please know that while these findings are significant, they are not unusual. Roughly half of EHE enrollees are in this category, and those who pursue post-exam care via clinical intervention and/or referral coordination (see below) are better able to address issues before they become more serious.   Personal Health Coaching An incredibly effective, convenient, and flexible service, especially useful if your exam report identified health risks. EHE has credentialed health coaches, educators, and nutritionists whose collective expertise covers virtually any identified risk. Focal points of coaching include physical activity, nutrition, weight management, stress management, prediabetes management, and smoking cessation. Personal health coaches:
  • Work with you for a full year after the EHE exam at no additional charge — it’s built into the program for anyone who wants it
  • Coach remotely by telephone, so it’s available no matter where you live, at times that are convenient
The initial session is called a “goals call,” during which you establish what you want to work on, identifying past challenges and current motivations. Coaching can focus on one area or many areas — it’s entirely up to you. The entire process is patient-centric and designed to be encouraging, non-threatening, open, and flexible. Follow-up sessions are usually 15 to 20 minutes long and can be done on whatever schedule/frequency works best for you.   Clinical Intervention If your exam shows significant findings, an EHE clinical intervention nurse will contact you shortly after receiving the report. During that first point of contact, the nurse makes sure you understand the situation and are aware of next medical options and recommendations. EHE attempts to smooth your path — both in terms of understanding the health concern, and in getting access to primary care physicians and specialists. EHE will contact you six months later to see if there’s been follow-up on recommendations pertaining to the specific issue(s). The goal is to remove any obstacles preventing you from getting the targeted medical attention you need. There is no additional charge for a full year after the EHE exam for any clinical intervention services. EHE also provides travel medicine consultation if you are planning to travel overseas. An EHE nurse serves as the initial contact and can connect you with a provider, either at one of EHE’s locations or in the EHE physicians network. You can also reach out to EHE for travel medicine recommendations separately from any existing clinical intervention process.   Referral Coordination If you have significant exam findings or otherwise need assistance getting set up with a primary care physician or specialist, EHE offers referral coordination based on your existing insurance. EHE can help you establish contact with doctors (and transfer medical records, make a first appointment, etc.) in any geographic area, focusing on physicians with reasonable availability who meet EHE’s standards of quality care. You can also request referrals on your own through the secure EHE + Me portal. The site also lets you have access to your medical records for use whenever you need them.

It is clear that a healthy workforce is a happier, more creative, and more productive one. A culture of workplace wellness engages the full spectrum of health-oriented measures: preventive medical screenings
post_excerpt: nutrition and fitness guidance

post_author: a number of key practices are applicable across a variety of office environments. The following strategies help reduce absenteeism
post_date: turnover
post_content: while also maximizing employee satisfaction and the bottom line.

ID: • Communicate Employee Value — Employees who feel valued
post_author: and are able to trust their employer
post_date: have a greater sense of motivation
post_content: and morale at work. All of these factors contribute to overall company success. The key is to cultivate a workplace culture of mutual respect
post_excerpt: direct communication.

ID: • Invest in a Preventive Health Care Program — Preventive medical screenings are crucial to keeping workers well. Early detection protocols help identify illnesses at the earliest stages
post_author: when they are easiest to treat and potentially cure. It's an incredibly useful step toward building a healthy workforce.

ID: • Go Smoke-Free — Encourage and incentivize smoking cessation in the workplace. Organize a challenge for those employees who need to quit
post_author: and award bonuses for progress. Adhere to a strict no-smoking policy
post_date: and provide smoking cessation support programs for workers.

ID: • Create Fitness Challenges — Some healthy (wellness-oriented) competition can be fun and motivating for employers and employees alike. Physical fitness reduces the risk of chronic illnesses and lowers stress
post_author: and some friendly games with colleagues supports team building while boosting morale.

ID: • Implement Fitness Programs — Subsidized gym memberships and yoga classes
post_author: weight loss competitions
post_date: walking meetings
post_content: are just some great options to get your team moving. Offer incentives to encourage your employees to participate; whether it’s a prize
post_excerpt: or morning off
post_status: there are many ways to inexpensively reward participation.

ID: • Encourage Flexible Schedules — Offering remote work days
post_author: and allowing employees to set their own schedules (when possible) is a powerful way to reduce workplace stress. Studies show that more flex time increases employee satisfaction
post_date: and increases overall productivity.

ID: • Allow Pets at Work — Barring any allergies
post_author: this is a great way to reduce stress and increase morale and positivity in the workplace. If space or employee volume is an issue
post_date: create a rotating schedule allowing employees to bring their companion animals to work on a given day.

post_author: as well as walking breaks outdoors. Movement breaks are vital for stress relief and rest throughout the day. Moreover
post_date: getting up and moving encourages better cardiovascular health
post_date_gmt: lessening the risk of blood clots and heart disease.

ID: • Bring (Real) Plants to the Office — The increased oxygen provided by plants increases air quality
post_author: and studies show that having plants in the workplace increases productivity
post_date: and reduces absenteeism. Plants also create a more pleasant and welcoming work environment.

ID: • Encourage Employee Vacations — Taking regular time off reduces stress and increases productivity. Studies show that vacations also help prevent heart disease. Time away lets employees recharge and rest
post_author: returning to the workplace with renewed energy and focus.

ID: A healthy workforce is an investment that improves your bottom line
post_author: while giving vital support to the team responsible for the company's success. Creating a great work culture of wellness nurtures and sustains vigorous
post_date: productive
post_date_gmt: and innovative employees. And as outlined above

post_title: effective ways to encourage a healthy workforce.

Posture refers to how your body is positioned when sitting or standing, as well as its alignment when you are lying down. Often, we are only aware of our posture when we're engaged in an activity like yoga that requires attention to specific positioning. But
post_status: 00.html\">healthy posture throughout the day is critical to limiting stress on ligaments
ping_status: and tendons. Poor posture can lead to chronic pain and may increase your chance of injury. Good posture places the body in correct alignment so stress is properly distributed across muscles and ligaments. When this alignment is as it should be
post_password: the muscles work more efficiently and as intended
post_name: reducing wear and tear on the joints. Healthy posture decreases the risk of osteoarthritis and various stress-related injuries
to_ping: and improves balance and bodily stability.

ID: • Facilitates better breathing by opening up the lungs.
• Decreases stress on the ligaments holding spinal joints in place.
<li>Keeps joints and bones from becoming set in abnormal positions
post_author: ensuring muscles are used correctly.

ID: • Decreases wear and tear on joint surfaces.
<li>Maximizes energy and decreases fatigue; when muscles are being used efficiently
post_author: the body expends less effort.

ID: <li>Shoulders should be even; roll shoulders up
post_author: then back and down — the collar bones should feel open.

ID: • Chin should be parallel to the floor.
• Keep your spine in a neutral position; do not over flex or arch the back.
• Let arms fall to your sides with your elbows even.
• Body weight should be equally distributed on both feet.
• Neck ought to be straight — not too far forward or too far back. You can check your profile in a mirror to see if your head and neck are in good alignment.

post_author: keep shoulders in correct alignment
post_date: chin parallel to the floor
post_date_gmt: and hips and knees facing forward.

ID: You can achieve better posture with some simple
post_author: targeted exercises. The goal is to increase core strength and flexibility. Utilizing balance-specific exercises that address posture will facilitate improvements you will begin to feel in just a few weeks.

ID: Now that you know why it’s important to build and maintain good posture
post_author: let’s look at some habits that may be sabotaging your efforts:

ID: • Poor work ergonomics. If your desk or chair is not at the right height for your body
post_author: it can contribute to poor posture. It’s a good idea to have an ergonomics expert analyze your work setup to ensure it’s right for you.

ID: <li>Too little activity and a sedentary lifestyle. If you’re sitting at your desk all day
post_author: with no fitness or walking breaks
post_date: that increases your chances of developing poor posture. Be sure to make the time for exercise or activity of some kind. Movement also decreases compression on your spine
post_date_gmt: which is exacerbated by prolonged sitting. Spinal compression is a contributing factor to poor posture.

ID: <li>Imbalanced fitness training. It is important to exercise in a way that emphasizes balanced strength and development throughout the body. Be sure to strengthen the back

post_date: if necessary

One visualization that can help you maintain good posture is to imagine a string starting in your heels
post_author: going all the way up through your legs and spine
post_date: and then up and out through the top of your head. If someone were to pull the string from the top of your head

post_content: imagine the string starting at your tailbone
post_title: and being pulled from there up through the top of your head. Sit upright
post_excerpt: breathe

ID: Being mindful of your posture is not difficult

Breast cancer develops when breast tissue cells form a malignancy. This happens when there's a disruption in the tissue's ordinary life cycle — new cells grow when the body doesn’t need them; old
post_title: damaged cells do not die off as they should; and the resulting buildup becomes a tumor. These malignant cells can spread by breaking off from the original growth and entering other body systems through lymph and blood vessels. Metastasis occurs when cancer cells travel
post_excerpt: damaging other organs and body tissues.

ID: • Breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer in women.
• Breast cancer is the second-leading cause of cancer-related death among women.
<li>Most breast cancers are found in women who are age 50 or older
post_author: but it can also affect younger women. Approximately 10 percent of breast cancer cases occur in women under the age of 45.

ID: • One in eight women in the United States will be diagnosed with breast cancer in her lifetime.

post_author: but it is far more rare. Less than one percent of breast cancer cases occur in men.
000 women are diagnosed with breast cancer in the United States each year
post_date: and more than 40

ID: • There are more than 2.8 million breast cancer survivors in the United States.

post_author: the main factors that influence your risk of breast cancer are age and having a predisposition via mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes. But many women who are diagnosed have no family history of the disease
post_date: and it's important to know other potential risk factors. Here are ways you can reduce your personal risk:

ID: • Commit to regular exercise — at least four hours per week.

post_author: or limit intake to no more than one drink per day.
fresh
post_date: plant-centered diet.

post_author: and limit your sugar and refined carbohydrate intake.

ID: <li>Limit exposure to radiation from medical imaging tests
post_author: such as X-rays and CT scans.

ID: • Avoid and limit exposure to known carcinogens (chemicals which cause cancer).
<li>Discuss the risks of hormone replacement therapy
post_author: oral contraception (birth control pills)
post_date: and hormonal birth control methods with your doctor.

ID: <li>Take steps to improve your sleep if needed
post_author: and get 8 hours of sleep each night.

ID: Be vigilant about breast cancer detection
post_author: and perform a breast self-exam each month. If you notice any changes in your breasts
post_date: such as lumps or skin changes
post_date_gmt: consult your physician right away. Also discuss the benefits and risks of mammograms and other screening procedures. Breast cancer prevention starts with healthy habits and taking action.

post_author: Breast Cancer Awareness Month: What You Should Know
post_content: open
What is the link between estrogen and breast cancer?

post_author: of course
post_date: is vital to sexual development and many important bodily functions. Before menopause
post_date_gmt: estrogen is produced mainly in the ovaries. After menopause
post_content: it is produced mostly in fat tissue. Throughout both her reproductive and post-menopausal years
post_title: a woman is exposed to different levels of estrogen from various sources.

ID: Estrogen and breast cancer have at least some correlation. High levels of estrogen over long periods of time are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. A meta analysis of data from several different studies shows that higher blood estrogen levels in premenopausal women increases breast cancer risk. Women who have an earlier first menstrual period or a later menopause are more likely to develop breast cancer.
Estrogen and Breast Cancer: Effect of Hormone Replacement Therapy
Estrogen is sometimes prescribed to treat the symptoms of menopause
post_author: such as night sweats
post_date: sleeplessness
post_date_gmt: and hot flashes. Estrogen also provides the benefit of lowering the risk of bone thinning
post_content: or osteoporosis. That said
post_title: a large-scale clinical trial has was shown that the risks of hormone replacement therapy (estrogen plus progesterone) can be significant. Combined hormone therapy with estrogen and progesterone increases the incidence of blood clots
post_excerpt: heart disease
comment_status: prolonged exposure to high levels of estrogen increases the risk of uterine and breast cancers.

ID: Estrogen-only hormone replacement therapy has also been shown to elevate breast cancer risk
post_author: but combined hormone replacement therapy increases that risk more substantially. High estrogen levels encourage cell division in the uterine and breast tissues
post_date: and cells that are actively dividing are thought to have a greater chance of DNA damage. The more cells with DNA damage
post_date_gmt: the higher the chance of developing cancer.

ID: Blood estrogen levels are affected by a number of variables. Some of these are under your control. You can regulate your blood estrogen levels by:
<li>Keeping your weight in check. Fatty tissue impacts estrogen production
post_author: and by maintaining a healthy weight
post_date: you decrease your breast cancer risk

ID: • Getting and staying physically active. Exercise at least four hours per week.
• Limiting your alcohol intake. Avoiding alcohol consumption entirely is best.
These action steps can help keep your estrogen levels in check
post_author: and help lower your risk of breast cancer and other chronic diseases.

ID: There are additional measures you can take to combat overall cancer risks. These include:

post_author: whole foods
post_date: plant-centered diet. Limit or avoid refined sugars
post_content: and processed meats. Opt for whole grains
post_excerpt: moderate amounts of healthy fats
post_status: and an abundance of fresh fruits and vegetables.

post_author: and watch for any changes in skin and breast tissue.

ID: • Manage and reduce stress as much as possible.
• Get eight hours of quality sleep each night.
Estrogen and breast cancer may be linked
post_author: but the keys to lowering your risk are education and engagement. Healthy lifestyle choices and preventive screenings are critical. Not every illness can be anticipated or prevented
post_date: but by focusing on wellness
post_date_gmt: you can embrace habits that will boost and optimize your ability to stave off disease.

Rewiring the Fight or Flight Response  Relaxation therapy uses a combination of techniques including breathing
post_excerpt: and guided imagery to help regulate the body’s stress response. The approach is applicable in a variety of situations. Whether we are coping with ongoing chronic stress or a specific stressful event
comment_status: helping to moderate physical and emotional tension. Many related practices can be learned without professional assistance. But it is useful to seek guidance from a trained practitioner to understand how to mitigate the body’s stress responses with relaxation therapy.

ID: Stress affects the body. After a triggering incident
post_author: our autonomic nervous system activates the “fight or flight” response. Breathing and heartbeat quicken
post_date: and blood vessels throughout the body dilate in order to prepare either to fight a potential adversary or flee the situation. By utilizing relaxation therapy
post_date_gmt: we help the body to reverse the effects of the stress response on the nervous system
post_content: restoring physical and emotional equilibrium. The cornerstone of good relaxation therapy is learning how to regulate breathing. We first recognize the status of our breathing in the midst of the stress response
post_title: and then we consciously and gradually slow the rate down to a more relaxed pace. As breathing normalizes
post_excerpt: so does the heartbeat. This helps the body shift out of \"fight or flight.\"

ID: It is known that stressed workers are sicker

post_date: and less productive. They also have higher rates of addiction

post_title: and cardiovascular disease. <span style=\"font-size: 16px;\">When employees utilize stress reduction and relaxation therapy

Depression is not simply feeling sad, despite how it's frequently characterized in our culture. There are many types of depression, and it can be a very complex disease. Additionally
post_title: the symptoms differ in severity and duration from person to person. That said
post_excerpt: depression is often distinguished by prolonged periods of hopelessness
post_password: and a number of other mood disturbances. It is important to understand depression's warning signs so that it can be treated effectively.

post_author: anxious
post_date: or desolate mood that persists

ID: • Sleep disturbances such as insomnia or hypersomnia (oversleeping)
• Cognitive problems such as difficulty concentrating or remembering things

post_author: chronic frustration
post_date: or pessimism

ID: • Thoughts of suicide and / or suicide attempts
<li>Chronic physical symptoms that do not correspond to an underlying medical condition
post_author: such as digestive problems
post_date: persistent headaches

ID: • Loss of interest in activities one usually enjoys

Depression is diagnosed when a person has experienced some or all of these symptoms for two weeks or longer. It is important to seek help from a licensed mental health professional as early as possible. Depression can be difficult to treat
post_author: particularly when it has persisted for a while. Also
post_date: different types of depression may need specialized support.

ID: • Major Clinical Depression: The most commonly diagnosed form of depression
post_author: characterized by hopelessness and a profoundly depressed mood that persists for more than two weeks.
but symptoms are complex and chronic while lasting for two years or longer.

ID: • Seasonal Affective Disorder: Sufferers experience the symptoms depression
post_author: but tied to seasonal change
post_date: usually taking place in fall or winter
post_date_gmt: when sunlight decreases and the days become shorter.

ID: • Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood: Characterized by the typical symptoms of major depression
post_author: but the disordered mood is in response to a life event or change resulting in a significant stress increase.

ID: • Postpartum Depression: The hormones estrogen and progesterone increase dramatically in a woman’s body during pregnancy
post_author: but rapidly drop to normal levels soon after delivery (postpartum). In some women
post_date: this hormonal drop can trigger the symptoms of major depression
post_date_gmt: and is more likely to recur with subsequent pregnancies. Early intervention is key.

ID: There is no shame in seeking treatment for depression — or any other mental health condition. Mental health awareness is increasing
post_author: and old stigmas rooted in outdated misinformation should never interfere with someone getting the assistance he or she needs. It takes strength and courage to ask for help. Treatment for depression is often a combination of interventions
post_date: tailored to the individual's unique set of biological
post_content: and social factors. Types of depression also require different types of treatment. What's effective in one context may not affect change in another. Treatment takes time and patience
post_excerpt: psychotherapy
ping_status: and nutritional and lifestyle modifications. There is also evidence that mindfulness meditation techniques are helpful in treating some forms of depression. Help is available
post_password: and despite how difficult depression can be
post_name: with the appropriate social support and treatment plan

Good brain food is critical to wellness. It's important for mental and cognitive health to nourish our brains with the proper balance of nutrients. Including quality brain food in your diet will help keep your mind sharp and clear for as long as possible. The brain responds powerfully to the right fuel
post_excerpt: fats
post_status: and antioxidants from fresh fruits and vegetables. The following foods help prevent inflammation and degenerative diseases

ID: Fish - Essential fatty acids (EFAs) cannot be manufactured by the body
post_author: so we need to get them from our diets. Oily fish like wild salmon
post_date: mackerel
post_content: and tuna are great sources of omega-3 fatty acids in the form of EPA and DHA. (Excellent plant-based sources of brain-boosting fats are walnuts
post_excerpt: chia
post_status: and pumpkin seeds.) These EFAs help preserve brain function while also promoting good cardiovascular and musculoskeletal health. Not only do EPA and DHA decrease the risk of Alzheimer’s disease and dementia
comment_status: they also help promote the production of the feel-good brain chemical
post_password: which helps us manage stress and regulate mood.

ID: Diet tip: Choose only wild fish. When eating salmon
post_author: wild Alaskan is best. Also
post_date: limit tuna to no more than six ounces per week to minimize mercury exposure.

post_author: particularly blueberries
post_date: are loaded with antioxidants
post_date_gmt: which help promote brain health and function. Blueberries are especially excellent for overall health: they're low glycemic
post_content: high in fiber
post_title: and have been positively linked to lowered Alzheimer’s risk. Evidence also suggests that blueberries help improve memory and protect against general cognitive decline.

ID: Diet tip: Eat a serving of blueberries every day. Whenever possible
post_author: buy organic berries. When out of season
post_date: organic frozen berries are a good option (great for smoothies). Other fantastic brain-boosting varieties include cranberries
post_content: and cherries.

post_author: lycopene
post_date: tomatoes help protect against free radical damage in cells
post_date_gmt: helping to stave off dementia and other degenerative diseases.

ID: Diet tip: Lycopene increases when tomatoes are cooked. Opt for organic
post_author: low sugar tomato sauces
post_date: or try gently roasting your tomatoes with a drizzle of olive oil.

ID: Avocados - Avocados are the highest in protein and lowest in sugar of any fruit
post_author: making them among the healthiest foods you can eat. Packed with vitamins C and B
post_date: and rich in folate and vitamin K
post_date_gmt: avocados are protective against strokes and blood clots in the brain. They also help improve memory and overall cognitive function. Their high vitamin E content fights the onset of Alzheimer’s and dementia.

ID: Diet tip: Add about a quarter to half of an avocado to your smoothies. Avocados also make a great fat replacement for your favorite baked goods.
Broccoli - High levels of choline and vitamin K help keep your memory healthy and sharp
post_author: making broccoli a terrific brain food. Just one cup of broccoli provides about 150 percent of the daily recommended intake of vitamin C.

ID: Diet tip: Lightly steam your broccoli until bright green but still firm (about four minutes)
post_author: and add to eggs
post_date: whole grain pasta
post_date_gmt: or as a side dish to your meal. You can also add raw florets to your salads
post_content: or serve with a veggie tray and a healthy dip.

ID: Dark Chocolate (Cacao) - Cacao is a great brain food loaded with flavanols
post_author: which have anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties
post_date: promoting robust circulation and blood flow to the brain.

ID: Diet tip: Opt for organic dark chocolate bars of 70 percent or higher to keep exposure to refined and added sugars to a minimum. Your best bet is 100 percent raw
post_author: organic cacao with no added sugar — this is a wonderful addition to smoothies
post_date: and great for healthier baking at home.

ID: Remember that eating for overall systemic health goes hand in hand with eating good brain food. While certain foods offer particular support for the brain (the above list is by no means exhaustive)
post_author: a diet of whole foods
post_date: primarily centered on plants and fresh produce
post_date_gmt: will support your body and brain health in profound ways. What we eat is vital to sustaining memory
post_content: mental clarity
post_title: and cognitive function across our life spans.

Stress is not always a negative thing. In moderate amounts, it can motivate us and increase our concentration and clarity. But when life or workplace stress becomes chronic
post_title: the symptoms can be incredibly detrimental to our wellbeing. Stress management becomes essential. Here are ten techniques that will help your stress management
post_excerpt: keeping you mentally and physically healthy even when pressure hits.

ID: • Exercise at least three times per week. Exercise releases endorphins
post_author: which help you relax and feel better. Many fitness activities
post_date: including yoga
post_date_gmt: also stimulate the parasympathetic nervous system (the part of your nervous system which resets and calms your stress response). And if that wasn't enough
post_content: regular exercise also improves sleep.

ID: • Practicing meditation has been shown to decrease symptoms of stress and anxiety while facilitating calmness and overall mental wellbeing. Meditation is also good cognitive training — it retrains us to observe and release negative thought patterns. And the benefits of meditation accumulate over time. So find a method you enjoy
post_author: and add it to your stress management regimen.

ID: • Try progressive muscle relaxation (deep muscle relaxation). Progressively tense each muscle group
post_author: breathe deeply
post_date: and then release. It's particularly helpful to do this before going to sleep.

ID: • Make a list of important work and personal tasks you need to accomplish each day. Working through your daily list will help you feel organized and on top of things
post_author: giving you a sense of mastery over your schedule and workload.
rest
post_date: and eat your meals mindfully. Try to avoid letting your mealtime be disturbed. Avoid stressful or upsetting conversation while eating. Allow yourself both nourishment and some separation from the daily grind.

ID: • Practice good sleep hygiene. Structure your sleep schedule so that you are going to bed and waking up at the same time each day. Lower the lights and turn off your phone and devices at least one hour before bedtime
post_author: and sleep in a well-darkened room.
our breathing tends to be shallow and centered in the chest. Diaphragmatic breathing (deep breathing) helps to regulate the body’s stress response and increases feelings of calm.

ID: • Seek support. Find at least one person you can confide in and share your concerns tied to the matters causing you stress. The more social support you have
post_author: the more stress resilience you will develop. If you feel isolated
post_date: you may need to create more community in your life. Seek out new activities
post_date_gmt: join an adult recreational sports team for connection and exercise
post_content: or take a new class to connect with others who have similar interests.

ID: • Laugh more. Make a point of watching funny movies or stand-up comedy. Regular laughter is one of the easiest and most effective stress management devices. It lowers stress hormones in the body
post_author: relaxes your muscles to release tension
post_date: and helps put things in perspective.

ID: • Learn to say no. Set boundaries around your life demands as much as possible to avoid becoming overloaded. Delegate responsibilities when you can
post_author: and give yourself permission to implement limits on how much you can take on at a given time. You might encounter some friction in your relationships as others adjust to these new boundaries
post_date: but you are ensuring better mental and physical health (and relationships) in the long run by learning to say no.

ID: Cultivating stress management is a key component good mental health hygiene. Unchecked stress is a major contributing factor to illness. Making time for self-care is crucial to staying well in the long term. While it takes vigilance and effort to ensure you are properly moderating stress
post_author: it's well worth the investment.

October is Domestic Violence Awareness Month, an opportunity to address a destructive and widespread health crisis. While it takes many forms, domestic violence is characterized by an intimate partner's pattern of abusive behavior. This abuse can include psychological, sexual, and physical elements. It can start when the relationship does, or it can emerge after time. It can be conspicuous to others or hidden behind closed doors. It can occur in an established marriage or in a brand new romance. It affects victims across socioeconomic and educational levels, sexual orientations, and ethnic backgrounds. While the majority of cases involve a male perpetrator and a female victim, domestic violence can also victimize men or people of either gender in a same-sex relationship. Statistics About Domestic Violence and Abuse
  • More than one in three women (35.6%) in the United States has experienced rape, physical violence, and/or stalking by an intimate partner
  • One in four women (24.3%) and one in seven men (13.8%) in the United States have experienced severe physical violence by an intimate partner
  • Almost half of all women (48.4%) have experienced psychological aggression by an intimate partner
  • Women between 18 and 34 years old generally experience the highest rates of domestic violence
  • Roughly 15% of all violent crime in the United States is intimate partner violence
At its core, domestic violence is about power. One partner uses abusive tactics to control the other. The abuse can be physically damaging, emotionally manipulative, and/or psychologically isolating. Many people assume domestic violence (also labeled intimate partner violence) refers only to dramatic instances of physical assault. But the abuse can be more subtle and insidious while still causing deep, lasting damage. It's important to recognize the signs of potential abuse to ensure that your relationship — or those involving your family and friends — is healthy and safe. Warnings Signs of Domestic Violence and Abuse Abuse consolidates control with one partner through a combination of tactics including (but not limited to): physical threats and attacks, stalking, sexual coercion and violence, social isolation, emotional degradation and manipulation, repeated threats, and management of all aspects of the other's life. Over time, the pattern of behavior erode's the victim's independence, self-esteem, and wherewithal to escape. An abusive partner may:
  • Isolate partner from friends and family
  • Insult, ridicule, or demean partner
  • Coerce partner into sex
  • Control partner's actions and decisions
  • Undermine partner's studies or career
  • Threaten to harm partner's loved ones
  • Make partner feel guilty
  • Be violent toward pets
  • Exploit partner's finances or control his or her money
  • Express intense jealousy or possessiveness
  • Gaslight partner (intentionally cause partner to doubt his or her own sanity)
  • Blame partner for anything that goes wrong
  • Take advantage of partner's insecurities
  • Have an unpredictable or easily triggered temper
  • Refuse to give partner privacy in the home or online
Often, an abuser will successfully mask his or her temperament when interacting with people outside the relationship. Perpetrators often come across as \charming
post_title: \" which can be how they attract partners in the first place. Moreover
post_excerpt: an abusive partner typically either minimizes the severity of the physical or psychological abuse or deflects the blame
post_status: pinning it on external circumstances like stress or even the victim. Such tactics are consistent with the nature of the abuse itself. Perpetrators seek control
comment_status: and they'll typically manipulate the image of the relationship in order to preserve their domination.

ID: Domestic Violence or Abuse Effects on the Abused
It can be difficult to see an intimate partner's abuse for what it is
post_author: or to escape a relationship that's become dangerous. Many times
post_date: the victim will find it easier to placate an abuser than to risk more violence or abuse by standing up to it. But even in situations where a victim believes he or she can \"manage\" or \"survive\" the level of abuse
post_date_gmt: there are devastating effects that accumulate over time. Victims of domestic violence or abuse may experience:

ID: • Anger or guilt toward themselves for the situation
• Fear for the wellbeing of their children and other loved ones
• Anxiety over how to survive without partner
• Shame over allowing abuse to persist and worsen

These effects explain part of the reason why it can be so difficult for abuse victims to leave a relationship in which they are being badly harmed. There are also social obstacles — lacking familiarity with healthy relationships means people often wrongly believe abuse is normal; religious traditions may make an imbalance of power seem appropriate; often
post_author: victims fear backlash from friends and family who will \"judge\" them harshly. Additionally
post_date: many victims still feel love or affection for their abusers and are reluctant to sever ties.

ID: How to Get Help for Domestic Violence or Abuse
But domestic violence and abuse should never be tolerated. It is destructive and must be escaped. The dangers are real
post_author: varied
post_date: and impact the victim in ways he or she may not realize. It's important to realize that help exists
post_date_gmt: and to reach out as soon as possible. Here are some resources:

ID: National Resource Center on Domestic Violence (1-800-799-7233)
"

post_content: One of the best forms of exercise is simple
post_excerpt: and overlooked. Going for regular walks is great for your health. It can help you reduce stress
ping_status: and keep chronic illnesses at bay — and all you need is a pair of comfortable shoes. Here are some of the benefits of walking just 30 minutes a day.

ID: • Elevate and improve your mood - Walking can help alleviate symptoms of depression and lift your mood. Studies have shown that walking for 30 minutes a day can be as effective as antidepressant medications for some people.
• Slim down - Regular walking is one of the best low-impact ways to lose weight and trim your waistline. Daily walking increases metabolism
post_author: burns calories
post_date: and protects against muscle loss. It also improves the body’s insulin response

ID: • Improve circulation - Walking helps ward off varicose veins
post_author: prevents heart disease
post_date: strengthens the heart
post_date_gmt: and lowers blood pressure. Studies have found that post-menopausal women who walked one to two miles per day lowered their blood pressure by 11 points in just 24 weeks. Women who walked 30 minutes per day also slashed their risk of stroke by 20 percent.

ID: • Boost your creativity - The benefits of walking are often unexpected. A recent study shows that regular walking heightens creativity and improves divergent and convergent thinking
post_author: both of which are associated with high levels of creative thinking and problem solving.

ID: • Deepen and improve your sleep - Walking can help you fall asleep faster
post_author: sleep more soundly
post_date: and prevents and improves insomnia. A walk in the early morning hours can be especially helpful keeping you in sync with your circadian rhythms and sleep cycle.

ID: • Heighten immunity - Regular walking and exercise helps boost your immune system. Because it's also helpful for reducing excess weight and belly fat
post_author: it reduces your risk of developing chronic illnesses like cancers and Type 2 diabetes.

ID: • Reduce pain - Walking may help lessen symptoms and reduce discomfort for those suffering with chronic pain conditions
post_author: such as fibromyalgia and arthritis. The gentle
post_date: low-impact nature of walking can help improve functioning while reducing pain.

ID: • Improve and maintain memory - Walking boosts function in the hippocampus — the part of the brain involved in learning and memory. Research has shown that age-related memory impairment is lessened in those who regularly walk.
• Bolster bone strength - The physical benefits of walking can be long-term. For instance
post_author: it can help strengthen your bones and reduce the risk of osteoporosis. One study shows that women who walk for at least 4 hours per week have a 40 percent reduced risk of hip fractures. While many other forms of exercise (such as weightlifting and running) also offer bone strengthening benefits
post_date: walking is an excellent low-impact option.

ID: • Keep your brain sharp and slow the aging process - Regular walking is shown to maintain cognitive function
post_author: and lower the risk of age-related dementia
post_date: Alzheimer’s disease
post_date_gmt: and other brain disorders. Researchers have also found that those who walk for exercise have preserved and lengthened telomeres
post_content: the parts of our DNA that shorten as we age. Regular walkers tend to look younger than their years — and may be younger on a cellular level

post_author: preventing illness
post_date: boosting mood
post_date_gmt: and improving your overall quality of life
post_content: exercise is tough to beat. Walking is an easy way to reap the benefits of exercise with a no-cost
post_title: low-impact workout that gets you outside in the fresh air. Just 30 minutes a day
post_excerpt: several days a week
post_status: is all it takes to see improvement thanks to the benefits of walking.

Few foods represent autumn better than butternut squash. Roasted, this vegetable caramelizes into a buttery, decadent treat. We've taken the roasting process one step further to create this simple yet incredibly flavorful butternut squash soup that will wow anyone. Fall is peak season for butternut squash, so the flavor will be at its best. In addition to serving as an ideal base for a blended soup, butternut squash has a number of health benefits. It's full of dietary fiber, which improves digestion and lowers the risk for heart disease. It's also rich in B6, which helps elevate your moods, improves brain function, and facilitates healthy blood pressure levels. The rich, orange hue of butternut squash can be credited to nutrients known as carotenoids. Carotenoids are a type of antioxidant commonly found in yellow, orange, and red produce. They protect eye health, prevent cardiovascular disease, help skin health, and even improve male fertility. Eating carotenoid-rich foods with fat helps improve its bioavailability to the body, so drizzling a little olive oil on top of the squash is a great idea for both flavor and health. Beyond adding even more taste to the butternut squash soup, sage has long been used for its medicinal purposes. The oils found in sage are both antiseptic and antibacterial, making it the perfect herb to choose as cold and flu season kicks into high gear. Sage is also rich in vitamin K, which helps activate proteins produced by the liver, ensuring proper blood clotting. Bone metabolism (which allows us to replace old bone cells with healthy ones) and the regulation of calcium in the blood are two other important tasks in which vitamin K plays a role. Choosing high quality, organic vegetable broth makes this butternut squash soup vegan and yields even more health benefits. The broth helps hydrate the body, which improves digestion, regulates body temperature, increases circulation and energy, and prevents muscle cramps. Additionally, the broth retains many of the antioxidants and minerals found in the vegetables and herbs used to make it. Saving produce scraps you'd otherwise toss and storing them in the freezer is a great way to utilize food waste and produce a homemade vegetable broth.

ID: <strong>Step 1: Preheat oven to 425 degrees. Cut butternut squash in half
post_author: scoop out seeds
post_date: and place on a baking sheet flesh side up. Coat in olive oil
post_content: and pepper. Roast for 45-60 minutes
post_title: until flesh is golden brown and easily pierced with a fork.

post_author: prepare vegetables. Peel and chop onion
post_date: shallot
post_date_gmt: and garlic. Pick off 5-6 sage leaves
post_content: and leave 1-2 sage sprigs whole (leaves attached to stem). Peel sweet potato.

ID: <strong>Step 3: Steam sweet potato until easily pierced with a fork. While sweet potato steams
post_author: add olive oil and onions to a saute pan over medium heat. Saute onions for 4-5 minutes
post_date: then add shallots and garlic

ID: <strong>Step 4: Pour broth over onions. Add thyme and sage leaves (the ones attached to the stem)
post_author: and set the individual sage leaves aside for use later. Simmer for 10 minutes
post_date: then remove from heat. Remove sage and thyme and discard.

ID: Step 5: Place sweet potato and squash flesh (scoop from skin) into blender. Pour over broth and blend on high.

post_author: fry sage leaves in olive oil for 60-90 seconds until crispy and lightly browned. Top your butternut squash soup with sage and serve!

post_content: open

Walking meditation can be a wonderful addition to your self-care regimen. It’s also a helpful introduction to sitting meditation, as it’s easier for some people to do first. The renowned Buddhist monk Thich Nhat Hanh has said that the “practice of mindful walking is a profound and pleasurable way to deepen our connection with our body and the earth.\ While most of us walk only to get from one place to the next
post_title: walking meditation asks us to refocus attention on the act itself — to be mindful of how we walk and our level of presence. Evidence suggests that the health benefits of meditation increase the more we practice. To start
post_excerpt: though
post_status: it's worth trying walking meditation for just 10 minutes a day for a week. Like they say: baby steps.

ID: Walking meditation is usually slower than a typical stroll
post_author: and it incorporates breathing coordination or other focusing techniques. Part of its beauty is its simplicity: walking meditation does not need to be a time-consuming or complicated activity
post_date: nor does it require a specific setting. It teaches us to bring mindfulness into one of our primary actions. It also serves as an excellent starting point for beginning meditators
post_date_gmt: as it’s closer to our everyday experiences and routines than traditional sitting forms of meditation.

ID: Walking meditation teaches us to pay attention to the movements of our body
post_author: legs
post_date: and feet
post_date_gmt: as we walk. Unlike seated meditation practices
post_content: walking meditation gives us a deeper interaction with the world around us; our eyes remain open as we walk
post_excerpt: and attend to our mindfulness.

ID: Walking meditation is best done outdoors
post_author: and it is recommended that it not be combined with other activities (such as exercise or running errands). It’s best to let this walk be focused solely on meditation so you can immerse yourself in the experience with undivided attention.

ID: <li>Choose a time and place that will allow you to walk undisturbed
post_author: peacefully
post_date: and without traffic. Try to do your meditation at the same time each day. Begin by standing still
post_content: relaxed breaths. Place your attention on the breath to start
post_title: then allow your breathing to return to normal while you continue observing
post_excerpt: but without forcing the breath. Now bring your awareness to all of your body. Notice any sensations as they arise
post_status: and fully absorb how your body feels as you stand and breathe.

post_author: begin walking. Walk at a somewhat slower pace than you normally might
post_date: and notice all the sensations in your body as you walk
post_date_gmt: from head to toe. You can allow your arms and hands to swing loosely at your sides
post_content: or you can gently grasp your hands at your navel. Let your leg muscles relax
post_title: and feel down into the soles of your feet. As you observe how your body feels while walking
post_excerpt: continue gently bringing your attention back to your internal experience. The aim is to have your focus on the physical experience of walking; if you notice your mind becoming preoccupied with other thoughts
post_status: gently bring your attention back to your body's movement. Observe the sensations in as much detail as possible.

post_author: going from the soles of your feet to the top of your head
post_date: as you notice the sensations of walking. When your mind begins to wander
post_date_gmt: bring your attention back to the sensations in your body.

ID: There are some slight variations to approaching walking meditation
post_author: so find the method you like best. This is a profound yet simple practice which can help re-energize
post_date: center
post_date_gmt: and calm you. As with any meditation practice there is no set amount of time you must set aside; start with ten minutes per day if you can
post_content: but even five minutes is beneficial. Begin with what feels manageable to you
post_title: and build your practice from there.

Mammograms do not prevent breast cancer
post_title: but they are vital to the detection of the disease when it's still in its early stages and easier to treat. Diagnosing breast cancer early reduces the chance of dying from the illness by 30 percent or more. Additionally
post_excerpt: prompt detection means local cancers (which have not metastasized) are treatable without mastectomy (breast removal).

ID: A mammogram involves a low-dose X-ray that emits a minimal amount of radiation (less than a standard chest X-ray). The procedure is safe. Specialists examine the scan for any changes or abnormalities developing in the breast tissue. The primary risk mammograms carry is that false negatives and false positives are possible. Sometimes an abnormality that looks like cancer — such as a cyst or dense breast tissue — is reported but turns out to be benign. Normal breast tissue also sometimes conceals cancer that fails to show up on the scan.
Both false positives and false negatives can cause stress and upset
post_author: and the limitations in mammography mean additional screening methods may be necessary. Performing breast self-exams and getting regular clinical breast exams from your healthcare provider are also important. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and other scanning techniques are sometimes ordered to analyze the breast tissue. But mammography is still the most powerful method for detecting abnormalities.

ID: It is recommended that women begin having yearly mammograms by age 40
post_author: or earlier if they are at high risk. By age 55
post_date: a mammogram every other year is recommended. Regardless of age
post_date_gmt: all women should report any changes in their breasts to their doctor.

ID: • Where to go - Find a facility that is FDA-certified and specializes in mammograms. If possible
post_author: go to the same location annually so that your imaging can be easily monitored over time. If you are being seen at a new facility
post_date: provide the radiologist with your previous scans so they can be analyzed against your new ones.

ID: • When to go - It is best to schedule your mammogram the week after your menstrual period. Your breasts are less likely to be swollen or tender at this time
post_author: so results are clearer
post_date: and the test will be more comfortable.

ID: • An abnormal result does not mean you definitely have breast cancer - About 10 percent of women receive results that require further testing
post_author: and while 8 to 10 percent of these women require a biopsy
post_date: about 80 percent of these biopsies are benign.

ID: • The procedure is fast - A mammogram only takes about 20 minutes
post_author: and discomfort is minimal for most women. To avoid the anxiety of waiting for results
post_date: choose a facility that will provide them before you leave.

ID: • Don’t apply deodorant before your visit - Avoid deodorants
post_author: perfumes
post_date: powders
post_content: or creams under your arms or on your breasts. Particles in these substances can be seen on a mammogram and cause confusion. Remove any jewelry
post_excerpt: comfortable clothing to your appointment.

post_author: ibuprofen
post_date: or acetaminophen can offer relief if you experience discomfort during mammograms.

ID: The procedure takes about 20 minutes. Breast tissue is compressed between two plates for a few seconds while an X-ray scan is taken. The breast will then be repositioned and compressed again to get an image from a different angle. The process is then repeated on the other breast. Your facility may provide same-day results
post_author: or it can take up to 30 days to receive them. If your doctor finds anything of concern
post_date: you will usually be contacted within a week to take new images or undergo further tests. You doctor may also order additional tests if this is your first mammogram

ID: Medicare and nearly all private insurers cover annual mammograms with no co-pay or out-of-pocket costs. Free and lost-cost options are also available for uninsured or low-income women. Contact the American Cancer Society Helpline at 1-800-227-2345 for more information and to find a program near you.

post_author: What You Should Know About Mammograms

Halloween is about costumes, carved pumpkins, scary stories, and... candy. Lots of candy. Treats are obviously a big part of Halloween, and, as with many holidays, less-than-healthy temptations are hard to resist. But as those big bags of candy come into your house, it's worth keeping in mind just how unhealthy sugar can be in large quantities. It's not that you shouldn't be allowed to enjoy the (occasional) overindulgence on days like Halloween. But it's important to know your sugars
post_title: and to avoid sliding into any poor habits with sweets. It can be all too easy to snack mindlessly on mini candy bars and other treats as the holidays begin. But studies show sugar has addictive properties
post_excerpt: and it wreaks havoc on our health in multiple ways.

ID: The ingredients used to make candy are full of empty calories
post_author: highly processed sugars
post_date: fats
post_date_gmt: and food dyes. Bingeing on sugar will cause the pounds to add up
post_content: and many people struggle to keep sugar intake to a minimum. It’s far too easy to overdo our consumption of sugary treats.

ID: Eating too much candy leads to cavities and enamel damage. The bacteria that cause cavities feed on sugar
post_author: so the more you eat
post_date: the more these bacteria are able to multiply. These bacteria also damage gums
post_date_gmt: leading to corrosion and even tooth loss. Tacky candies like taffy
post_content: caramel
post_title: and fruit chews stick to teeth
post_excerpt: leading to enamel damage and tooth decay.

ID: Diets high in refined sugars lower the strength and effectiveness of the immune system
post_author: compromising your body's resistance to viruses and disease. Consumption of industrialized fats and sugar leads to obesity and heart disease; obesity also contributes to the development of diabetes
post_date: as well as a host of other health conditions

ID: Candy contains no vitamins or nutrients. Filling up on high-calorie candies leaves less room for nourishment from nutrient-dense foods. Sugar consumption also leaches other nutrients
post_author: such as calcium
post_date: from the body. This leads to a number of deficiencies
post_content: vitamin A and vitamin C
post_excerpt: anemia

post_author: Twizzlers
post_date: or fruit chews contain none of the fiber which helps foods move through the digestive tract. Binging on these types of treats can lead to an upset stomach
post_date_gmt: and a backed up GI tract.

ID: Commit to limiting your intake of candies this year. Better yet
post_author: avoid the the traditional Halloween treats entirely
post_date: and opt for healthier substitutions. Don’t buy those bags of mini candy bars once they go on sale
post_date_gmt: and if you really struggle with sugar
post_content: be sure not to keep it in your house. If you want to indulge a bit
post_title: have a few squares of organic dark chocolate of 70 percent cacao or higher. Learn to enjoy a few bites of something sweet in moderation
post_excerpt: without going off the deep end into a full-blown binge. When you do want to enjoy a treat
comment_status: natural products with the highest quality ingredients you can find
ping_status: and enjoy them after a full day of eating a wholesome
post_password: balanced diet. Many companies are creating healthier candies these days; while they may be more expensive
post_name: taking steps to protect your and your family’s health is worth it.

post_author: Sugar Is Scary, So Be Careful with Halloween Candy

It's vital to stay fit, as the benefits of exercise are countless. It promotes longevity
post_excerpt: and supports a vigorous immune system and overall wellness. Combined with a healthy diet
post_status: a lifelong commitment to exercise is one of the surest ways to stay healthy as you get older.

ID: While some forms of exercise are doable at any age
post_author: modifications based on life stage are important. Your needs and abilities change over time
post_date: and while a good exercise regimen will benefit you no matter when you start
post_content: the sooner the better. Here are some tips in order to stay fit at any age.

ID: Childhood is the perfect time to encourage play and an active lifestyle
post_author: building the foundation for good lifelong habits. Kids who are physically active have stronger muscles and bones
post_date: leaner bodies
post_date_gmt: decreased risk of type 2 diabetes and other chronic conditions
post_content: and better confidence and mental health. Young children and teens have a variety of fitness options available to them
post_excerpt: swimming
ping_status: and outdoor games. Fitness guidelines for children and teens recommend:

ID: • Keeping periods of inactivity (besides sleeping) to under two hours at a time
• Vigorous activity for a minimum of one hour per day
This is the perfect time to establish a daily fitness and nutrition routine
post_author: especially post-college. If you have good fitness habits in place
post_date: continue with those sports and activities you already love doing. This is the decade to emphasize cardiovascular fitness
post_date_gmt: which supports your long-term health as you get older. Aim for 30 minutes of moderate cardio exercise five days per week
post_content: or 25 minutes of intense cardio three days per week.

ID: This is the decade to emphasize core strength
post_author: especially if you plan to get pregnant
post_date: and add interval training to your cardio routine to counteract a slowing metabolism. This is also the time to shore up and maintain your muscle mass
post_date_gmt: as most people lose muscle as they age. Weight training
post_content: weight-bearing yoga postures
post_excerpt: and anything that works to strengthen and build your muscles is a must.

ID: If you are already in great shape
post_author: this is an excellent time to increase your activity and take your fitness up a notch. The more exercise the better — this will protect your muscle mass
post_date: as well as your telomeres
post_date_gmt: which are stretches of DNA that promote longevity and cellular health. Alternate between moderate and vigorous cardiovascular exercise
post_content: and continue weight training. Bike
post_excerpt: brisk walks
comment_status: or take a fun new fitness class. The key is to keep moving
ping_status: and stay active. If you are new to the fitness game
post_password: jump in - your body will respond beautifully
post_name: and you will feel and look better than ever.

ID: Lowered estrogen and fluctuating hormone levels due to menopause can lead to mood dysregulation and potential bone loss. Exercise is excellent for stabilizing moods
post_author: and weight-bearing exercises are vital to maintaining muscle and bone mass. Aim for 30 minutes of daily weight-bearing exercise
post_date: such as yoga
post_content: tennis
post_excerpt: or weight training. This is also the decade to focus on protecting leg and lower body strength. Research shows a connection between leg strength and brain health as we age. The mechanism isn’t fully understood
post_status: but one theory posits that brain-stimulating neurochemicals are released when muscles are worked
comment_status: and leg muscles are some of the largest in the body. Regardless
ping_status: physical exercise that improves brain health is doubly important to pursue.

ID: The healthier and more fit you’ve been up to this point
post_author: the better. Make adjustments as your body requires — don’t ignore illness
post_date: pains
post_date_gmt: or signs of distress. But there is no need to slow down if you still feel good. Keep moving and stay active. The better shape you're in
post_content: the greater your vitality as you age. While weight gain is common after menopause
post_title: it's still possible to drop extra pounds and trim your belly at this life stage. It's also important to sustain excellent cardiovascular health
post_excerpt: and to reduce your risk of type 2 diabetes and various cancers. Light aerobic activity
comment_status: and gardening are all great options to stay fit. Strength training continues to be important in these years
ping_status: so try to do a full body workout with medium weights for about 40 minutes twice a week in addition to cardio activities.

Sleep deprivation has many negative short-term effects. It often makes us irritable and less productive the next day. It undermines concentration and slows our reaction time. We usually feel it when we didn't get enough sleep and need to catch up the following night.

ID: But chronic sleep deprivation has long-term effects that could be even more significant. Routinely failing to get adequate sleep
post_author: whether due to a condition like insomnia or just life circumstances
post_date: has a cumulative impact on brain functioning and elevates risks for mental health issues like anxiety and depression.

ID: Sleep Deprivation: Cause or Effect of Mental Health Problems?
The medical community has long wrestled with the chicken-or-the-egg relationship between sleep loss and mental health. After all
post_author: there's a vicious cycle at work. When we're anxious
post_date: for instance
post_date_gmt: it's harder to get quality sleep
post_content: which then only increases our level of anxiety. And the overlap between poor sleep habits and psychological distress is so prevalent
post_title: it can be difficult to unpack which leads to which.

ID: Chronic sleep problems are said to affect 50% to 80% of psychiatric patients
post_author: compared with just 10% to 18% of adults in the general U.S. population. The relationship between insomnia and mental illness is frequently described as \"bidirectional.\" Sleep issues and mental health problems also exacerbate each other
post_date: creating situations where it's increasingly difficult to treat both.

ID: While causation is often tricky to decipher with mental health problems
post_author: a growing body of research indicates that sleep deprivation is a strong predictor of mood disorders. In one study
post_date: people with chronic insomnia were five times more likely to develop depression and 20 times more likely to develop a panic disorder.

ID: Experts have found that in sleep-deprived patients
post_author: the amygdala
post_date: a part of the brain that processes emotion
post_date_gmt: becomes \"rewired\" in a way that reduces our rational response to external events. These individuals have big emotional swings
post_content: going from upset to giddy in moments. Sleep deprivation can even create symptoms similar to those of schizophrenia.

post_author: however
post_date: is between insomnia and depression. In a number of studies
post_date_gmt: insomnia represented a \"substantial risk\" for the development of depressive disorders. Encouragingly
post_content: investigators have discovered that individuals with depression who improve their sleep experience a faster response from antidepressants. Experts have found that cognitive behavior therapy designed to treat insomnia has the effect of reducing depression symptoms.

ID: For severe cases of lasting and intractable insomnia
post_author: individuals should consult with a physician. But for many people
post_date: countering sleep deprivation is simply a matter of committing to improved sleep hygiene. Taking sleep seriously and making a few adjustments to your nightly routine is often enough to get back on track. And returning to adequate sleep is a preventive tool against depression and other mental health issues.

ID: Proper sleep hygiene has many components
post_author: but among the most important steps you can take:

ID: • Go to bed and wake up at the same times every day to put your body on a schedule.
• Keep your bedroom dark and not using electronics once there; the light emitted by screens confuses your body's internal clock.
<li>Exercise — regular physical activity has innumerable health benefits
post_author: including the facilitation of sleep patterns.
caffeine
post_date: and nicotine in the hours before bed whenever possible.

post_author: especially in the morning.

ID: Sleep deprivation doesn't just make you grumpy. Over time
post_author: it can lead to mental health issues and other medical problems. Addressing chronic sleeplessness before it starts to affect your daily life is a major piece of good preventive self-care.

November is National Diabetes Month, making it an excellent time to be informed about diabetes symptoms. Diabetes mellitus refers to a cluster of diseases that impact how the body utilizes blood sugar (glucose). Glucose is a vital energy source for the brain, as well as the cells that make up our tissues and muscles. But diabetes leads to too much glucose in the blood. A preventive lifestyle, including a whole foods, plant-centered diet
post_excerpt: is integral to maintaining healthy blood sugar. Diabetes symptoms can take many forms
post_status: but good health practices can mitigate most of them.

ID: Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes are different versions of the disease. Type 1 diabetes
post_author: also called juvenile diabetes
post_date: occurs when the pancreas produces little or no insulin
post_date_gmt: meaning the body cannot regulate glucose. This type cannot be prevented and usually develops during childhood or adolescence. Type 2 diabetes
post_content: which is more common
post_title: involves insulin resistance. Their bodies don't utilize insulin as they should
post_excerpt: leading to problems managing glucose. Type 2 diabetes can be prevented by lifestyle changes around nutrition and exercise.

ID: Prediabetes occurs when your blood sugar is higher than normal
post_author: but is not yet high enough to qualify as diabetes. Gestational diabetes occurs during pregnancy
post_date: but can be resolved after the baby's delivery.

ID: Due to poor diets filled with processed foods and refined sugars
post_author: as well as sedentary lifestyles
post_date: diabetes is a growing health concern across a wider range of Americans than ever before.

ID: Diabetes symptoms vary depending on how high your blood glucose levels are. In Type 1 diabetes
post_author: symptoms tend to be severe
post_date: with a more rapid onset
post_date_gmt: while those with Type 2 and prediabetes may not experience symptoms at first
post_content: or they may be somewhat mild. Women with gestational diabetes may have no symptoms
post_title: so tests are required at certain stages of pregnancy. Below are some signs and symptoms of diabetes you should be aware of:

ID: Early detection of diabetes symptoms and treatment can reduce the risk of complications. Diabetes increases your risk for various health problems
post_author: but with recommended lifestyle changes and effective treatment
post_date: many people are able to delay or prevent complications from occurring. Complications from diabetes include:

ID: • Skin Complications - Stay alert for signs of bacterial infections such as styes (infections of the eyelid glands)
post_author: boils
post_date: and folliculitis (inflammation of the hair follicles)
post_date_gmt: as well as fungal infections like Candida albicans.

ID: • Eye Complications - Keep up with regular checkups to reduce your risk of cataracts
post_author: glaucoma
post_date: and other eye conditions.

ID: • Neuropathy - Diabetic nerve damage occurs in about half of all people living with diabetes.
• Kidney Disease - Keeping diabetes and blood pressure under control will lower the risk of kidney disease (nephropathy).

post_author: blood pressure
post_date: and blood glucose to reduce risk of stroke.

post_author: high blood pressure raises your risk of heart attack
post_date: stroke
post_content: and eye complications.

post_author: but the same preventive lifestyle adjustments used to treat gestational and Type 2 diabetes
post_date: can also help prevent symptoms from developing. Remember that preventive lifestyle adjustments are for everyone; not just those managing diabetes. A fresh
post_content: maintaining a healthy weight
post_title: and keeping up with regular exercise are all key to maintaining health
post_excerpt: and reducing your risk of chronic illnesses in the long term.

ID: "
post_author: These Are Diabetes Symptoms You Should Know
post_content: open
You may think that receiving a diagnosis of insulin resistance or prediabetes is a guarantee you will develop Type 2 diabetes
post_title: but that's not the case. Insulin resistance and prediabetes are very responsive to lifestyle and dietary adjustments. Things like weight loss
post_excerpt: improved nutrition
post_status: and regular exercise can help your blood glucose levels considerably.

ID: Insulin is a hormone created by the pancreas. Insulin resistance occurs when cells in your muscles
post_author: liver
post_date: and body fat begin to resist (ignore) the signal that insulin sends out
post_date_gmt: alerting them to remove excess glucose from the blood stream. These tissues depend upon insulin to stay properly nourished; they are limited in their ability to draw glucose from the bloodstream on their own. If all systems are working as they should
post_content: blood sugar stays in balance
post_title: and the body’s muscles and tissues are well fed by the excess glucose drawn from the bloodstream.

ID: Prediabetes occurs when glucose in the bloodstream is high
post_author: but not yet high enough to be classified as diabetes. Insulin resistance
post_date: prediabetes
post_date_gmt: and Type 2 diabetes can be managed
post_content: and in many cases reversed
post_title: by the right lifestyle changes. Medication may also be prescribed.

ID: • Choose a Whole Foods Diet - Try to eat complex carbohydrates. Eliminate refined and processed starches
post_author: as well as industrially produced fats (trans fats) and processed foods
post_date: from your diet. Some good choices are vegetables
post_content: and whole grains. Complex carbohydrates are more complex on a molecular level
post_title: and take longer for the body to break down. This means they absorb more slowly
post_excerpt: helping to keep blood glucose levels stable. Complex carbs will also help you feel fuller longer
post_status: and help with weight and appetite control. Aim to eat a whole foods

ID: • Eliminate Sugary Drinks and Simple Carbohydrates - Simple sugars alone don’t cause diabetes
post_author: but they do contribute to insulin resistance and overall poor health. High fructose corn syrup is a particularly bad offender. Avoid simple carbohydrates that contain glucose
post_date: fructose
post_content: such as candies
post_excerpt: soft drinks
post_status: and added sugars and sweeteners. Learn to read food labels — you'll discover that processed foods and sweets tend to be loaded with added sugars.

ID: • Increase Fiber Intake - Research shows that eating insoluble fiber along with whole grains and complex carbohydrates reduces the risk of Type 2 diabetes. Aim to eat some insoluble fiber with each meal. Good sources include:

post_author: apples
post_date: prunes

post_author: squashes
post_date: peas

post_author: quinoa
post_date: oats

post_author: navy beans
post_date: kidney beans

post_author: it is important to increase your activity and fitness level in order to manage and reverse insulin resistance and prediabetes. Choose a physical activity you enjoy doing
post_date: and commit to at least three days per week. Moderate exercise is best
post_date_gmt: such as a brisk 30-minute walk each day
post_content: yoga
post_title: or tai chi. Combine cardio exercise with strength training or weight bearing exercise. Consider whether you prefer working out alone
post_excerpt: with a partner
post_status: or if you’d enjoy a group sport. Also
comment_status: add in some simple ways to get more active
ping_status: like taking the stairs or including stretch breaks throughout the day.
