A morning cup of joe can be great, but if you want to lower your caffeine intake
post_title: there are plenty of great coffee alternatives that can still provide the energy (and comfort) of your daily coffee. It's not necessary to avoid caffeine entirely
post_excerpt: but a coffee habit can quickly develop into caffeine dependence
post_status: especially if we're drinking it without really thinking. Taking the time to vary your routine with the coffee alternatives outlined below can be part of a larger mindful eating approach that will change your relationship with nutrition for the better.

ID: • Green tea is the quintessential coffee substitute. Green tea has a lot less caffeine than coffee
post_author: but still enough to give you a bit of an energy boost. This traditional Japanese tea is also packed with antioxidant health benefits from catechins
post_date: which are powerful disease fighters
post_date_gmt: and even more powerful than vitamins C and E in halting oxidative cellular damage. Green tea also contains L-theanine
post_content: which is great for focus.

ID: • Teeccino is popular with those coming off strong coffee dependencies. It has a flavor and mouthfeel similar to coffee
post_author: but without the overstimulation of caffeine. Teeccino is loaded with nutrients from fruits
post_date: nuts
post_content: and herbs
post_title: and also contains soluble fiber from inulin. Unlike coffee
post_excerpt: which can have a negative effect on gastrointestinal health
comment_status: and the inulin (derived from chicory root) acts as a probiotic
ping_status: feeding the good bacteria — bifidus and lactobacillus — as it travels through the large intestine.

ID: • Yerba mate is made from the naturally caffeinated leaves of the South African holly tree. It will give you the caffeine boost of coffee
post_author: but without the crash. Yerba mate is also significantly more nutritious than coffee
post_date: with an antioxidant profile similar to green tea
post_date_gmt: but with even more powerful health-promoting compounds like fatty acids
post_content: carotene
post_excerpt: trace minerals

post_author: and has a bold
post_date: sweet
post_date_gmt: and spicy flavor profile. Licorice supports the adrenal glands
post_content: and is recommended as a stress-relieving compound. Licorice is also used to promote gastrointestinal health
post_excerpt: and has anti-inflammatory and immune-boosting properties.

post_author: somewhat bitter brew
post_date: and has long been used for energy
post_content: concentration
post_title: and fatigue relief. It is also considered an adaptogen
post_excerpt: and is used to boost stress resilience.

ID: • Kombucha tea is known as a probiotic drink
post_author: but it is also high in B vitamins
post_date: particularly B12
post_date_gmt: which are fantastic for energy. Kombucha is also a great alternative for those looking to kick the sugary soda habit.

post_author: and is a great
post_date: anti-inflammatory and caffeine-free alternative to coffee. It is also rich in antioxidants
post_content: flavones
post_excerpt: which may combat cancer cells.

post_author: it may always be a part of your life in some way. But mixing in some of these coffee alternatives — or switching entirely — can help with your sleep
post_date: dental health
post_date_gmt: and mood. If you’ve decided to break your dependency on your daily cup (or five) of coffee
post_content: you have lots of alternatives to choose from to help energize
post_excerpt: and nourish you throughout the day.

post_author: we'll remind you to try to avoid energy drinks
post_date: which are loaded with sugar and caffeine. If it's pure energy you're after
post_date_gmt: it's better to go with the more nutritious options we outline here!)

Sugar effects on health are significant and often poorly understood. While most people understand that too much sugar can be unhealthy
post_title: they also continue to eat products with high amounts of hidden sugars
post_excerpt: leading to performance problems with both mind and body. Cereals
ping_status: bottled condiments and canned soups — these are just some of the common packaged and processed foods with a surprising amount of added sugars
post_password: not to mention sodas and sweetened beverages. Added sugars have harmful effects on metabolism and contribute to numerous diseases. There are many reasons why you may want to consider cutting added sugars out of your diet (or at least significantly limiting them).

post_author: vegetables
post_date: and other whole foods come in a perfect package of fiber and nutrition
post_date_gmt: nourishing your body and keeping blood sugar levels stable. Refined and highly processed sugars are different. While minimal amounts of natural sweeteners — such as raw honey and maple syrup — have some nutritional value and are mostly safe in moderation
post_content: cutting out added sugars like refined white sugar and high fructose corn syrup is the best option. Managing your overall sugar intake is vital.

ID: Sugar can be addictive. Sugar is chemically designed to be difficult to resist
post_author: and sugary foods are common binged. By stimulating the brain’s reward and appetite centers
post_date: fructose can inhibit satiety signals
post_date_gmt: making it difficult to moderate and limit intake.

post_author: and bring no benefit to the body — no vitamins
post_date: minerals
post_content: or proteins. Sugars like high fructose corn syrup and sucrose are calorie rich and nutrient poor. For this reason
post_title: they are often called “empty calories.\" High sugar consumption contributes to weight gain but often nutrient deficiencies.

ID: Sugars mess with your brain. Eating added sugars gives your brain a major surge of feel-good dopamine
post_author: resulting in intense cravings. Sugars from whole foods like fresh fruits and vegetables don’t cause this same spike of dopamine. Over time
post_date: your brain requires greater amounts of sugar to get a “fix” from a surge of chemical pleasure. That's why the more sugar you eat
post_date_gmt: the more intense your cravings become.

ID: Sugars prematurely age your skin. Too much sugar hinders collagen repair
post_author: resulting in glycation. Glycation occurs when sugar in your bloodstream attaches to proteins
post_date: forming harmful new molecules called advanced glycation end products (AGEs). Too much glycation negatively affects your skin’s collagen formation
post_date_gmt: thus determining how resistant your skin will be to wrinkle formation. In short
post_content: too much sugar makes you look older than your years.

ID: Sugars contribute to stress. Research shows that sugars can lower the stress hormone
post_author: cortisol. When you binge on sweets and refined carbs
post_date: your risk for insulin resistance goes up
post_date_gmt: and stress resilience bottoms out. Healthy stress management techniques
post_content: like exercise and meditation
post_title: are your best bet for finding your calm.

ID: Excess sugars cause weight gain. It’s no secret that too much sugar makes us fatter. The liver metabolizes sugar and converts it to energy
post_author: but only to a point. The liver converts excess sugar to fat
post_date: raising your risk for obesity
post_content: and cardiovascular disease.

ID: Sugar destabilizes your energy levels. We all know the infamous sugar high is followed by the dreaded crash. And you may feel even more sluggish than you did before you indulged in that sugary treat. Instead of refined carbs and sugars
post_author: opt for fresh fruits and veggies
post_date: and high quality proteins
post_date_gmt: to raise your energy throughout the day.

ID: Sugar is bad for your teeth. Sugars provide an easily digestible energy source for the bad bacteria in your mouth
post_author: contributing to bad breath
post_date: tooth decay

ID: Sugar effects can include contributing to cancer. Multiple studies link sugar consumption to a significantly higher risk of cancer. Having constantly elevated insulin levels — a result of regular sugar consumption — can contribute to cancer
post_author: as insulin is a key hormone in regulating cell multiplication and growth.

ID: The point is that sugar effects on your health are many
post_author: varied
post_date: and harmful. While it's difficult to eliminate all sugars from your diet
post_date_gmt: it's critical to regulate these negative sugar effects by moderating your consumption. Read nutrition labels. Plan your meals. Avoid relying on too many impulse snacks. You can have the occasional doughnut or ice cream sundae. The key is to treat yourself to one after making sure the meals and staples at the backbone of your diet aren't full of sugar themselves.

Like many people, you may be facing holiday travel. While it’s exciting to visit with family and friends, getting there and back can be stressful. It can also be unhealthy. Congested traffic
post_excerpt: poor quality food
post_status: and disrupted sleep can all take a toll on your health — especially if you are traveling by plane
comment_status: which exposes you to germs in an enclosed space.

post_author: it’s important to plan ahead for meals
post_date: exercise
post_content: so that your body can stay strong during the festivities. The last thing you need is a post-vacation cold or flu. Let’s take a look at some tips for staying well as you embark on holiday travel.

ID: • Pack healthy snacks. More than half of air travelers buy food in airports. That can lead to fast food
post_author: candy
post_date: chips
post_date_gmt: and other less-than-healthy options which weaken your immune system and leave you vulnerable to illness. Instead
post_content: plan ahead! Bring apples
post_excerpt: bananas
post_status: or a healthy meal for the flight. If you do buy food in transit
comment_status: the GateGuru app can help you locate healthy foods in your airport
ping_status: and HappyCow can help you find the best plant-based options. Opt for a fresh salad; some high-protein snacks like sliced veggies and hummus; raw
post_name: low-sugar energy bars. Avoid packaged processed foods with added sugars and heavy oils
to_ping: as well as sodas and alcohol. Bring an empty water bottle to fill once you get past security.

post_author: fresh fruit
post_date: and raw vegetables will keep you well-hydrated on the plane
post_date_gmt: and will help keep your sinuses from dehydrating — leaving you less susceptible to viruses. Try to drink plenty of water throughout your trip.

ID: • Keep moving and stay active. If you have time before your flight
post_author: take a brisk lap around the terminal. If you're staying in a hotel
post_date: use the exercise room or swimming pool. Bodyweight exercises are excellent for holiday travel. They offer an effective
post_content: no-cost workout. All you need is 20 minutes and some space to move around. Bodyweight exercises include squats
post_excerpt: sit-ups
post_name: and bicycle crunches. You can create your own circuit workout: do 12 to 20 reps of each
to_ping: with little rest in between. This will get your heart rate up while building strength.

ID: • Prioritize sleep. Make sleep a top priority
post_author: especially during the nights before you travel. Aim for seven to nine full hours of sleep (absolutely no less than six)
post_date: even when you're traveling
post_date_gmt: and take naps as needed. Sleep allows your body to heal
post_content: rest
post_excerpt: and is vital to good health and stress resilience. Research shows that skimping on sleep — even a few hours — leaves you more susceptible to catching a cold or flu the next day. And if you are taking a road trip to your destination
post_status: adequate sleep the night before is essential to staying alert while driving.

post_author: especially during air travel
post_date: is key to avoiding viruses and infections. When you cough or sneeze
post_date_gmt: do so in the crook of your elbow
post_content: and avoid touching your mouth
post_excerpt: and nose unless you’ve washed your hands.

ID: • Indulge mindfully. Enjoy your favorite holiday treats
post_author: just don’t overdo it. Fill 80 percent of your plate with steamed and fresh vegetables and fruits
post_date: and leave 20 percent for those foods you want to indulge in. Dark chocolate is a great indulgence that's easy to pack and has health benefits. If you want to avoid overly rich and sugary desserts
post_date_gmt: have a few squares after dinner
post_content: and really savor them.

ID: • Enjoy yourself and manage stress. Take time to fully appreciate and enjoy the company of your loved ones. Focus on quality time and fun activities. If certain family members are a source of stress for you
post_author: take breaks. Go for a walk outside
post_date: catch a quick nap
post_date_gmt: or retreat for a meditation to reset when needed.

post_author: you can enjoy holiday travel while keeping yourself healthy. The better you feel
post_date: the more energy you will have to enjoy the season.

A health coach can make all the difference when it comes to achieving your wellness goals.   Research backs up the power of health coaching.   https://www.aafp.org/news/practice-professional-issues/20160601healthcoaching.html http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0161269 http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1559827615592351?journalCode=ajla https://www.healthaffairs.org/do/10.1377/hblog20110921.013449/full/   EHE Health Coaching An incredibly effective, convenient, and flexible service, especially for those patients with identified health risks. EHE has credentialed health coaches, educators, and nutritionists whose collective expertise covers virtually any identified health risk. Major focal points of coaching include physical activity, nutrition, weight management, stress management, prediabetes management, and smoking cessation. Personal health coaches:
  • Work with patients for a full year after the EHE exam at no additional charge — it’s built into the program for anyone who wants it
  • Coach remotely by telephone, so it’s available no matter where the patient is
The initial session is called a “goals call,” during which the patient establishes what he or she wants to work on, identifies past challenges, current motivations, etc. Coaching can focus on one area or many areas — it’s entirely up to the patient. The entire process is patient-centric and designed to be encouraging, non-threatening, open, and flexible. Follow-up sessions are usually 15 to 20 minutes long and can be done on whatever schedule/frequency works best for the patient — weekly, biweekly, monthly, etc.    
"
post_title: Why Your Health Coach Is So Important

post_content: Seasonal affective disorder (SAD) is officially classified as a \specifier\" for a recurrent depressive mood disorder that occurs during a specific period of the year
post_excerpt: when the days are shorter
comment_status: and colder. While many people experience some form of winter blues
ping_status: if the sadness and lethargy persists for more than a week or two and tends not to respond to physical exercise or activities you usually enjoy
post_password: you may be one of the million Americans who suffer from SAD.

ID: Seasonal affective disorder is a type of depression. Most people with SAD experience the onset of symptoms during the fall and winter months
post_author: although it is possible to have seasonal affective disorder in the spring and summer. The symptoms can be profound and debilitating
post_date: and they worsen as the season progresses. These effects include fatigue
post_content: difficulty concentrating
post_title: and overeating sugar and high carbohydrate foods.

ID: The symptoms of seasonal affective disorder may fade with the arrival the next season
post_author: but the havoc they cause during can be severe. You may be left overweight
post_date: in poor physical condition
post_date_gmt: and with strained interpersonal relationships. Additional symptoms may include:

post_author: irritability
post_date: and anxiety

ID: • Sleep disturbances (sleeping too much or too little)
Seasonal affective disorder in the fall and winter tends to feature the symptoms of oversleeping
post_author: overeating
post_date: extreme fatigue
post_date_gmt: and trouble in relationships. When seasonal affective disorder arrives in the spring
post_content: symptoms are inclined toward insomnia
post_excerpt: and weight loss.

ID: The causes of seasonal affective disorder are not entirely known. There may be several different contributing factors
post_author: such as a sensitivity to decreased sunlight or changes in the body’s natural circadian rhythms leading to shifts in serotonin levels.

ID: Some people find antidepressant medications and talk therapy helpful. Many doctors prescribe light therapy
post_author: also known as phototherapy. With light therapy
post_date: patients are exposed to natural and artificial lights
post_content: on a daily basis. The therapy works by activating cells in the retina which connect to the hypothalamus
post_title: the part of the brain that helps regulate circadian rhythms. The majority of patients treated with phototherapy see marked improvement as soon as four days after beginning treatment. It's also important to maintain a regular sleep schedule
post_excerpt: and maximize your exposure  to natural daylight. Wake up early
comment_status: and spend some time outside each day — particularly in the early morning hours.

ID: While light therapy is an effective treatment for SAD
post_author: it may not be appropriate or helpful for everyone. Some people respond well to more (or brighter) light
post_date: but not everyone. Individuals with bipolar disorder may experience mania or hypomania when exposed to bright light
post_date_gmt: and those with diabetes or other pre-existing eye conditions should check with their doctor before beginning phototherapy. Remember that SAD
post_content: like other forms of depression
post_title: can have different causes. You have options when it comes to selecting the best treatment plan. The key is to establish a good relationship with a mental health professional who can help guide your progress.

ID: "
post_author: How to Cope with Seasonal Affective Disorder
post_content: open
\How do I boost my immunity?\" It's a question that gets asked all the time
post_title: but especially during flu season and colder months when everyone you know seems to be coming down with something.

ID: A vigorous immune system readily fights off pathogens and invaders
post_author: but if we are run down by nutrient poor diets
post_date: stress overload
post_content: our chances of getting sick increase. Luckily
post_excerpt: daily lifestyle adjustments you can make to support your immune system and optimize its ability to battle infection.

ID: Increase the whole foods and plants in your diet. Vitamins A
post_author: C
post_date: E
post_content: minerals zinc and selenium
post_title: and omega-3 fatty acids are vital to a functioning immune system. Whenever possible
post_excerpt: choose whole
comment_status: a wide array of fruits and vegetables
post_password: raw nuts and seeds are all good options. Stay hydrated with plenty of pure water. Avoid soft drinks
post_content_filtered: and refined starches and sugars. For an added immune boost

ID: Eat organic. Poor quality diets leave us nutrient-depleted and are a cause of weakened immune response. Fresh fruits and vegetables contain numerous vitamins
post_author: minerals
post_date: and phytochemicals that are essential for vibrant health. Citrus fruits
post_content: berries
post_excerpt: tomatoes
comment_status: and red peppers are among the many fruits and veggies loaded with vitamin C: a major immunity booster. Purchasing organic products as often as possible reduces your exposure to carcinogenic pesticides. If you’re shopping on a budget
ping_status: check out the Dirty Dozen and Clean 15
post_password: which lists the produce items most (and least) contaminated with pesticide residues.

ID: Manage your stress levels. Did you know that prolonged stress can lower the body’s disease-fighting white blood cell count? While some stress is normal and can even motivate us
post_author: excessive or chronic stress can be exhausting
post_date: leaving us run down and vulnerable to infection and illness. Learning to manage stress well is a key component of healthy immunity. Meditate
post_date_gmt: spend time with loved ones and pets
post_content: exercise
post_excerpt: and focus as much as you can on the things that bring you happiness. A therapist (or a trusted friend) call also serve as a good sounding board.

ID: Emphasize probiotics for a healthy gut. A healthy GI tract is key to a strong immunity. Probiotics are essential to maintaining great gut health. Balanced intestinal flora contribute to better nutrient absorption
post_author: and help keep the intestinal lining strong
post_date: forming a barrier against pathogenic microbes and other harmful substances. Probiotics help alleviate inflammation in the gut
post_date_gmt: which also supports healthy immunity and digestion. Eat probiotic-rich foods
post_content: such as kimchi and sauerkraut
post_title: and take a high quality probiotic supplement every day.

ID: Commit to exercise you enjoy. Getting moderate to vigorous exercise every day is one of the most important things we can do for our health. The key is to avoid overtraining
post_author: which can add to your body’s stress levels. It's vital to exercise in ways you genuinely like. You don’t want exercise to be one more chore you dread doing. Yoga can be excellent exercise for immunity. It promotes relaxation and a healthy stress response
post_date: helps lower stress hormones that negatively impact the immune system
post_date_gmt: and stimulates the lymphatic system to give toxins the boot.

ID: Prioritize sleep. Getting enough sleep is integral to good immune function. Aim for seven to nine hours of uninterrupted sleep a night
post_author: so your body can fully rest
post_date: repair
post_date_gmt: and charge up for the coming day. Practice good sleep hygiene habits. Take an hour (at least) to wind down before bed. Play soothing music or read a good book. Sip on some herbal tea
post_content: like chamomile
post_excerpt: or passion flower
post_status: which have relaxation-promoting compounds. Invest in cozy sheets
to_ping: so that you sleep in complete darkness. You want your bedroom to be a comforting
post_modified_gmt: and computers in other parts of the house. Quality sleep will supercharge your immunity.

ID: "
post_author: How to Boost Your Immunity
post_content: open

Are You Getting Enough Vitamin D? Vitamin D is the “sunshine vitamin”
post_title: and the array of health benefits it provides is significant. The two primary ways to get vitamin D are by exposing your skin directly to sunlight
post_excerpt: or through supplementation. Vitamin D containing foods are also helpful
post_status: but do not provide adequate levels of this crucial nutrient on their own. Studies have found that vitamin D’s impact on our overall good health should not be underestimated: it affects as many as 2000 genes throughout the body. Vitamin D is a fat soluble vitamin in a cluster of compounds that includes vitamins D1
ping_status: and D3. Without sufficient levels of this vitamin in our bloodstreams
post_password: we are at risk for bone abnormalities
post_modified: and even mood disorders. Let’s take a closer look at this nutrient powerhouse
post_modified_gmt: and some of the benefits it provides.

ID: • Immune System Support - By stimulating production of crucial peptides in white blood cells
post_author: and epithelial cells which line the respiratory tract
post_date: vitamin D helps ward off colds and flu
post_date_gmt: and protects the lungs from infection. Vitamin D may also modulate the immune response
post_content: and strengthen overall immunity.

ID: • Reduces Depression Symptoms - Research shows that vitamin D is a powerful way to support depression sufferers
post_author: as it helps regulate mood. Studies also suggest that vitamin D3 may be helpful for treating symptoms of seasonal affective disorder (SAD)
post_date: in conjunction with light therapy (phototherapy)
post_date_gmt: during the winter months when exposure to sunlight decreases in certain regions.

ID: • Maintains the Health of Teeth and Bones - By assisting in the absorption of calcium
post_author: Vitamin D promotes optimal bone density and dental health.

ID: • Aids in Diabetes Management - Vitamin D helps regulate insulin levels
post_author: keeping blood sugar levels stable.

ID: • Boosts Weight Loss - Receptors in the brain rely on vitamin D to keep hunger and food cravings in check
post_author: and to keep mood-elevating serotonin flowing. Vitamin D also optimizes the body’s absorption of many weight-loss boosting nutrients
post_date: particularly calcium. When our bodies are deficient in calcium
post_content: a fatty acid which converts calories to fat
post_title: can increase up to five times its normal amount. Vitamin D fueled nutrients help shift our bodies from fat storage mode
post_excerpt: to fat burning mode
post_status: helping us shift any excess weight we may be carrying.

ID: Research suggests that up to 75 percent of the US population is vitamin D deficient
post_author: so it's safe to assume that virtually anyone is at risk of deficiency
post_date: especially during the winter months. Due to widespread sun avoidance
post_date_gmt: the majority of our days spent indoors
post_content: and sunscreen use to prevent skin cancers
post_title: most of us aren’t getting enough vitamin D through natural means. Vitamin D is a vital nutrient
post_excerpt: so supplementation makes sense. The most natural way to make vitamin D is to expose your bare skin to sunlight for about half the time it takes to develop a sunburn - tanning is not necessary. However

As we've emphasized in the past, caffeine is no substitute for the energy you get from a healthy lifestyle. But moderate consumption of espresso can benefit your health in a number of ways. It's been shown to improve long-term memory

How to motivate others to make some of the healthy choices you're making? It's not so easy. Anyone who's found it difficult to get on the right path understands the frequent resistance of their loved ones to adopt similar lifestyle changes. Despite intellectually understanding the benefits of exercise
post_excerpt: they may feel too busy or hopelessly behind to start a fitness routine. No one doubts the power of eating healthy
post_status: but many of people are caught in dietary ruts and haven't been sufficiently motivated to change.

post_author: family
post_date: and colleagues have a secret weapon: you.

ID: You're proof that someone they know can break bad habits and start good ones. You're actively looking for articles like this one
post_author: and therefore motivated to motivate them. Unlike wellness gurus they may see on book covers or television
post_date: you're in their lives and in their corner. That's incredibly powerful
post_date_gmt: as are some of the specific ways you can be a daily or weekly motivational presence for people who know they need to get healthier but haven't had the right personal nudge in that direction quite yet.

ID: Here are some thoughts on how to motivate others:

• Help them find the \"why.\" Get clear on why better health is important to them. Maybe they're tired of their clothes not fitting. Maybe they're managing a health condition that requires better habits. Maybe it's vanity. Maybe it's a desire for more energy or better sleep or a prolonged life or higher performance. Maybe it's general prevention. Maybe it's something else. Regardless
post_author: the key is to connect them with a specific goal that feels personal. They will be more likely to take steps toward a destination when they've said
post_date: out loud

post_author: but it's essential. Use your own suggestions as motivation where appropriate
post_date: but actually hear what the other person is saying about what they want out of a different habit. Don't replace their story with your own. The more you understand their rationale
post_content: fears
post_excerpt: the easier the entire process will be.

ID: • Incentivize the process. If it’s been a while since they exercised
post_author: you may suggest a small system of self-bribery. This is especially true in pursuing the small bits of progress that ultimately add up to something like a smaller waist size. Try to come up with a rewards system that's built into your relationship with the person you hope to motivate. For instance
post_date: if you live with them
post_date_gmt: say you'll watch a show or movie of their choice after a healthy dinner together. If it's a friend
post_content: offer to take them out to lunch after they hit the gym. Figure out the best “habit loop” that makes sense for them. Habit loops involve a cue or trigger for the desired new behavior
post_excerpt: and then the reward. If they've found that similar tricks haven't worked when they've tried to use them
post_status: it's possible that having someone else as the protector/dispenser of rewards will provide the extra incentive they need to actually get the job done.

ID: • Don't be a scold or perfectionist. There's a reason you're helping to motivate someone — because change is difficult
post_author: and progress doesn't always go in a straight line. If and when there's a hiccup in the process
post_date: use it as an opportunity to refocus the person you're motivating on the big picture. While there's no one right way to motivate
post_date_gmt: the least productive \"how to motivate\" approach is one that involves shame or negativity or asking the other person to reach impossibly high expectations. Build some looseness and flexibility into your motivation.

ID: • Do be gently insistent. Try not to let them delay or slip out of their new commitment without explanation. Flexibility is good
post_author: but so are specific plans and start dates. Make it clear that life can interfere with plans and people are allowed the occasional day of laziness
post_date: but that this commitment is a commitment and means something to you. When they understand that you're part of this
post_content: they'll take it more seriously themselves.

ID: • Ask them to sign a contract committing to exercise or healthier eating. Act as a \"witness.\" When promises are put into writing
post_author: in the presence of another
post_date: they can feel more real. If feasible
post_content: reasonable) penalty into the contract
post_title: whereby your loved one will donate to charity or take care of a long-delayed task if they skip a workout or ignore their nutritional goals during the week. The contract should be specific in outlining the exercise and/or eating habits. Again
post_excerpt: externalizing and publicizing these goals can put the right kind of pressure on someone to follow through.

post_author: or visualizing the results you want as a motivational exercise
post_date: is great. That said
post_date_gmt: there is a caveat to be aware of in order for their visualizations to work. Once you’re clear on the outcome(s) they want
post_content: like toned muscles or amazing energy
post_title: help them to identify their internal blocks or resistance to change
post_excerpt: and strategize as to how they will overcome these barriers to success. If they know they’re more likely to follow through with exercise during a certain time of day
comment_status: make sure they focus on that window of opportunity.

ID: • Be a workout or meal buddy. This
post_author: more than anything else
post_date: is a practical way to help someone achieve real progress. Actually do the thing with them. Offer to go to the gym
post_content: or share meals. Bicycle together or cook together. Mutual support and accountability are powerful ways to keep their momentum fired up over time. Research shows that fitness clubs
post_excerpt: and workout partners increase exercise compliance
comment_status: and commitment to goals in the long term. Fitness buddies help you enjoy your workouts more
ping_status: and can offer support navigating slumps and discouraged moments along the way.

ID: There is no doubt that that making changes for the better requires commitment
post_author: and there may be times when your friends and family feel uninspired or unmotivated. Know that you will encounter those moments
post_date: and set them up for success by implementing tools and strategies that will keep them moving
post_date_gmt: even when the going gets tough.

internally observant mode.
starting at the top of your head

Health coaching benefits people in a variety of amazing ways. Whatever your wellness goals, a good coach can help you reach them. Here are some of the big ways in which a health coach can make all the difference. Expertise: There’s perhaps no resource more valuable than your coach’s knowledge — and his or her ability to convey that knowledge to you. A coach will distill the most important advice for any health journey, cutting through a lot of the contradictory information you may have heard to give you the most effective, up-to-date, and actionable advice. It’s expertise you can trust. Experience: The plan you devise with your health coach is tailored to your needs and circumstances. But there's no substitute for the experience the coach has acquired working with countless other patients, even if their own plans looked nothing like your own. Coaches understand how to handle any situation that develops, how to motivate, how to communicate, and how to adapt. Accountability: Being in regular contact with someone does wonders for your motivation. Aside from the coach's expertise, merely having an objective person involved in your goal-setting and progress makes the process far likelier to succeed. Externalizing your intentions — discussing them openly with a coach, instead of just letting them bounce around your head — is one of the keys to putting forward the effort required to follow through on them. A health coach makes you accountable. Big Picture Thinking: It's all too easy for us to get discouraged by short-term failure when pursuing health goals. A health coach helps to keep our eyes on the prize. Progress will not always follow a straight line. Coaching keeps us on track with a plan, which is essential to maintaining momentum, even through the tough moments. Partnership: A health coach is your partner in a journey toward wellness. At the end of the day, having another person walk with you, step by step, as you attempt to elevate your quality of healthy living, makes the experience less lonely and more engaging. Your friends and family support you, and a coach doesn't replace the emotional lift you can get from loved ones. But having a partner whose only interest is your health progress can be uniquely beneficial. Ultimately, health coaching benefits you by making you more educated and confident about the process of sustaining healthy habits over the long term. Regular contact with an expert makes you likelier to maintain momentum and positive results, even after the period of coaching ends. In this way, health coaching actually becomes one of the best ways to ensure long-term self-sufficiency. If you're an EHE patient, we really encourage you to use our health coaching program. It's an opportunity to learn more than you ever have about what goes into good health and holistic, preventive care. It helps you identify goals and stay on track. It enhances your journey toward wellness.

ID: "
post_author: How Health Coaching Can Change Your Life

Is dark chocolate healthy? While we wouldn't exactly call it a superfood, dark chocolate does have some remarkable health benefits, making it a good choice for dessert. It is loaded with vitamins
post_excerpt: and antioxidants
comment_status: dark chocolate has plenty of other advantages.

ID: Just to be clear: We're not talking about the processed
post_author: sugar-laden candy bars you'll find in the supermarket checkout aisle. We mean high-quality dark chocolate with at least 60 percent cocoa content.

ID: What makes dark chocolate healthy? Check out some of its benefits:
• Dark chocolate is a mood-booster. Dark chocolate is full of compounds that can help prevent depression
post_author: such as anandamide
post_date: which is structurally similar to THC but much milder. Anandamide can give you a good mood and energy lift
post_date_gmt: without the potential health concerns that come with other stimulating substances. Chocolate also contains phenylethylamine
post_content: which converts to mood lifting and stabilizing serotonin in the body.

post_author: and provides excellent free-radical protection. There are more polyphenols and flavonoids present in dark chocolate than in either tea or wine. These help neutralize free radicals
post_date: and shield the body from their potential damage.

ID: • Dark chocolate can lower blood pressure. The flavonols in dark chocolate can stimulate the endothelium (the lining of arteries) to produce nitric oxide
post_author: which then signals the arteries to relax. This lowers resistance to blood flow
post_date: thereby lowering blood pressure.

ID: • Dark chocolate may help prevent cancer. The rich supply of flavonoids in dark chocolate may account for its potential cancer-fighting properties. While studies are still emerging
post_author: they suggest that chocolate’s antioxidant properties possibly protect against free radical cellular damage that leads to cancer formation.

ID: • Flavonols favorably impact heart health. Eating flavonoid-rich dark chocolate is good for your heart. A study published in the International Journal of Cardiology reports that dark chocolate intake considerably improved heart circulation in healthy adults. The compounds in dark chocolate are also significantly protective against the oxidation of LDL
post_author: which causes less cholesterol to lodge in the arteries over time.

ID: • Dark chocolate may protect your skin against the sun. Flavonols can protect against sun damage
post_author: and also improve blood flow to the skin.

ID: • Dark chocolate is amazing brain food. One study showed that five days of high-flavonol dark cocoa consumption improved blood flow to the brain in healthy volunteers. Another study reports that dark chocolate consumption improved cognitive and verbal function in elderly adults with mental impairment.

post_author: vegetables
post_date: and tea are known as fantastic sources of antioxidants (and you should definitely consume lots of them)
post_date_gmt: research shows that the cocoa bean is an even more potent source. It features one of the highest concentrations of nutrients and antioxidants of any food. That makes dark chocolate healthy
post_content: as long as you enjoy it in moderation. Your best bet is to buy 100 percent cocoa or raw cacao powder
post_title: and add it to your smoothies
post_excerpt: whole grain cereals
post_status: or low-sugar homemade dishes. If you go with bars that are at least 60 to 70 percent cocoa
comment_status: one to three squares per day is all you need to enjoy the benefits.

post_author: Is Dark Chocolate Healthy? See How It Can Be!

Why You Might Want to Ditch Your Caffeine Routine   Caffeine is type of psychoactive drug found in coffee, teas, sodas, chocolate, and energy drinks, and is generally considered safe in moderate amounts; billions of people worldwide enjoy a caffeinated beverage (or a few) each day. We’re not suggesting you forever ditch your favorite latte, but, given the benefits of cutting out caffeine, you might want to.  
  1. Decreased jitters. Caffeine affects the central nervous system. It also stimulates the adrenal glands which release cortisol and activate the body’s fight-or-flight response. Many people report increased anxiety levels with caffeine consumption. Quitting caffeine can help you feel less anxious; especially if you are prone to panic or anxiety disorders.
  2. Fewer headaches. Caffeine often triggers headaches
post_title: and even migraines. This is a major reason why switching up your daily caffeine routine can cause withdrawal headaches. If you have a major caffeine habit and quit cold turkey
post_excerpt: you might get some intense symptoms. This is why weaning off caffeine over time works best for some people.

post_author: caffeine blocks the calm-inducing neurotransmitters that make you feel sleepy. Consuming caffeine after 12 noon is a common cause of poor and disrupted sleep patterns. Drinking coffee and energy drinks late in the day often hinders quality sleep
post_date: as it can take 4 to 7 hours for caffeine to fully work through your system.

post_author: caffeinated drinks results in healthier
post_date: whiter teeth: coffee and tea stain
post_date_gmt: and sugary sodas and energy drinks erode enamel and contribute to tooth decay.

ID: • Are you addicted? Caffeine is a psychoactive drug with addictive properties. It can cause some degree of physical dependency
post_author: which is why many people experience withdrawal symptoms such as headaches
post_date: nausea
post_content: and impaired concentration once they quit. Caffeine is not considered a major addictive drug; but many people quit the stuff due to its drawbacks
post_title: and don’t like the dependency created by leaning on it for energy every day.

ID: • Lessen hypertension. Caffeine can raise your blood pressure
post_author: so quitting contributes to lower blood pressure
post_date: and lessens the workload for your heart.

ID: • Improve your mood. Caffeine consumption can cause irritability and anxiety in some people
post_author: and many people feel a slump in mood and energy if they miss their routine cup of coffee. Quitting caffeine can contribute to feelings of calm
post_date: and may even out your mood and energy levels.

ID: Some studies suggest that moderate caffeine consumption may reduce depression in women
post_author: and lessen the risk of dementia
post_date: Parkinson’s
post_content: and stroke. A longitudinal Harvard study reports that caffeine consumption is not linked to increased mortality. While there may be some benefits to caffeine consumption
post_title: there are also negative effects in some people; like restlessness
post_excerpt: irritability
ping_status: and heartburn. Caffeine may also act as a diuretic in high quantities

ID: You may not need to quit caffeine totally
post_author: or you might find you feel best if you kick the habit entirely. If you do quit
post_date: you may experience withdrawal symptoms lasting two to nine days or so. Some people find that weaning off coffee or caffeine over days or weeks is a more manageable solution.

Heart disease symptoms may not be obvious. You might be vulnerable to cardiovascular issues but not realize it, especially if you haven't gotten recent screenings. Silent or atypical heart attack symptoms are especially prevalent in women and too frequently overlooked.

ID: Great awareness about the importance of a healthy lifestyle and advances in treatment methods have helped many people avoid heart disease or recover from it. That said
post_author: the risk is still sky high. Heart disease remains the leading cause of death in the United States. Recognizing these heart disease symptoms early can help you steer clear of disaster and motivate you to adopt healthier habits.
really tired. This is not typical fatigue
post_date: or simply feeling tired from lack of sleep. Fatigue associated with heart disease is extreme
post_date_gmt: and doesn’t go away. If your heart is struggling to deliver oxygen to other parts of your body
post_content: you will feel unusual levels of lingering exhaustion.

ID: Walking becomes painful. This pain can become extreme
post_author: and shouldn’t be dismissed. Cramping in the hips and legs that occurs when moving
post_date: walking
post_date_gmt: or climbing (but improves with rest) may be a sign of peripheral arterial disease
post_content: also called PAD. PAD occurs when there is fatty plaque buildup in the arteries of the legs. PAD is serious

ID: You feel dizzy at random times. This symptom has many non-heart related causes
post_author: but feeling faint or dizzy at random times may mean your heart is struggling. You may have an irregular heartbeat
post_date: or you may be at risk of heart attack. Dizziness can be caused by blocked arteries that lessen blood pressure
post_date_gmt: or faulty valves struggling to maintain blood pressure.

ID: Your feet swell. If your feet are sore
post_author: painful
post_date: and swollen
post_content: your heart could be in trouble. Heart-related foot swelling will typically be accompanied by other symptoms such as sudden weight gain
post_excerpt: and shortness of breath.

ID: You have episodes of sudden anxiety and nausea. The classic symptoms of a panic attack
post_author: such as anxiety
post_date: nausea
post_content: and sudden sweating
post_title: can also indicate heart attack. You may also feel fatigue
post_excerpt: pain and fullness in the chest that may radiate to the back
post_password: or shoulders. Get to the emergency room immediately if these symptoms are present. Do not wait. Those who arrive at the hospital within one hour of heart attack symptoms have the best chance of survival.

ID: You’re experiencing exercise intolerance. If you start feeling winded or unable to easily complete physical tasks you’re used to doing
post_author: like climbing stairs and working out
post_date: your heart may be in distress. If you suddenly need more rest after your normal physical activities
post_date_gmt: it might be smart to get your heart checked
post_content: especially if exercise intolerance occurs with other symptoms.

ID: You’re depressed. Depression is not necessarily a sign of heart disease
post_author: but people who have heart disease
post_date: or increased risk factors for heart disease
post_date_gmt: tend to be depressed. Check with your doctor if you’re depressed
post_content: especially if other symptoms are present.

post_author: arms
post_date: or chest. If you suddenly have significant new pain
post_date_gmt: whether or not it feels like the typical chest heaviness
post_content: check in with your doctor. Heart muscle cells run out of oxygen during a heart attack because of blocked arteries
post_title: triggering pain signals throughout the nervous system. The brain may confuse these nerve signals as coming from the back
post_excerpt: chest
comment_status: due to nerve proximity with the heart muscle.

ID: Your stomach or gastrointestinal tract is upset. Heart disease can present as nausea
post_author: vomiting
post_date: indigestion
post_content: especially in women. If you’re feeling particularly unwell
post_title: it’s always a good idea to check in with your healthcare provider.

ID: The guiding principle is to listen to your body. If something doesn't feel right
post_author: don't ignore it. These heart disease symptoms overlap with other conditions
post_date: so don't assume you are in serious cardiovascular trouble just because you have one or two of them. But monitor them closely and
post_content: talk to a doctor. And remember to reduce your risk of heart disease by quitting smoking
post_excerpt: minimizing stress

ID: "
post_author: The Hidden Heart Disease Symptoms You Need to Know
post_content: open

Vascular screening helps you assess your risk of cardiovascular disease by checking your blood vessels. Healthy blood vessels are elastic and smooth, allowing blood to flow easily through them. Heart disease causes weak spots in the vessels, as well as possible narrowing or blockage. A vascular screening detects these abnormalities.

ID: It's an especially important assessment if you smoke
post_author: or have a family history of heart disease
post_date: high blood pressure (hypertension)
post_content: or diabetes. Vascular screening is a key preventive health tool
post_title: providing insight into your level of risk and whether a medical intervention is advisable. Screenings are performed by trained technologists under the supervision of vascular surgeons and cardiologists. They are painless.

ID: Here are some common vascular screenings:
The ABI checks for signs of peripheral artery disease (PAD). PAD can be painful if left untreated
post_author: and may cause problems with walking. Serious damage can lead to limb loss. During this test
post_date: your technician will take your blood pressure in both your limbs and your ankles. If your blood pressure is lower in your ankles than your arms
post_date_gmt: this may indicate lower body blockages in your arteries.

ID: This test checks the arteries in your neck
post_author: which carry blood to the brain. During this safe and non-invasive screening
post_date: you lie flat on your back
post_date_gmt: and images of your carotid arteries are taken via ultrasound to determine the thickness of their walls. The thicker the walls
post_content: the greater your risk of heart disease. This assessment also checks how quickly and easily blood is flowing through the carotid arteries to determine whether there has been narrowing. If untreated
post_title: blocked arteries can lead to stroke.

ID: An abdominal ultrasound checks for abdominal aortic aneurysm
post_author: which is a weak
post_date: bulging spot in the abdomen's largest artery . The aorta leads from the heart to the abdomen
post_date_gmt: and then branches into two smaller arteries in the legs. For this test
post_content: you will again lie on your back as measurements and images of the abdominal aorta are taken via ultrasound. An abdominal aortic aneurysm occurs when the part of the aorta located in the abdomen swells and bursts
post_title: causing internal bleeding. About 75 percent of abdominal aortic aneurysm victims die before they reach the hospital.

ID: How Often Should I Have Vascular Screening?
If your tests show no risks and your health is good
post_author: your doctor will likely recommend a screening every five years or so. If your physician wants to keep a closer eye on things
post_date: a yearly test may be prescribed. Cardiovascular diseases are often silent until crisis hits
post_date_gmt: so preventive measures are crucial. Vascular screening detects cardiovascular damage
post_content: and also catches early warning signs sometimes missed by other testing methods. Early detection gives you a chance to adopt a healthier diet
post_excerpt: lifestyle and stress management techniques that can help prevent further damage to your body.

In recent years, the gluten-free diet has become more widely known and practiced. People with celiac disease
post_title: an autoimmune disorder that causes damage to the intestine when gluten is consumed
post_excerpt: removed gluten from their diets out of necessity. Increasingly
comment_status: a large group of people with non-celiac gluten sensitivity have followed suit
ping_status: using gluten-free recipes and reporting better digestion and energy. But what is the difference between non-celiac gluten sensitivity and celiac disease?

ID: Gluten is a composite of proteins found in wheat
post_author: barley
post_date: rye
post_content: spelt
post_excerpt: kamut
post_status: and other wheat-derived grains like durum
post_password: and helps foods like breads and pizza crusts maintain their shape and chewy texture. Gluten is found in baked goods
guid: and other foods. It’s often hidden in processed
post_type: and commercial foods where you’d least expect it. So-called “natural flavors

ID: Some argue that gluten isn’t an ideal food for anyone
post_author: as it’s difficult for the body to break down and digest. That said
post_date: gluten sensitivity
post_content: and celiac disease are specific medical conditions that have impact systemic and gastrointestinal health. Is it possible to have non-celiac gluten issues? Yes. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity is a real concern. So what’s the difference
post_title: and how do you know which is which?

ID: Celiac is a genetic autoimmune illness in which ingestion of gluten results in damage of gastrointestinal (GI) tissue. The body's response ultimately destroys and flattens the villi (villous atrophy) in the GI tract. This can lead to severe malabsorption of nutrients over time
post_author: resulting in poor health
post_date: inflammation
post_content: low body weight
post_title: lack of developmental growth in children
post_excerpt: and vulnerability to other illnesses
comment_status: and infections. There are over 200 identified symptoms of celiac disease
post_name: and behavioral changes. Dermatitis herpetiformis is celiac disease manifesting as a skin rash
to_ping: and is common in those with the condition. There is no known cure for celiac disease beyond managing it with strict adherence to a gluten-free diet.

ID: Non-celiac gluten sensitivity may present with symptoms similar to celiac
post_author: but it doesn’t cause the autoimmune response of CD
post_date: or the anaphylactic reaction that wheat allergies do. Some researchers suspect that NCGS does involve an immune component
post_date_gmt: but this isn’t established. While tests and biomarkers exist for CD (and for wheat allergies)
post_content: none conclusively indicate the presence of NCGS. Working with your doctor on an elimination diet can help distinguish non-celiac gluten sensitivity from other food intolerances.

ID: Wheat allergy is distinct from CD and NCGS. When someone has a wheat allergy
post_author: B-cells (a type of white blood cell) send out immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies to “attack” the wheat
post_date: while other chemical messengers are released to alert the body to the invasion. This causes a rapid reaction that can result in itching
post_content: swelling of the tongue
post_excerpt: nausea
comment_status: or anaphylaxis — which is potentially life-threatening. Children sometimes outgrow a wheat allergy
ping_status: but adults usually have it for life. It's managed with a strict wheat-free diet.

ID: • Celiac disease diagnosis involves blood tests to establish the presence of gluten antibodies
post_author: followed by a small intestinal biopsy to confirm villous atrophy. Patients must be on a diet containing gluten at the time of testing to get an accurate diagnosis.

ID: • Non-celiac gluten sensitivity diagnosis is made through a blinded food challenge.
• Wheat allergy diagnosis is via skin prick test or IgE testing that looks for wheat allergy in the blood.
If you have medical or personal reasons for going gluten free
post_author: keep in mind that when “gluten free” is listed on a food package
post_date: it doesn’t necessarily equate with healthier eating. The best way to ensure your health on a gluten free-diet is to adopt nutritious habits. If you can tolerate eating grains
post_content: certified (tested) gluten free grains like brown rice
post_excerpt: and quinoa. Be sure to eat lots of fresh fruits and vegetables
post_status: as well as high quality fats and proteins. Many packaged gluten-free foods are highly processed and contain refined starches
post_password: and those diagnosed with CD often fail to thrive after going gluten free when consuming these highly processed products. Choose your foods wisely to ensure optimal health

post_content: open
Colon cancer is one of the most common cancers in the United States. Roughly one in 20 people will be diagnosed with it during his or her lifetime. March is Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month
post_title: making it the perfect time to discuss some of the ways to lower your risk.

ID: Almost all colon cancer begins as precancerous polyps
post_author: or abnormal growths
post_date: in the rectum or colon. Polyps can also be benign
post_date_gmt: and may be present in the colon for years before cancer develops. Luckily
post_content: there are things you can do to lower your risk of developing colon cancer.

ID: Colorectal cancer screenings can detect precancerous polyps for removal before they turn into cancer. Screenings also give you a better shot at detecting cancer early
post_author: when it’s easiest to treat. The American Cancer Society and U.S. Preventive Services Task Force both recommend screenings starting at age 50 for those within a normal risk range. Your doctor can help you determine if earlier screenings are appropriate based on your health history.
but it's important to note that there are also non-invasive screening methods. The fecal immunochemical test (FIT) evaluates blood found in the stool. If occult (hidden) blood is detected
post_date: further testing will be needed. But FIT testing itself requires no drug or dietary restrictions
post_date_gmt: and it's less physically taxing than other screening techniques.

ID: Regular exercise is crucial to overall good health and a well-functioning immune system. Sedentary lifestyles are linked to increased risk of colorectal cancers. Research shows that active adults have a 40 to 50 percent reduced risk of developing colon cancer
post_author: and regular exercise may even reduce cancer risk in those who are obese or overweight.
fresh fruits
post_date: and vegetables. Purchase organic produce whenever possible to avoid ingesting carcinogenic pesticides. Diets rich in veggies
post_content: and whole grains are linked to lowered colon cancer risk. Eat less red meat
post_title: and avoid processed meats like hot dogs
post_excerpt: salami
comment_status: which have been tied to a higher colon cancer risk.

ID: Avoid foods processed with sodium nitrite. Highly processed commercial meats like bacon
post_author: sausage
post_date: and lunch meats are usually preserved with sodium nitrite. Sodium nitrite converts to nitrosamine in the body
post_date_gmt: which is a known carcinogen. The regular consumption of nitrites and processed meats have been linked with an increased risk for colon cancers compared to those who avoid them.

ID: Don’t smoke. Long-term smokers have a higher risk of developing and dying from colorectal cancers than nonsmokers do. If you smoke and need help quitting
post_author: look into smoking cessation programs. You can also refer to the American Cancer Society’s Guide to Quitting Smoking. Getting help and support increases your chances of quitting successfully.

ID: Limit or avoid alcohol. Colon cancer has been associated with heavy drinking. Recommended amounts are one drink per day for women
post_author: and no more than two per day for men. One drink equates to five ounces of wine
post_date: a twelve ounce beer
post_date_gmt: or 1 ½ ounces of 80 proof hard liquor.

ID: Remember that a preventive lifestyle is key to boosting your health and longevity over time. Any adjustments you need to make are well worth your efforts
post_author: but if change feels overwhelming
post_date: take it step by step. Quitting smoking and committing to regular colorectal screenings are two of the most powerful things you can do to reduce your risks. Over time
post_date_gmt: you can adopt a healthier diet with reduced intake of red and processed meats. Identify the most pressing risk factors potentially impacting your health
post_content: and implement a strategy to tackle them one by one.

Heart disease is the leading cause of death for women in the United States. Despite that distinction
post_title: heart disease is still often regarded as more of a men's health issue. Even now
post_excerpt: heart disease in women remains largely misunderstood. Women need to be aware of the risks
post_status: especially as heart disease symptoms in women can be different from the classic signs among men.

ID: The good news is that by eating a heart-healthy diet
post_author: getting regular exercise
post_date: and being more attuned to the symptoms and risks
post_date_gmt: women can do a great deal to protect themselves from the dangers of heart disease.

ID: Heart Disease in Women: Know the Symptoms
While some women experience the dull
post_author: achy
post_date: or sharp chest pains associated with a heart attack
post_date_gmt: others have no overt symptoms at all. Heart disease can be \"silent
post_content: \" going undiagnosed until a woman experiences a full-blown heart attack
post_excerpt: or stroke. Symptoms to monitor include:

post_author: extreme fatigue
jaw
post_date: neck
post_content: or abdominal pain or discomfort

ID: Heart disease in women can be subtle. Symptoms may be most acute during rest or sleep. Chest pain can seem like tightness or pressure
post_author: rather than the intense pains classically linked to cardiac arrest. Meanwhile
post_date: panic and anxiety attacks can mimic the signs of cardiac arrest
post_date_gmt: creating additional confusion. But these signs should always be treated seriously
post_content: especially if you don't have a history of such pain. If you think you may be experiencing a heart attack

ID: Heart Disease in Women: Understand the Risk Factors
While the traditional risks for heart disease — such as hypertension (high blood pressure)
post_author: high cholesterol
post_date: and obesity — should always be noted
post_date_gmt: the following factors are important risk considerations for heart disease in women:

ID: • Smoking. While smoking is a risk factor for both men and women
post_author: it’s an especially significant threat to women’s heart health.

ID: • Diabetes increases a woman’s chances of developing heart disease — even more so than it does for men.
• Pregnancy complications including high blood pressure can increase a woman’s chances of developing heart disease.
• Sedentary lifestyle and inactivity are major risk factors for heart disease.

post_author: upping the risk for coronary microvascular disease
post_date: or cardiovascular disease in the smaller blood vessels of the body.

ID: • Excessive alcohol use poses a significant risk to heart health
post_author: as does a poor diet high in artificial trans fats
post_date: and refined and highly processed foods.

ID: Many women underestimate the potential risks of heart disease
post_author: and awareness is key--even for younger women. To reduce your chances of getting heart disease
post_date: make sure to:

ID: <li>Eat a healthy diet high in fiber
post_author: whole grains
post_date: natural foods
post_date_gmt: and fresh fruits and vegetables. Avoid artificial trans and hydrogenated fats
post_content: added and refined sugars

post_author: and find healthy ways of coping — like meditation and deep breathing exercises.
cholesterol
post_date: and blood sugar within a healthy range.

ID: Remember that women don’t always present with the “classic” symptoms of heart disease. Protect yourself with a preventive approach to your health
post_author: and monitor any changes or symptoms you may be experiencing. If you notice any sudden shortness of breath
post_date: nausea or vomiting when you exert yourself
post_content: or changes in your activity levels

What is pharmacogenomics, and why should you know about it? Pharmacogenomics examines a person’s genome and how a genetic predisposition might respond to various medications. Genes provide the blueprints for the body's proteins. Different drugs target different proteins
post_excerpt: break down
post_status: and absorb the medication. By exploring how different drugs interact with different genetic profiles
comment_status: doctors can more accurately assess which treatment plans are best for someone.

ID: What works well for one person may be far less effective or even harmful for another. The aim of pharmacogenomics is to create highly targeted
post_author: personalized medical care
post_date: treating people's unique needs. With greater insight into someone’s genetic makeup
post_date_gmt: doctors can better select the medications and dosages for their patients.

post_author: drugs were developed under the assumption that they work pretty much the same for everyone. But genetic research shows that an individualized approach to pharmaceutical treatment produces safer and more powerful results. Genomics also help to identify potential non-responders to medications
post_date: and can help prevent side effects and negative reactions to medication.

ID: Pharmacogenomics mitigates the “trial-and-error” method of prescribing medications. It helps doctors find the best options faster
post_author: saving patients time
post_date: money

ID: Pharmacogenomics is an exciting new development in medical care
post_author: but there are currently some challenges and limitations.

ID: • Drug responses are not usually determined by a single genetic variant.
• There can be a broad number of intersecting environmental and genetic variants that influence how we respond to certain drugs.
<li>Side effects are often the result of a patient not taking a medication as directed
post_author: or from doctors prescribing the wrong dosage.

ID: <li>Pharmacogenomics won’t necessarily reveal the perfect medication for you or your condition. It can narrow the choices
post_author: and help your doctor find the right medication faster
post_date: but it’s not a perfect predictor of successful treatment. It also won’t predict potential drug-to-drug or drug-to-supplement interactions.

ID: <li>Tests won’t show how you might respond to every medication. Current research focuses primarily on drugs for mental illnesses and depression
post_author: cardiovascular conditions
post_date: HIV
post_content: and pain management.

ID: <li>A particular genetic variant can up the likelihood of an adverse reaction to a drug
post_author: but doesn’t guarantee it.

ID: Pharmacogenomics shows a lot of promise in the field of personalized medical care
post_author: potentially making drug treatment plans safer and more effective. More studies are needed. Additional clinical trials would further identify the link between genes and treatment outcomes
post_date: and also confirm initial findings
post_date_gmt: thereby translating them into more precise prescribing guidelines.

ID: Genome research can also help in the development of safer
post_author: better drugs with fewer side effects. Researchers now use genomic information to design drugs for subgroups of patients with specific genetic profiles
post_date: and also to search for drugs that target certain cellular and molecular pathways involved in disease processes. Despite some obstacles
post_date_gmt: pharmacogenomics shows promise as a powerful way to promote precision medicine
post_content: and may soon be part of routine medical care.

post_content: Dr. Tania Elliott is EHE's Chief Medical Officer and a board-certified allergist. Throughout March, she'll be sharing her expertise on allergies and how to manage them. Here she discusses what you need to know about hives. Hives are a common skin rash — one person out of five will experience them at some point. They can be triggered by a variety of substances or circumstances. Anything from pet dander to peanuts is a potential trigger for hives. As with any allergy
post_title: the most important thing is to recognize your personal triggers and avoid them as best as possible.

ID: <em>1) hives typically last in one place for less than 24 hours
post_author: they are itchy
post_date: and they don’t bruise or scar. When you press on them
post_content: meaning they turn white and then when you let go the blood comes back and the hive turns pink again.

ID: <em>Most other rashes stick around in one spot for days and don’t blanch. Rashes tends to spread locally
post_author: hives come and go in different areas of the body.

ID: <em>2) hives are caused when allergy cells get aggravated—-the most common causes—foods
post_author: medications
post_date: and infection. The allergy cells release a chemical called histamine
post_content: itching

ID: 3) people with allergies are slightly more prone to developing hives because they tend to have more allergy cells in the body. People with autoimmune conditions (when your body attacks your own organs) are also more prone to getting hives.

post_author: we sometimes recommend a low histamine diet! Believe it or not histamine is contained in a lot of foods. Every get an itchy mouth from eating pineapple? That’s because it’s high in histamine content!
aged cheese
post_date: processed meats

ID: <em>5) if you suffer from everyday hives
post_author: see an allergist to get to the root of the problem. Keep a log of food you eat
post_date: medicines you take
post_date_gmt: even over the counter and vitamins
post_content: and any recent infections you can think of or recent travel. We will need to do some detective work! Most of the time
post_title: we don’t uncover an underlying cause of hives
post_excerpt: but the treatment is daily

ID: <em>6) if symptoms ever progress beyond the skin
post_author: such as difficulty breathing
post_date: swelling
post_content: or vomiting
post_title: that is a serious emergency and 911 needs to be called.

Dr. Tania Elliott is EHE's Chief Medical Officer and a board-certified allergist. Throughout March, she'll be sharing her expertise on allergies and how to manage them. Here she recommends how to handle different indoor and seasonal allergies.     SEASONAL ALLERGIES: WHAT MIGHT I BE ALLERGIC TO? If you are experiencing symptoms in the early spring, tree pollen is the likely culprit. Late spring to summer is typically grass pollen, and weed pollen season begins in the late summer and can last up until the first frost. Interestingly, grass pollen counts tend to be highest the days after a thunderstorm. It is helpful to check daily pollen counts. On high pollen count days, staying inside might be the best bet.   WHAT TO DO ABOUT YOUR SEASONAL ALLERGIES Avoidance is key. During allergy season, keeping the windows closed and the air conditioning on while driving may be helpful. When coming inside after being outdoors, be sure to wash your clothing and hair to remove any of the pollen that may have been tracked inside. Do this before laying or sitting on furniture to prevent pollen transfer to the inside of you home. Pollens in particular are very difficult to control because of their prevalence in the environment. WHAT TO DO ABOUT INDOOR ALLERGIES   MOLD: The key to indoor mold control is reducing humidity. This can be done by covering cold, moist surfaces such as water pipes with insulation, as well as increasing ventilation. A number of academic and federal agencies have developed guidelines for controlling mold in the home, and additional information can be found at the environmental protection agency website at www.epa.gov/mold. Visible mold should be removed from surfaces with detergent and water, and any areas where mold is imbedded should be removed or replaced.   PETS: If you have a dog or cat that causes symptoms, be sure to keep it out of the bedroom. It is important to note that even when cats are removed from a home, the allergen can still persist for up to 6 months. The use of HEPA filters is most effective after the pet is removed from the home, in conjunction with a thorough cleaning.   DUST MITES: Dust mites tend to thrive in humid environments and create nests in sofas, carpets, bedding, and any woven material. The humidity level in the room should be kept at a minimum. This can be accomplished by using an air conditioner in humid environments or simply opening the windows in dryer environments. Remove any humidifier machines from the bedroom. Dust proof covers on pillows and mattresses are helpful, and bedding should be washed weekly in hot water (140°F) and dried under high heat in an electric drier. If it is not feasible to remove carpets, they should be vacuumed and/or cleaned frequently. Wearing a mask while cleaning may be useful. The best benefit is seen when all of these avoidance measures are utilized.   COCKROACHES: Avoid keeping out open food containers or eating in the bedroom. Keep the bathroom dry and clean. Bait-traps are useful.   MICE:  Mouse allergen is a recently recognized problem. The same principles apply as those for cockroach avoidance. Crawl spaces should be checked.  
"

Dr. Tania Elliott is EHE's Chief Medical Officer, a board-certified allergist, and a thought leader with the American College of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology (ACAAI). Throughout March, she'll be sharing her expertise on allergies and how to manage them.  At EHE, we believe knowing which small steps to take can lead to significantly better health. That's certainly true when it comes to allergies. All month long, I'll be sharing simple tips for preventing allergic reactions and mitigating symptoms. Allergies affect millions of Americans, and the pollen season beginning now can be particularly difficult. But with the right insight and actions, you can greatly reduce the impact an allergy has on your life. Overview of Allergies
  • More than 50 million people in the United States suffer from allergies, making it the 6th-leading cause of chronic illness.
  • Among the most common allergic diseases: Asthma, conjunctivitis, dermatitis, and hives.
  • Allergic rhinitis (commonly called \hay fever\") can be seasonal or perennial (year-round); symptoms typically include sneezing
post_excerpt: and itching or watery eyes. More than 20 million American adults and 6 million children experience allergic rhinitis.

ID: • Seasonal allergic rhinitis is usually caused by the immune system's overreaction to a trigger like pollen; perennial allergic rhinitis can result from sensitivity to substances such as pet dander or dust mites.
• Recent research suggests approximately 4 percent of Americans have a food allergy
post_author: with the number rising in recent years. Food allergies are most common among children.

ID: Allergies can present a range of symptoms. Seasonal allergies
post_author: food allergies
post_date: hives
post_date_gmt: and dermatitis are separate conditions with different symptoms. Seasonal allergies typically lead to sneezing
post_content: nasal inflammation
post_title: and irritated eyes. Rashes such as dermatitis and hives can indicate an allergic reaction to animal dander
post_excerpt: household products
comment_status: or the ingestion of certain medications and foods. Nausea and/or vomiting can result from food allergies. And symptoms commonly associated with other illnesses can also be a sign of allergic reaction.

ID: The important thing is to monitor symptoms like these and see if they recur. If they do not seem explainable by another illness
post_author: seek a consultation with an allergist.
depending on their severity
post_date: dangerous. But there are simple ways to address them. If you know what triggers your allergic response and how to protect yourself from them
post_date_gmt: you can move in the right direction.

ID: The most important step to take is to identify your allergy or allergies. The substances that cause certain people to develop an allergic reaction are called allergens. To safeguard yourself against them
post_author: you have to know what they are! That means going to an allergist and getting a safe
post_date: convenient
post_date_gmt: and accurate allergy test. When you discuss your symptoms and history with a doctor
post_content: you'll be far likelier to (1) know whether you have an allergy
post_excerpt: and (3) receive medication

ID: Pollen will get caught in your nose. The longer it's there
post_author: the more it will irritate your airways. That's why it's wise to keep the area clean
post_date: washing out pollen with a saline sinus rinse or nasal spray.

post_author: but it's advisable to keep the windows to your home (and car) closed as much as possible to avoid contact with allergens. Pollen can be airborne
post_date: and it's much more difficult to control your indoor environment when you let in the outdoors.

ID: You could be inadvertently bringing a lot of pollen into bed with you if you don't wash your hair and body first. That means you'll be breathing in the allergen for hours. Clean up before hitting the hay
post_author: and you will reduce the chances of hay fever. (For the same reason
post_date: try to avoid wearing to bed any clothes that might have come into contact with pollen. Otherwise
post_date_gmt: your bedding becomes a triggering environment.)

ID: • Wash your bedding weekly in hot water

post_author: laundering your sheets and pillowcases every week in water that's at least 140 degrees can eliminate most pollen and dust mites. Also dry using high heat rather than a clothesline
post_date: which exposes your clothes for long periods to the allergens you want to avoid.

ID: High-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters trap many of the most common allergens (like pollen)
post_author: thereby making them incredibly useful in preventing exposure to triggering substances. If your air conditioning does not come with HEPA
post_date: consider getting a portable air purifier with HEPA for the room or rooms where you spend a lot of time
post_content: HEPA-equipped vacuums can help with dust mites and other non-airborne allergens. Change the filters every three months.

post_author: and mold spores can be terrible for allergies. That's why it's vital to keep moisture to a minimum
post_date: especially in bathrooms
post_content: and basements
post_title: where water can seep into surfaces and create mold issues. You can measure your home's humidity with an inexpensive meter; try to keep it between 35% and 50%. Dehumidifiers and exhaust fans are useful when it comes to making the air drier. If you find mold
post_excerpt: scrub thoroughly with bleach.

post_author: cockroaches
post_date: or other insects in your home as it is. But since unwelcome visitors can bring allergens with them
post_date_gmt: often spreading them in areas you don't immediately notice
post_content: it's critical to take measures if you suffer allergies.

ID: Keep hydrated to help your nasal passages stay clear. Wear sunglasses to keep pollen out of your eyes. Make sure your pets are groomed and kept away from places where they're likely to leave dander
post_author: such as your bed. Check daily pollen counts so you can plan to be least exposed outside during times of highest pollen activity.

ID: Stay tuned for more allergy-related advice all month long!
"
