post_author: EHE Canyon Ranch Giveaway — Official Contest Rules
post_content: open

Dr. Tania Elliott is EHE's Chief Medical Officer, a board-certified allergist, and a thought leader with the American College of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology (ACAAI). Throughout March, she'll be sharing her expertise on allergies and how to manage them.  At EHE, we believe knowing which small steps to take can lead to significantly better health. That's certainly true when it comes to allergies. All month long, I'll be sharing simple tips for preventing allergic reactions and mitigating symptoms. Allergies affect millions of Americans, and the pollen season beginning now can be particularly difficult. But with the right insight and actions, you can greatly reduce the impact an allergy has on your life. Overview of Allergies
  • More than 50 million people in the United States suffer from allergies, making it the 6th-leading cause of chronic illness.
  • Among the most common allergic diseases: Asthma, conjunctivitis, dermatitis, and hives.
  • Allergic rhinitis (commonly called \hay fever\") can be seasonal or perennial (year-round); symptoms typically include sneezing
post_excerpt: and itching or watery eyes. More than 20 million American adults and 6 million children experience allergic rhinitis.

ID: • Seasonal allergic rhinitis is usually caused by the immune system's overreaction to a trigger like pollen or mold spores; perennial allergic rhinitis can result from sensitivity to substances such as pet dander or dust mites.
• Recent research suggests approximately 4 percent of Americans have a food allergy
post_author: with the number rising in recent years. Food allergies are most common among children.

ID: Allergies can present a range of symptoms. Seasonal allergies
post_author: food allergies
post_date: hives
post_date_gmt: and dermatitis are separate conditions with different symptoms. Seasonal allergies typically lead to sneezing
post_content: nasal inflammation
post_title: and irritated eyes. Rashes such as dermatitis and hives can indicate an allergic reaction to animal dander
post_excerpt: household products
comment_status: or the ingestion of certain medications and foods. Nausea and/or vomiting can result from food allergies. And symptoms commonly associated with other illnesses can also be a sign of allergic reaction.

ID: The important thing is to monitor symptoms like these and see if they recur. If they do not seem explainable by another illness
post_author: seek a consultation with an allergist.
depending on their severity
post_date: dangerous. But there are simple ways to address them. If you know what triggers your allergic response and how to protect yourself from them
post_date_gmt: you can move in the right direction.

ID: The most important step to take is to identify your allergy or allergies. The substances that cause certain people to develop an allergic reaction are called allergens. To safeguard yourself against them
post_author: you have to know what they are! That means going to an allergist and getting a safe
post_date: convenient
post_date_gmt: and accurate allergy test. When you discuss your symptoms and history with a doctor
post_content: you'll be far likelier to (1) know whether you have an allergy
post_excerpt: and (3) receive medication

ID: Pollen will get caught in your nose. The longer it's there
post_author: the more it will irritate your airways. That's why it's wise to keep the area clean
post_date: washing out pollen with a saline sinus rinse or nasal spray.

post_author: but it's advisable to keep the windows to your home (and car) closed as much as possible to avoid contact with allergens. Pollen can be airborne
post_date: and it's much more difficult to control your indoor environment when you let in the outdoors.

ID: You could be inadvertently bringing a lot of pollen into bed with you if you don't wash your hair and body first. That means you'll be breathing in the allergen for hours. Clean up before hitting the hay
post_author: and you will reduce the chances of hay fever. (For the same reason
post_date: try to avoid wearing to bed any clothes that might have come into contact with pollen. Otherwise
post_date_gmt: your bedding becomes a triggering environment.)

ID: • Wash your bedding weekly in hot water

post_author: laundering your sheets and pillowcases every week in water that's at least 140 degrees can eliminate most pollen and dust mites. Also dry using high heat rather than a clothesline
post_date: which exposes your clothes for long periods to the allergens you want to avoid.

ID: High-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters trap many of the most common allergens (like pollen)
post_author: thereby making them incredibly useful in preventing exposure to triggering substances. If your air conditioning does not come with HEPA
post_date: consider getting a portable air purifier with HEPA for the room or rooms where you spend a lot of time
post_content: HEPA-equipped vacuums can help with dust mites and other non-airborne allergens. Change the filters every three months.

post_author: and mold spores can be terrible for allergies. That's why it's vital to keep moisture to a minimum
post_date: especially in bathrooms
post_content: and basements
post_title: where water can seep into surfaces and create mold issues. You can measure your home's humidity with an inexpensive meter; try to keep it between 35% and 50%. Dehumidifiers and exhaust fans are useful when it comes to making the air drier. If you find mold
post_excerpt: scrub thoroughly with bleach.

post_author: cockroaches
post_date: or other insects in your home as it is. But since unwelcome visitors can bring allergens with them
post_date_gmt: often spreading them in areas you don't immediately notice
post_content: it's critical to take measures if you suffer allergies.

ID: Keep hydrated to help your nasal passages stay clear. Wear sunglasses to keep pollen out of your eyes. Make sure your pets are groomed and kept away from places where they're likely to leave dander
post_author: such as your bed. Check daily pollen counts so you can plan to be least exposed outside during times of highest pollen activity.

ID: Stay tuned for more allergy-related advice all month long!
"

A health coach can make all the difference when it comes to achieving your wellness goals.   Research backs up the power of health coaching.   https://www.aafp.org/news/practice-professional-issues/20160601healthcoaching.html http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0161269 http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1559827615592351?journalCode=ajla https://www.healthaffairs.org/do/10.1377/hblog20110921.013449/full/   EHE Health Coaching An incredibly effective, convenient, and flexible service, especially for those patients with identified health risks. EHE has credentialed health coaches, educators, and nutritionists whose collective expertise covers virtually any identified health risk. Major focal points of coaching include physical activity, nutrition, weight management, stress management, prediabetes management, and smoking cessation. Personal health coaches:
  • Work with patients for a full year after the EHE exam at no additional charge — it’s built into the program for anyone who wants it
  • Coach remotely by telephone, so it’s available no matter where the patient is
The initial session is called a “goals call,” during which the patient establishes what he or she wants to work on, identifies past challenges, current motivations, etc. Coaching can focus on one area or many areas — it’s entirely up to the patient. The entire process is patient-centric and designed to be encouraging, non-threatening, open, and flexible. Follow-up sessions are usually 15 to 20 minutes long and can be done on whatever schedule/frequency works best for the patient — weekly, biweekly, monthly, etc.    
"

post_content: closed
It's vital to exercise at any age, as the benefits of exercise are countless. It promotes longevity
post_excerpt: and supports a vigorous immune system and overall wellbeing. Combined with a healthy diet
post_status: a lifelong commitment to exercise is one of the surest ways to stay healthy as you get older.

ID: While some forms of exercise are doable at any age
post_author: modifications based on life stage are important. Your needs and abilities change over time
post_date: and while a good exercise regimen will benefit you no matter when you start
post_content: the sooner the better. Here are some tips in order to enjoy the benefits of regular exercise at any age.

ID: Childhood is the perfect time to encourage play and an active lifestyle
post_author: building the foundation for good lifelong habits. Kids who are physically active have stronger muscles and bones
post_date: leaner bodies
post_date_gmt: decreased risk of type 2 diabetes and other chronic conditions
post_content: and better confidence and mental health. Young children and teens have a variety of fitness options available to them
post_excerpt: swimming
ping_status: and outdoor games. Fitness guidelines for children and teens recommend:

ID: • Keeping periods of inactivity (besides sleeping) to under two hours at a time
• Vigorous activity for a minimum of one hour per day
This is the perfect time to establish a daily fitness and nutrition routine
post_author: especially post-college. If you have good fitness habits in place
post_date: continue with those sports and activities you already love doing. This is the decade to emphasize cardiovascular fitness
post_date_gmt: which supports your long-term health as you get older. Aim for 30 minutes of moderate cardio exercise five days per week
post_content: or 25 minutes of intense cardio three days per week.

ID: This is the decade to emphasize core strength
post_author: especially if you plan to get pregnant
post_date: and add interval training to your cardio routine to counteract a slowing metabolism. This is also the time to shore up and maintain your muscle mass
post_date_gmt: as most people lose muscle as they age. Weight training
post_content: weight-bearing yoga postures
post_excerpt: and anything that works to strengthen and build your muscles is a must.

ID: If you are already in great shape
post_author: this is an excellent time to increase your activity and take your fitness up a notch. The more exercise the better — this will protect your muscle mass
post_date: as well as your telomeres
post_date_gmt: which are stretches of DNA that promote longevity and cellular health. Alternate between moderate and vigorous cardiovascular exercise
post_content: and continue weight training. Bike
post_excerpt: brisk walks
comment_status: or take a fun new fitness class. The key is to keep moving
ping_status: and stay active. If you are new to the fitness game
post_password: jump in - your body will respond beautifully
post_name: and you will feel and look better than ever.

ID: Lowered estrogen and fluctuating hormone levels due to menopause can lead to mood dysregulation and potential bone loss. Exercise is excellent for stabilizing moods
post_author: and weight-bearing exercises are vital to maintaining muscle and bone mass. Aim for 30 minutes of daily weight-bearing exercise
post_date: such as yoga
post_content: tennis
post_excerpt: or weight training. This is also the decade to focus on protecting leg and lower body strength. Research shows a connection between leg strength and brain health as we age. The mechanism isn’t fully understood
post_status: but one theory posits that brain-stimulating neurochemicals are released when muscles are worked
comment_status: and leg muscles are some of the largest in the body. Regardless
ping_status: physical exercise that improves brain health is doubly important to pursue.

ID: The healthier and more fit you’ve been up to this point
post_author: the better. Make adjustments as your body requires — don’t ignore illness
post_date: pains
post_date_gmt: or signs of distress. But there is no need to slow down if you still feel good. Keep moving and stay active. The better shape you're in
post_content: the greater your vitality as you age. While weight gain is common after menopause
post_title: it's still possible to drop extra pounds and trim your belly at this life stage. It's also important to sustain excellent cardiovascular health
post_excerpt: and to reduce your risk of type 2 diabetes and various cancers. Light aerobic activity
comment_status: and gardening are all great options to keep moving. Strength training continues to be important in these years
ping_status: so try to do a full body workout with medium weights for about 40 minutes twice a week in addition to cardio activities.

post_excerpt: and anything that works to strengthen and build your muscles is a must.

ID: If you are already in great shape
post_author: this is an excellent time to increase your activity and take your fitness up a notch. The more exercise the better — this will protect your muscle mass
post_date: as well as your telomeres
post_date_gmt: which are stretches of DNA that promote longevity and cellular health. Alternate between moderate and vigorous cardiovascular exercise
post_content: and continue weight training. Bike
post_excerpt: brisk walks
comment_status: or take a fun new fitness class. The key is to keep moving
ping_status: and stay active. If you are new to the fitness game
post_password: jump in - your body will respond beautifully
post_name: and you will feel and look better than ever.

ID: Lowered estrogen and fluctuating hormone levels due to menopause can lead to mood dysregulation and potential bone loss. Exercise is excellent for stabilizing moods
post_author: and weight-bearing exercises are vital to maintaining muscle and bone mass. Aim for 30 minutes of daily weight-bearing exercise
post_date: such as yoga
post_content: tennis
post_excerpt: or weight training. This is also the decade to focus on protecting leg and lower body strength. Research shows a connection between leg strength and brain health as we age. The mechanism isn’t fully understood
post_status: but one theory posits that brain-stimulating neurochemicals are released when muscles are worked
comment_status: and leg muscles are some of the largest in the body. Regardless
ping_status: physical exercise that improves brain health is doubly important to pursue.

ID: The healthier and more fit you’ve been up to this point
post_author: the better. Make adjustments as your body requires — don’t ignore illness
post_date: pains
post_date_gmt: or signs of distress. But there is no need to slow down if you still feel good. Keep moving and stay active. The better shape you're in
post_content: the greater your vitality as you age. While weight gain is common after menopause
post_title: it's still possible to drop extra pounds and trim your belly at this life stage. It's also important to sustain excellent cardiovascular health
post_excerpt: and to reduce your risk of type 2 diabetes and various cancers. Light aerobic activity
comment_status: and gardening are all great options to stay fit. Strength training continues to be important in these years
ping_status: so try to do a full body workout with medium weights for about 40 minutes twice a week in addition to cardio activities.

ID: "
post_author: How to Stay Fit No Matter How Old You Are
post_content: closed
It's vital to stay fit, as the benefits of exercise are countless. It promotes longevity
post_excerpt: and supports a vigorous immune system and overall wellness. Combined with a healthy diet
post_status: a lifelong commitment to exercise is one of the surest ways to stay healthy as you get older.

ID: While some forms of exercise are doable at any age
post_author: modifications based on life stage are important. Your needs and abilities change over time
post_date: and while a good exercise regimen will benefit you no matter when you start
post_content: the sooner the better. Here are some tips in order to stay fit at any age.

ID: Childhood is the perfect time to encourage play and an active lifestyle
post_author: building the foundation for good lifelong habits. Kids who are physically active have stronger muscles and bones
post_date: leaner bodies
post_date_gmt: decreased risk of type 2 diabetes and other chronic conditions
post_content: and better confidence and mental health. Young children and teens have a variety of fitness options available to them
post_excerpt: swimming
ping_status: and outdoor games. Fitness guidelines for children and teens recommend:

ID: • Keeping periods of inactivity (besides sleeping) to under two hours at a time
• Vigorous activity for a minimum of one hour per day
This is the perfect time to establish a daily fitness and nutrition routine
post_author: especially post-college. If you have good fitness habits in place
post_date: continue with those sports and activities you already love doing. This is the decade to emphasize cardiovascular fitness
post_date_gmt: which supports your long-term health as you get older. Aim for 30 minutes of moderate cardio exercise five days per week
post_content: or 25 minutes of intense cardio three days per week.

ID: This is the decade to emphasize core strength
post_author: especially if you plan to get pregnant
post_date: and add interval training to your cardio routine to counteract a slowing metabolism. This is also the time to shore up and maintain your muscle mass
post_date_gmt: as most people lose muscle as they age. Weight training
post_content: weight-bearing yoga postures
post_excerpt: and anything that works to strengthen and build your muscles is a must.

post_content: and continue weight training. Bike

Dr. Tania Elliott is EHE's Chief Medical Officer, a board-certified allergist, and a thought leader with the American College of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology (ACAAI). Throughout March, she'll be sharing her expertise on allergies and how to manage them.  At EHE, we believe knowing which small steps to take can lead to significantly better health. That's certainly true when it comes to allergies. All month long, I'll be sharing simple tips for preventing allergic reactions and mitigating symptoms. Allergies affect millions of Americans, and the pollen season beginning now can be particularly difficult. But with the right insight and actions, you can greatly reduce the impact an allergy has on your life. Overview of Allergies
  • More than 50 million people in the United States suffer from allergies, making it the 6th-leading cause of chronic illness.
  • Among the most common allergic diseases: Asthma, conjunctivitis, dermatitis, and hives.
  • Allergic rhinitis (commonly called \hay fever\") can be seasonal or perennial (year-round); symptoms typically include sneezing
post_excerpt: and itching or watery eyes. More than 20 million American adults and 6 million children experience allergic rhinitis.

ID: • Seasonal allergic rhinitis is usually caused by the immune system's overreaction to a trigger like pollen; perennial allergic rhinitis can result from sensitivity to substances such as pet dander or dust mites.
• Recent research suggests approximately 4 percent of Americans have a food allergy
post_author: with the number rising in recent years. Food allergies are most common among children.

ID: Allergies can present a range of symptoms. Seasonal allergies
post_author: food allergies
post_date: hives
post_date_gmt: and dermatitis are separate conditions with different symptoms. Seasonal allergies typically lead to sneezing
post_content: nasal inflammation
post_title: and irritated eyes. Rashes such as dermatitis and hives can indicate an allergic reaction to animal dander
post_excerpt: household products
comment_status: or the ingestion of certain medications and foods. Nausea and/or vomiting can result from food allergies. And symptoms commonly associated with other illnesses can also be a sign of allergic reaction.

ID: The important thing is to monitor symptoms like these and see if they recur. If they do not seem explainable by another illness
post_author: seek a consultation with an allergist.
depending on their severity
post_date: dangerous. But there are simple ways to address them. If you know what triggers your allergic response and how to protect yourself from them
post_date_gmt: you can move in the right direction.

ID: The most important step to take is to identify your allergy or allergies. The substances that cause certain people to develop an allergic reaction are called allergens. To safeguard yourself against them
post_author: you have to know what they are! That means going to an allergist and getting a safe
post_date: convenient
post_date_gmt: and accurate allergy test. When you discuss your symptoms and history with a doctor
post_content: you'll be far likelier to (1) know whether you have an allergy
post_excerpt: and (3) receive medication

ID: Pollen will get caught in your nose. The longer it's there
post_author: the more it will irritate your airways. That's why it's wise to keep the area clean
post_date: washing out pollen with a saline sinus rinse or nasal spray.

post_author: but it's advisable to keep the windows to your home (and car) closed as much as possible to avoid contact with allergens. Pollen can be airborne
post_date: and it's much more difficult to control your indoor environment when you let in the outdoors.

ID: You could be inadvertently bringing a lot of pollen into bed with you if you don't wash your hair and body first. That means you'll be breathing in the allergen for hours. Clean up before hitting the hay
post_author: and you will reduce the chances of hay fever. (For the same reason
post_date: try to avoid wearing to bed any clothes that might have come into contact with pollen. Otherwise
post_date_gmt: your bedding becomes a triggering environment.)

ID: • Wash your bedding weekly in hot water

post_author: laundering your sheets and pillowcases every week in water that's at least 140 degrees can eliminate most pollen and dust mites. Also dry using high heat rather than a clothesline
post_date: which exposes your clothes for long periods to the allergens you want to avoid.

ID: High-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters trap many of the most common allergens (like pollen)
post_author: thereby making them incredibly useful in preventing exposure to triggering substances. If your air conditioning does not come with HEPA
post_date: consider getting a portable air purifier with HEPA for the room or rooms where you spend a lot of time
post_content: HEPA-equipped vacuums can help with dust mites and other non-airborne allergens. Change the filters every three months.

post_author: and mold spores can be terrible for allergies. That's why it's vital to keep moisture to a minimum
post_date: especially in bathrooms
post_content: and basements
post_title: where water can seep into surfaces and create mold issues. You can measure your home's humidity with an inexpensive meter; try to keep it between 35% and 50%. Dehumidifiers and exhaust fans are useful when it comes to making the air drier. If you find mold
post_excerpt: scrub thoroughly with bleach.

post_author: cockroaches
post_date: or other insects in your home as it is. But since unwelcome visitors can bring allergens with them
post_date_gmt: often spreading them in areas you don't immediately notice
post_content: it's critical to take measures if you suffer allergies.

ID: Keep hydrated to help your nasal passages stay clear. Wear sunglasses to keep pollen out of your eyes. Make sure your pets are groomed and kept away from places where they're likely to leave dander
post_author: such as your bed. Check daily pollen counts so you can plan to be least exposed outside during times of highest pollen activity.

ID: Stay tuned for more allergy-related advice all month long!

post_author: What Should I Know About Allergies?
post_content: closed
Colon cancer is one of the most common cancers in the United States. Roughly one in 20 people will be diagnosed with it during his or her lifetime. March is Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month
post_title: making it the perfect time to discuss some of the ways to lower your risk.

ID: Almost all colon cancer begins as precancerous polyps
post_author: or abnormal growths
post_date: in the rectum or colon. Polyps can also be benign
post_date_gmt: and may be present in the colon for years before cancer develops. Luckily
post_content: there are things you can do to lower your risk of developing colon cancer.

ID: Colorectal cancer screenings can detect precancerous polyps for removal before they turn into cancer. Screenings also give you a better shot at detecting cancer early
post_author: when it’s easiest to treat. The American Cancer Society and U.S. Preventive Services Task Force both recommend screenings starting at age 50 for those within a normal risk range. Your doctor can help you determine if earlier screenings are appropriate based on your health history.

ID: Regular exercise is crucial to overall good health and a well-functioning immune system. Sedentary lifestyles are linked to increased risk of colorectal cancers. Research shows that active adults have a 40 to 50 percent reduced risk of developing colon cancer
post_author: and regular exercise may even reduce cancer risk in those who are obese or overweight.
fresh fruits
post_date: and vegetables. Purchase organic produce whenever possible to avoid ingesting carcinogenic pesticides. Diets rich in veggies
post_content: and whole grains are linked to lowered colon cancer risk. Eat less red meat
post_title: and avoid processed meats like hot dogs
post_excerpt: salami
comment_status: which have been tied to a higher colon cancer risk.

ID: Avoid foods processed with sodium nitrite. Highly processed commercial meats like bacon
post_author: sausage
post_date: and lunch meats are usually preserved with sodium nitrite. Sodium nitrite converts to nitrosamine in the body
post_date_gmt: which is a known carcinogen. The regular consumption of nitrites and processed meats have been linked with an increased risk for colon cancers compared to those who avoid them.

ID: Don’t smoke. Long-term smokers have a higher risk of developing and dying from colorectal cancers than nonsmokers do. If you smoke and need help quitting
post_author: look into smoking cessation programs. You can also refer to the American Cancer Society’s Guide to Quitting Smoking. Getting help and support increases your chances of quitting successfully.

ID: Limit or avoid alcohol. Colon cancer has been associated with heavy drinking. Recommended amounts are one drink per day for women
post_author: and no more than two per day for men. One drink equates to five ounces of wine
post_date: a twelve ounce beer
post_date_gmt: or 1 ½ ounces of 80 proof hard liquor.

ID: Take a vitamin D supplement every day. Most people require some form of vitamin D supplementation
post_author: especially those in northern climates with colder winters
post_date: and those with darker complexions. Low blood levels of vitamin D have been linked with the development of colorectal cancers. Vitamin D is also key for healthy immune system function.

ID: Remember that a preventive lifestyle is key to boosting your health and longevity over time. Any adjustments you need to make are well worth your efforts
post_author: but if change feels overwhelming
post_date: take it step by step. Quitting smoking and committing to regular colorectal screenings are two of the most powerful things you can do to reduce your risks. Over time
post_date_gmt: you can adopt a healthier diet with reduced intake of red and processed meats. Identify the most pressing risk factors potentially impacting your health
post_content: and implement a strategy to tackle them one by one.

In recent years, the gluten-free diet has become more widely known and practiced. People with celiac disease
post_title: an autoimmune disorder that causes damage to the intestine when gluten is consumed
post_excerpt: removed gluten from their diets out of necessity. Increasingly
comment_status: a large group of people with non-celiac gluten sensitivity have followed suit
ping_status: using gluten-free recipes and reporting better digestion and energy. But what is the difference between non-celiac gluten sensitivity and celiac disease?

ID: Gluten is a composite of proteins found in wheat
post_author: barley
post_date: rye
post_content: spelt
post_excerpt: kamut
post_status: and other wheat-derived grains like durum
post_password: and helps foods like breads and pizza crusts maintain their shape and chewy texture. Gluten is found in baked goods
guid: and other foods. It’s often hidden in processed
post_type: and commercial foods where you’d least expect it. So-called “natural flavors

ID: Some argue that gluten isn’t an ideal food for anyone
post_author: as it’s difficult for the body to break down and digest. That said
post_date: gluten sensitivity
post_content: and celiac disease are specific medical conditions that have impact systemic and gastrointestinal health. Is it possible to have non-celiac gluten issues? Yes. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity is a real concern. So what’s the difference
post_title: and how do you know which is which?

ID: Celiac is a genetic autoimmune illness in which ingestion of gluten results in damage of gastrointestinal (GI) tissue. The body's response ultimately destroys and flattens the villi (villous atrophy) in the GI tract. This can lead to severe malabsorption of nutrients over time
post_author: resulting in poor health
post_date: inflammation
post_content: low body weight
post_title: lack of developmental growth in children
post_excerpt: and vulnerability to other illnesses
comment_status: and infections. There are over 200 identified symptoms of celiac disease
post_name: and behavioral changes. Dermatitis herpetiformis is celiac disease manifesting as a skin rash
to_ping: and is common in those with the condition. There is no known cure for celiac disease beyond managing it with strict adherence to a gluten-free diet.

ID: Non-celiac gluten sensitivity may present with symptoms similar to celiac
post_author: but it doesn’t cause the autoimmune response of CD
post_date: or the anaphylactic reaction that wheat allergies do. Some researchers suspect that NCGS does involve an immune component
post_date_gmt: but this isn’t established. While tests and biomarkers exist for CD (and for wheat allergies)
post_content: none conclusively indicate the presence of NCGS. Working with your doctor on an elimination diet can help distinguish non-celiac gluten sensitivity from other food intolerances.

ID: Wheat allergy is distinct from CD and NCGS. When someone has a wheat allergy
